chapters.chapter_title: I-The Old Sea-dog at the “Admiral Benbow”

events.title: Narrator's Introduction and the Captain's Arrival
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jim Hawkins, explains he is writing the story of Treasure Island at the request of Squire Trelawney and Dr. Livesey, omitting only the island's exact location due to remaining treasure.
He begins his account from the time his father ran the Admiral Benbow inn and a rugged old seaman first arrived.
Jim vividly recalls the seaman's appearance: tall, strong, with a tarry pigtail, scarred hands, black, broken nails, and a prominent sabre cut across one cheek.
The seaman surveyed the cove, whistled to himself, and then sang his characteristic sea-song: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
He rapped on the inn door with a stick and, when Jim's father appeared, roughly ordered a glass of rum, which he drank slowly while appraising the surroundings.
Declaring the inn a suitable 'berth,' he instructed the man with his sea-chest to bring it inside, stating his simple needs: rum, bacon, eggs, and a vantage point to watch for ships.
He asked to be called 'captain' and threw down three or four gold pieces, telling them to inform him when the money had been 'worked through.'
Despite his poor clothing and coarse speech, he possessed an air of command, like a mate or skipper accustomed to being obeyed.

The man who delivered the chest informed them that the captain had arrived by mail coach the previous morning, inquired about coastal inns, and, hearing theirs was well-regarded and secluded, had chosen it for his residence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Squire Trelawney, Dr. Livesey, and the rest of these gentlemen having asked me to write down the whole particulars about Treasure Island, from the beginning to the end, keeping nothing back but the bearings of the island, and that only because there is still treasure not yet lifted, I take up my pen in the year of grace 17—, and go back to the time when my father kept the Admiral Benbow inn and the brown old seaman with the sabre cut first took up his lodging under our roof.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And that was all we could learn of our guest.

events.text_segment:
Squire Trelawney, Dr. Livesey, and the rest of these gentlemen having asked me to write down the whole particulars about Treasure Island, from the beginning to the end, keeping nothing back but the bearings of the island, and that only because there is still treasure not yet lifted, I take up my pen in the year of grace 17—, and go back to the time when my father kept the Admiral Benbow inn and the brown old seaman with the sabre cut first took up his lodging under our roof.
I remember him as if it were yesterday, as he came plodding to the inn door, his sea-chest following behind him in a hand-barrow—a tall, strong, heavy, nut-brown man, his tarry pigtail falling over the shoulder of his soiled blue coat, his hands ragged and scarred, with black, broken nails, and the sabre cut across one cheek, a dirty, livid white. I remember him looking round the cove and whistling to himself as he did so, and then breaking out in that old sea-song that he sang so often afterwards: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
in the high, old tottering voice that seemed to have been tuned and broken at the capstan bars. Then he rapped on the door with a bit of stick like a handspike that he carried, and when my father appeared, called roughly for a glass of rum. This, when it was brought to him, he drank slowly, like a connoisseur, lingering on the taste and still looking about him at the cliffs and up at our signboard.
“This is a handy cove,” says he at length; “and a pleasant sittyated grog-shop. Much company, mate?”
My father told him no, very little company, the more was the pity.
“Well, then,” said he, “this is the berth for me. Here you, matey,” he cried to the man who trundled the barrow; “bring up alongside and help up my chest. I’ll stay here a bit,” he continued. “I’m a plain man; rum and bacon and eggs is what I want, and that head up there for to watch ships off. What you mought call me? You mought call me captain. Oh, I see what you’re at—there”; and he threw down three or four gold pieces on the threshold. “You can tell me when I’ve worked through that,” says he, looking as fierce as a commander.
And indeed bad as his clothes were and coarsely as he spoke, he had none of the appearance of a man who sailed before the mast, but seemed like a mate or skipper accustomed to be obeyed or to strike. The man who came with the barrow told us the mail had set him down the morning before at the Royal George, that he had inquired what inns there were along the coast, and hearing ours well spoken of, I suppose, and described as lonely, had chosen it from the others for his place of residence. And that was all we could learn of our guest.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Squire Trelawney, Dr. Livesey, and the rest of these gentlemen having asked me to write down the whole particulars about Treasure Island, from the beginning to the end, keeping nothing back but the bearings of the island, and that only because there is still treasure not yet lifted, I take up my pen in the year of grace 17—, and go back to the time when my father kept the Admiral Benbow inn and the brown old seaman with the sabre cut first took up his lodging under our roof.

I remember him as if it were yesterday, as he came plodding to the inn door, his sea-chest following behind him in a hand-barrow; a tall, strong, heavy, nut-brown man; his tarry pigtail falling over the shoulders of his soiled blue coat; his hands ragged and scarred, with black, broken nails; and the sabre cut across one cheek, a dirty, livid white. I remember him looking round the cove and whistling to himself as he did so, and then breaking out in that old sea-song that he used to sing at all hours of the day and night when he was dry, and the words of which I have now forgotten. But I remember that there were many verses, and that one chorus was always sung with a mighty flourish and a blow on the sills: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—
Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”

In the like old-fashioned way he came to the door and rapped on it with a stick, like a handspike. And when my father appeared, he made no answer at all, but stood looking past him into the inn. This was obliging enough, for the door stood open, and the supper table was set out with a good fire burning, and shining clean plates, and a steaming supper, ready to the minute. Presently he said, “Will any gentleman inform me where I am?” said he. “This is the Admiral Benbow, sir,” said my father, “the cove by Black Hill Cove.” “Well, then,” said he, “this is the berth for me. Here you, matey,” he cried to the man who trundled the barrow; “bring up alongside and help me in with this chest.”

The man who came with the barrow told us the mail had set him down the morning before at the Royal George, that he had inquired what inns there were along the coast, and hearing ours well spoken of, and that it was a quiet place, and where there was no great traffic of people, nor any other inns in the neighbourhood, he had come straight to us. And that was all we could learn of our guest.

He was a very silent man by custom. All day he hung about the cove or on the cliffs with a brass telescope; all evening he sat in a corner of the parlour next the fire, and drank rum and water very strong. Mostly he would not speak when spoken to, only glowering and blowing through his nose; but at other times, he would call for rum and water and tell stories of his life at sea. He had a thick, heavy, weather-beaten face; and his eyes were bloodshot and heavy-lidded. He was not cleanly, and his clothes were very coarse and dirty. But he had an air of command about him, and was used to being obeyed. He was a mate or a skipper—that was plain to see.

He had not been very long at our inn before he had got the upper hand of everyone. He was a terror to the neighbourhood, and the people were all afraid of him. He would sit in the parlour, and the folk that came in would be afraid to speak to him. He would sing his sea-songs, and the folk would be afraid to speak to him. He would tell his stories, and the folk would be afraid to speak to him. He was a terror to the neighbourhood, and the people were all afraid of him.

He had a great sea-chest with him. It was an old chest, and it was very heavy. It was bound with brass, and it was very strong. It was full of old clothes, and old pistols, and old cutlasses, and old charts, and old compasses, and old sextants, and old quadrants, and old telescopes, and old books, and old papers, and old money, and old jewels, and old gold, and old silver, and old copper, and old lead, and old iron, and old brass, and old tin, and old zinc, and old steel, and old wood, and old bone, and old ivory, and old horn, and old shell, and old coral, and old pearl, and old amber, and old jet, and old glass, and old china, and old earthenware, and old stoneware, and old porcelain, and old pottery, and old bricks, and old tiles, and old slates, and old stones, and old sand, and old gravel, and old earth, and old clay, and old mud, and old water, and old air, and old fire, and old light, and old darkness, and old heat, and old cold, and old wet, and old dry, and old hard, and old soft, and old rough, and old smooth, and old straight, and old crooked, and old long, and old short, and old wide, and old narrow, and old thick, and old thin, and old heavy, and old light, and old strong, and old weak, and old good, and old bad, and old right, and old wrong, and old true, and old false, and old real, and old unreal, and old living, and old dead, and old young, and old old, and old new, and old used, and old unused, and old whole, and old broken, and old clean, and old dirty, and old full, and old empty, and old open, and old shut, and old up, and old down, and old in, and old out, and old on, and old off, and old over, and old under, and old before, and old behind, and old beside, and old between, and old among, and old through

events.title: The Captain's Mysterious Habits and Jim's Secret Task
detailed_summary: The captain generally maintained a very quiet and reserved demeanor.
He spent his days observing the cove or the cliffs with a brass telescope.
In the evenings, he would sit in a corner of the parlor by the fire, drinking very strong rum and water.
He usually wouldn't speak when addressed, merely looking up suddenly and fiercely and blowing through his nose like a fog-horn, which led people to leave him alone.
Every day upon returning from his walk, he would inquire if any seafaring men had passed by on the road.
Initially, this was thought to be a desire for companionship, but it eventually became clear he wished to avoid such men.
When a seaman did stay at the Admiral Benbow, the captain would peer at him through the curtained door before entering the parlor and would remain completely silent in their presence.
Jim Hawkins understood the captain's anxieties, as he had been enlisted to help.
The captain had privately promised Jim a silver fourpenny on the first of each month if Jim would keep a lookout for a 'seafaring man with one leg' and inform him immediately of his appearance.

Frequently, when Jim asked for his monthly payment, the captain would initially just snort and stare him down, but he would invariably pay within the week and reiterate his instructions about the one-legged man.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He was a very silent man by custom.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Often enough when the first of the month came round and I applied to him for my wage, he would only blow through his nose at me and stare me down, but before the week was out he was sure to think better of it, bring me my four-penny piece, and repeat his orders to look out for “the seafaring man with one leg.”

events.text_segment: He was a very silent man by custom. All day he hung round the cove or upon the cliffs with a brass telescope; all evening he sat in a corner of the parlour next the fire and drank rum and water very strong. Mostly he would not speak when spoken to, only look up sudden and fierce and blow through his nose like a fog-horn; and we and the people who came about our house soon learned to let him be. Every day when he came back from his stroll he would ask if any seafaring men had gone by along the road. At first we thought it was the want of company of his own kind that made him ask this question, but at last we began to see he was desirous to avoid them. When a seaman did put up at the Admiral Benbow (as now and then some did, making by the coast road for Bristol) he would look in at him through the curtained door before he entered the parlour; and he was always sure to be as silent as a mouse when any such was present. For me, at least, there was no secret about the matter, for I was, in a way, a sharer in his alarms. He had taken me aside one day and promised me a silver fourpenny on the first of every month if I would only keep my “weather-eye open for a seafaring man with one leg” and let him know the moment he appeared. Often enough when the first of the month came round and I applied to him for my wage, he would only blow through his nose at me and stare me down, but before the week was out he was sure to think better of it, bring me my four-penny piece, and repeat his orders to look out for “the seafaring man with one leg.”

events.title: Jim's Nightmares and the Captain's Tyrannical Evenings
detailed_summary: Jim explains that the figure of the one-legged seafaring man deeply troubled his dreams, appearing in countless forms and with diabolical expressions, sometimes with a leg severed at the knee or hip, or as a monstrous single-legged creature.
He recounts nightmares of this figure leaping, running, and chasing him, feeling that these terrors were a significant cost for his monthly fourpenny.
Despite his fear of the one-legged man, Jim was less afraid of the captain himself than anyone else who knew him.
On nights when the captain consumed more rum and water than he could handle, he would sometimes sing his 'wicked, old, wild sea-songs' without regard for others.
At other times, he would demand drinks for everyone and force the trembling company to listen to his stories or sing along with him.

Jim recalls the house shaking with the chorus of “Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum,” with all the neighbors joining in out of fear, each trying to sing louder than the others to avoid drawing the captain's negative attention.

During these fits, the captain was an overwhelmingly dominant figure, slapping the table for silence and flying into a rage at questions or if he felt the company wasn't paying attention to his story.
He would not permit anyone to depart the inn until he had drunk himself into a stupor and staggered off to his bed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: How that personage haunted my dreams, I need scarcely tell you.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Nor would he allow anyone to leave the inn till he had drunk himself sleepy and reeled off to bed.

events.text_segment:
How that personage haunted my dreams, I need scarcely tell you. On stormy nights, when the wind shook the four corners of the house and the surf roared along the cove and up the cliffs, I would see him in a thousand forms, and with a thousand diabolical expressions. Now the leg would be cut off at the knee, now at the hip; now he was a monstrous kind of a creature who had never had but the one leg, and that in the middle of his body. To see him leap and run and pursue me over hedge and ditch was the worst of nightmares. And altogether I paid pretty dear for my monthly fourpenny piece, in the shape of these abominable fancies.
But though I was so terrified by the idea of the seafaring man with one leg, I was far less afraid of the captain himself than anybody else who knew him. There were nights when he took a deal more rum and water than his head would carry; and then he would sometimes sit and sing his wicked, old, wild sea-songs, minding nobody; but sometimes he would call for glasses round and force all the trembling company to listen to his stories or bear a chorus to his singing. Often I have heard the house shaking with “Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum,” all the neighbours joining in for dear life, with the fear of death upon them, and each singing louder than the other to avoid remark. For in these fits he was the most overriding companion ever known; he would slap his hand on the table for silence all round; he would fly up in a passion of anger at a question, or sometimes because none was put, and so he judged the company was not following his story. Nor would he allow anyone to leave the inn till he had drunk himself sleepy and reeled off to bed.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: How that personage haunted my dreams, I need scarcely tell you. It was not only that my fancy was so continually busy about my gentleman of the sea; that face, by day and night, was always present to my mind; but in my dreams he was the great trouble. I would see him in a thousand forms, and with a thousand diabolical expressions. Now the leg would be cut off at the knee, now at the hip; now he was a monstrous image which I would see in all my dreams of terror, and with which, at that time, I have often woke up screaming. Sometimes he was hobbling after me, sometimes he was only sitting and talking, but in all that was dreadful. For instance, I was always glad when I woke up and found that it was only a dream. And these terrors were, I believe, the main reason of my holding so cheap the price of my monthly fourpenny. There were nights when he took a great deal more rum and water than his head could carry; and then he would sit and sing his wicked, old, wild sea-songs, minding nobody; but more often he would call for glasses round, and force all the trembling company to listen to his stories or to join in his singing. The house would shake with ‘Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum,’ all the neighbours joining in with tremulous voices, for they dared not refuse; and all the time, I was sure, they were wishing they were anywhere else. For my part, I would have been glad to get away, but I dared not leave my post; and besides, I was curious to hear his stories, which were always about the sea, and about pirates, and about treasure. During these fits, he was the most terrible man to cross. He would slap the table till the glasses rang and jumped, and he would fly out at any question or remark that did not please him, or that he felt was not giving him sufficient attention. And he was not only terrible in a passion, and when he had been drinking, but capable of some kind of spasmodic and sudden attack of temper, even when he was sober. It was not till he had his grog inside him, I believe, that he would allow anybody to go to bed.

events.title: The Captain's Dreadful Stories, Financial Strain, and the Father's Decline
detailed_summary: The captain's tales were the most terrifying aspect for the inn's patrons, filled with accounts of hangings, walking the plank, sea storms, the Dry Tortugas, and wild deeds and locations on the Spanish Main.

Based on his own accounts, he must have lived among some of the most wicked men ever to sail the seas, and the language he used shocked the local country folk nearly as much as the crimes he narrated.
Jim's father constantly expressed fears that the inn would be ruined, as people would eventually stop coming to be tyrannized and frightened.

However, Jim believed the captain's presence, though frightening at the time, was ultimately a positive influence, providing a source of excitement in their quiet country life; some younger men even feigned admiration for him, calling him a 'true sea-dog.'
The captain was indeed on a path to ruin them financially, as he continued to stay week after week, and then month after month, long after his initial payment was exhausted.
Jim's father never found the courage to insist on further payment.
If his father ever mentioned the debt, the captain would blow through his nose so loudly it sounded like a roar and stare him out of the room.
Jim witnessed his father wringing his hands after such dismissals and is convinced that the constant annoyance and terror contributed significantly to his father's premature and unhappy death.

events.text_segment:
His stories were what frightened people worst of all. Dreadful stories they were—about hanging, and walking the plank, and storms at sea, and the Dry Tortugas, and wild deeds and places on the Spanish Main. By his own account he must have lived his life among some of the wickedest men that God ever allowed upon the sea, and the language in which he told these stories shocked our plain country people almost as much as the crimes that he described. My father was always saying the inn would be ruined, for people would soon cease coming there to be tyrannized over and put down, and sent shivering to their beds; but I really believe his presence did us good. People were frightened at the time, but on looking back they rather liked it; it was a fine excitement in a quiet country life, and there was even a party of the younger men who pretended to admire him, calling him a “true sea-dog” and a “real old salt” and such like names, and saying there was the sort of man that made England terrible at sea.
In one way, indeed, he bade fair to ruin us, for he kept on staying week after week, and at last month after month, so that all the money had been long exhausted, and still my father never plucked up the heart to insist on having more. If ever he mentioned it, the captain blew through his nose so loudly that you might say he roared, and stared my poor father out of the room. I have seen him wringing his hands after such a rebuff, and I am sure the annoyance and the terror he lived in must have greatly hastened his early and unhappy death.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: His stories were what frightened people worst of all. My father was a peaceable, law-abiding man. The doctor, who came now and then to see him, and wore a wig so large that he looked like a very big man, had little to say to the captain. But the other townspeople would now and then come in to the "Admiral Benbow" on their affairs, and I remember the terror they were in when he was there. A word or two of his conversation would pluck them up by the roots, and their colour would change, and they would hurry off with their business finished. Once a bold fellow stopped to blow some smoke in his face, but at the first glare of the captain's eye and a shout, he all but fell to the floor for fright.  Of course, the captain thought of nothing but himself, and yet at the time he was brought up to the door, he had said it was the quietest place he could find, and that was the reason he took to it. He stayed on week after week, and at last month after month, so that all the money he had was spent, and still he lived on at the "Admiral Benbow," never saying a word about payment, and none of us daring to ask him for a farthing. My father was sure the inn would be ruined, and his constantly repeated complaint was, that he was a poor man and must be ruined. My mother was more hopeful about the pay, but she was terrified of the captain's temper, and she was right, for once, when she ventured to speak to him, he roared at her so loud that I came running down-stairs to see what was the matter. The captain's stay was long. He was there at the beginning of the summer, and at the end of the summer, and throughout the autumn. He was there in the winter when the snow came, and he was there in the spring when the snow melted. And all the time he was there, he was a source of constant annoyance and terror to my poor father.  For my part, I was not so much afraid of the captain as I was of the other people who came to the inn. LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
His stories were what frightened people worst of all. Dreadful stories they were, of hangings, and of the Spanish Main, and of great storms at sea, and of the Dry Tortugas, and of deeds of blood and rapine. They were told in a loud, roaring voice, often punctuated by drunken oaths and bursts of his terrible sea-songs. When he was in his cups, which was frequent, he would bellow these tales across the common room, silencing the company and making the very timbers of the old inn seem to shudder. The quiet villagers, accustomed to the gentle rhythm of their lives, found these glimpses into a world of brutal violence and lawlessness deeply unsettling. They would sit stiffly, avoiding his wild, bloodshot eyes, wishing he would cease his terrible reminiscences.

It wasn't just the content, though; it was the man himself. His weather-beaten face, scarred and grim, seemed a living testament to the horrors he described. His sudden rages, his demand for rum, his constant fear of a seafaring man with one leg – all these added to the atmosphere of dread he brought with him. His presence was a dark cloud over the Admiral Benbow, a constant reminder that the peaceful shore was not immune to the storms brewing on the high seas. His stories painted a vivid, terrifying picture of the life he had led, a life so alien and dangerous that it chilled the blood

events.title: The Captain's Unchanging State and Dr. Livesey's Arrival
detailed_summary: Throughout his entire stay, the only alteration the captain made to his attire was the purchase of some stockings from a traveling salesman.
One of the decorative points of his hat had fallen, and he let it hang unrepaired, despite it being an inconvenience in windy weather.
Jim recalls the state of the captain's coat, which he mended himself in his room, until it was eventually nothing but a collection of patches.
The captain never wrote or received any letters and only spoke with neighbors, and then typically only when he was drunk on rum.
His large sea-chest remained unopened and its contents a mystery to everyone at the inn.
The captain was seriously challenged on only one occasion, which occurred towards the end of his stay when Jim's father was severely ill and declining.

Dr. Livesey arrived late one afternoon to see the patient (Jim's father), had a quick meal provided by Jim's mother, and then went into the parlor to smoke his pipe while waiting for his horse to be brought from the hamlet.

Jim followed Dr. Livesey into the parlor and distinctly remembered noticing the stark difference between the tidy, bright doctor, with his snow-white powdered wig and pleasant demeanor, and the rustic local people, but especially the contrast with their own 'filthy, heavy, bleared scarecrow of a pirate,' the captain, who was sitting deeply intoxicated with his arms on the table.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: All the time he lived with us the captain made no change whatever in his dress but to buy some stockings from a hawker.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I followed him in, and I remember observing the contrast the neat, bright doctor, with his powder as white as snow and his bright, black eyes and pleasant manners, made with the coltish country folk, and above all, with that filthy, heavy, bleared scarecrow of a pirate of ours, sitting, far gone in rum, with his arms on the table.

events.text_segment:
All the time he lived with us the captain made no change whatever in his dress but to buy some stockings from a hawker. One of the cocks of his hat having fallen down, he let it hang from that day forth, though it was a great annoyance when it blew. I remember the appearance of his coat, which he patched himself upstairs in his room, and which, before the end, was nothing but patches. He never wrote or received a letter, and he never spoke with any but the neighbours, and with these, for the most part, only when drunk on rum. The great sea-chest none of us had ever seen open.
He was only once crossed, and that was towards the end, when my poor father was far gone in a decline that took him off. Dr. Livesey came late one afternoon to see the patient, took a bit of dinner from my mother, and went into the parlour to smoke a pipe until his horse should come down from the hamlet, for we had no stabling at the old Benbow. I followed him in, and I remember observing the contrast the neat, bright doctor, with his powder as white as snow and his bright, black eyes and pleasant manners, made with the coltish country folk, and above all, with that filthy, heavy, bleared scarecrow of a pirate of ours, sitting, far gone in rum, with his arms on the table.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: All the time he lived with us the captain made no change whatever in his dress

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: All the time he lived with us the captain made no change whatever in his dress

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: All the time he lived with us the captain made no change whatever in his dress but to buy some stockings from a hawker. One of the points of his hat having been broken off, he still wore it cocked athwart his brows as was his fashion, while the great flap of the damaged brim hung down upon his shoulder. I remember the patch he made on one of the sleeves with a piece of blue cloth from his wife's skirt, and the queer, crooked fashion in which he sewed it on. The captain never wrote or received a letter, and for all that I could tell he never troubled his head about politics or business. His talk, when he was sober, was mostly about a former shipmate and his own doings at sea. For the rest, he was so quiet at table that you could have scarce told where he was. The only thing he seemed to care about was his great sea-chest, which he kept always beside him in his room, and which was never opened that I know of. He was only once seriously challenged, and that was towards the end of his stay, when my poor father was extremely ill, and Dr. Livesey came late one afternoon to see him. The doctor had his dinner with my mother and himself, and being a very pleasant, hearty gentleman, with a snow-white powdered wig, and eyes as bright as a coal, it was a pleasure to hear him talk. Presently he went into the parlour to smoke a pipe until his horse should be brought down from the hamlet, and I followed him in. I remember remarking the contrast betwixt the neat, bright doctor, and our own slovenly, old, rum-puncheon of a captain that sat, with his arms on the table, in a stupor of drunkenness.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: All the time he lived with us the captain made no change whatever in his dress but to buy some stockings from a hawker. He wore a suit of soiled blue cloth, the coat of which was ragged and shiny, and hung down to his knees. He had a formidable copper-coloured face, seamed with a sabre cut. He wore his pigtail tied up with a bit of tarry string, and his hands were always cut and scarred, with black, broken nails. He never wore a hat, not even in the sharpest weather; and I can see his bluff, weather-beaten face, and the two red spots upon his high cheek-bones, stand out clearly in my memory. His one possession of any importance was a great sea-chest, bound with brass, which stood at the foot of his bed. He was jealously careful of this chest, and it was long ere we knew what it contained. It was said to be full of curiosities from foreign parts—shells and strange stones, and Indian weapons and silver, tomahawks and cutlasses—but the only things we ever saw were a few old clothes, and a bundle of papers tied up in oilcloth. He spent much of his time alone in his room, poring over a chart or a book, or counting money; and the rest of it, when not drinking rum at the 'Admiral Benbow,' he would spend on the cliffs, with a spy-glass, looking out to sea. He was a silent man by custom, and only when he had drunk a great deal of rum did he become talkative, and then his talk was all of the sea, and of ships, and of strange places, and of the wicked deeds he had done. He was a terror to the neighbourhood, and we were all afraid of him.

events.title: The Confrontation: Dr. Livesey vs. The Captain
characters: Old Taylor (the gardener, mentioned by Dr. Livesey)
detailed_summary: The captain abruptly started singing his usual sea shanty about 'Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest.'
Jim reflects that he initially thought 'the dead man’s chest' referred to the captain's large box upstairs, a notion that had merged with his nightmares about the one-legged man.

By this point, everyone was accustomed to the song except Dr. Livesey, upon whom Jim observed it had an unpleasant effect; the doctor looked up angrily for a moment before resuming his conversation with old Taylor, the gardener, about a new rheumatism treatment.
Meanwhile, the captain grew more animated by his own singing and eventually slapped his hand on the table—a gesture everyone recognized as a demand for silence.
All voices stopped instantly, except for Dr. Livesey's, who continued speaking clearly and kindly, taking puffs from his pipe.
The captain glared at Dr. Livesey, slapped his hand again, glared even more intensely, and finally swore, ordering, 'Silence, there, between decks!'

Dr. Livesey inquired if the captain was addressing him, and upon the captain's affirmative (accompanied by another oath), the doctor stated he had only one thing to say: if the captain persisted in drinking rum, the world would soon be rid of a 'very dirty scoundrel.'
The captain's fury was immense; he jumped to his feet, drew and opened a sailor's clasp-knife, and, balancing it on his palm, threatened to pin the doctor to the wall.

Dr. Livesey remained completely unmoved, speaking over his shoulder in the same calm but loud tone, ensuring everyone could hear: 'If you do not put that knife this instant in your pocket, I promise, upon my honour, you shall hang at the next assizes.'
A tense exchange of looks followed, but the captain soon relented, put away his weapon, and sat back down, grumbling like a defeated dog.

Dr. Livesey then asserted that, knowing such a person was in his district, he, as both a doctor and a magistrate, would keep a constant watch on the captain and would take decisive action if there were any complaints, even for incivility like that night's.
Shortly thereafter, Dr. Livesey's horse arrived, and he departed. The captain remained subdued that evening and for many evenings that followed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Suddenly he—the captain, that is—began to pipe up his eternal song: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum! Drink and the devil had done for the rest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Soon after, Dr. Livesey’s horse came to the door and he rode away, but the captain held his peace that evening, and for many evenings to come.

events.text_segment:
Suddenly he—the captain, that is—began to pipe up his eternal song: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum! Drink and the devil had done for the rest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
At first I had supposed “the dead man’s chest” to be that identical big box of his upstairs in the front room, and the thought had been mingled in my nightmares with that of the one-legged seafaring man. But by this time we had all long ceased to pay any particular notice to the song; it was new, that night, to nobody but Dr. Livesey, and on him I observed it did not produce an agreeable effect, for he looked up for a moment quite angrily before he went on with his talk to old Taylor, the gardener, on a new cure for the rheumatics. In the meantime, the captain gradually brightened up at his own music, and at last flapped his hand upon the table before him in a way we all knew to mean silence. The voices stopped at once, all but Dr. Livesey’s; he went on as before speaking clear and kind and drawing briskly at his pipe between every word or two. The captain glared at him for a while, flapped his hand again, glared still harder, and at last broke out with a villainous, low oath, “Silence, there, between decks!”
“Were you addressing me, sir?” says the doctor; and when the ruffian had told him, with another oath, that this was so, “I have only one thing to say to you, sir,” replies the doctor, “that if you keep on drinking rum, the world will soon be quit of a very dirty scoundrel!”
The old fellow’s fury was awful. He sprang to his feet, drew and opened a sailor’s clasp-knife, and balancing it open on the palm of his hand, threatened to pin the doctor to the wall.
The doctor never so much as moved. He spoke to him as before, over his shoulder and in the same tone of voice, rather high, so that all the room might hear, but perfectly calm and steady: “If you do not put that knife this instant in your pocket, I promise, upon my honour, you shall hang at the next assizes.”
Then followed a battle of looks between them, but the captain soon knuckled under, put up his weapon, and resumed his seat, grumbling like a beaten dog.
“And now, sir,” continued the doctor, “since I now know there’s such a fellow in my district, you may count I’ll have an eye upon you day and night. I’m not a doctor only; I’m a magistrate; and if I catch a breath of complaint against you, if it’s only for a piece of incivility like tonight’s, I’ll take effectual means to have you hunted down and routed out of this. Let that suffice.”
Soon after, Dr. Livesey’s horse came to the door and he rode away, but the captain held his peace that evening, and for many evenings to come.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Suddenly he—the captain, that is—began to pipe up his eternal song: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum! Drink and the devil had done for the rest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!” All the sailors in the bar joined in, with a sort of fierce, drunken chorus. The captain would brook no interruption while he was singing. He would glare round with a bloodshot eye, and if he caught anyone not joining in, or daring to speak, he would bring his fist down on the table with a crash that made the glasses ring, and roar out for silence. He was the terror of the whole neighbourhood, and the people were as much afraid of him as they were of the devil. My father was a mild, quiet man, and he was afraid of the captain. My mother was a plucky woman, but she was afraid of him too. I was a boy then, and I was afraid of him most of all. He had a way of looking at you that made your blood run cold. He would sit there all day, drinking rum, and singing his dreadful song. He never spoke to anyone, except to order more rum, or to curse the sailors. He was a strange, wild man, and I never saw anyone like him. He had a scar on his cheek, and his face was all seamed and wrinkled. He looked like a man who had seen a lot of trouble. He had a big sea-chest in his room, and he was always very careful about it. He kept it locked, and he never let anyone go near it. I often wondered what was in it. One day, a man came to the inn. He was a tall, thin man, with a pale face and a black patch over one eye. He had a hooked nose, and his face was all pitted with smallpox. He was dressed in a long, black coat, and he carried a stick. He looked like a seafaring man, but he was not a sailor. He was a pirate, I knew it at once. He came into the bar, and he looked around. His eye fell on the captain, who was sitting in his usual place, drinking rum. The man walked over to the captain, and he stood there for a moment, looking at him. The captain looked up, and his face turned white. He knew the man. The man spoke to him in a low voice, and the captain answered him. They talked for a few minutes, and then the man turned and walked out of the inn. The captain sat there for a long time, without speaking. He was trembling all over. I had never seen him like that before. He was usually so bold and fearless. But this man had frightened him. I wondered who he was, and what he had said to the captain. I was to find out soon enough. The man was Black Dog, one of the captain’s old shipmates. He had come to warn the captain that the pirates were after him. The captain knew that he was in danger, and he was afraid. He was afraid of the pirates, and he was afraid of the sea-chest. He knew that the pirates wanted the contents of the chest, and he was determined not to let them have it. He was a brave man, in his way, but he was also a coward. He was brave when he was drunk, but he was a coward when he was sober. And he was always drunk. He drank rum from morning till night. He said it was the only thing that kept him alive. But I think it was the rum that killed him in the end. He was a strange, sad man, and I was sorry for him. But I was also afraid of him. He was a pirate, and he had killed men. I knew that he was capable of anything. I was glad when he was gone. But

events.title: Winter Hardships and the Captain's Morning Stroll
detailed_summary: The narrative commences during a particularly harsh winter, marked by prolonged, severe frosts and strong gales.
The narrator's father is critically ill, with little hope of surviving until the spring.
Overwhelmed with the responsibilities of managing the inn, the narrator and his mother have limited time or attention for their troublesome guest, the captain.
On a biting January morning, the captain awoke earlier than his usual habit.
He ventured out for a walk along the beach, carrying his cutlass under his coat, his brass telescope under his arm, and his hat tilted back.

The narrator recalls seeing the captain's breath form vapor in the cold air and hearing a distinct snort of annoyance from him as he disappeared around a large rock, presumably still vexed by Dr. Livesey.

events.text_segment:
It was not very long after this that there occurred the first of the mysterious events that rid us at last of the captain, though not, as you will see, of his affairs. It was a bitter cold winter, with long, hard frosts and heavy gales; and it was plain from the first that my poor father was little likely to see the spring. He sank daily, and my mother and I had all the inn upon our hands, and were kept busy enough without paying much regard to our unpleasant guest.
It was one January morning, very early—a pinching, frosty morning—the cove all grey with hoar-frost, the ripple lapping softly on the stones, the sun still low and only touching the hilltops and shining far to seaward. The captain had risen earlier than usual and set out down the beach, his cutlass swinging under the broad skirts of the old blue coat, his brass telescope under his arm, his hat tilted back upon his head. I remember his breath hanging like smoke in his wake as he strode off, and the last sound I heard of him as he turned the big rock was a loud snort of indignation, as though his mind was still running upon Dr. Livesey.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was not very long after this that there occurred the first of the mysterious events that rid us at last of the captain, though not, as you will see, of his affairs. It was a bitter cold winter, with long, hard frosts and heavy gales, and at the back of the inn they lay snow four feet deep on the level, and great drifts mixed with sand. These gales and frosts and snows wereombang to the health of my father, who had ever been a weak man, and who now lay dying, as they said, of consumption. My mother and I were kept very busy by my father's illness and by the hard weather, which greatly interfered with our business both at the inn and on the farm. The consequence was that remarkable old seaman took a sort of command upon himself, the more since Mr. Dance, the exciseman, who had fished the captain out of the brandy cask, had written to Dr. Livesey, and that gentleman had replied. The letter was not communicated to my father, but I heard some talk of the price of medicine, and how the doctor had come away swearing like a trooper. I was told, too, that the captain had protested that he was not afraid of not being afraid, and that if a doctor came to see him he would "blow the doctor out of the water." He would tolerate no words of advice or reproof, but did what he pleased and went where he pleased, and swore where he pleased. He would fire off his great blunderbuss in a vain humour, though not allowing anyone else to fire off so much as a pistol; and he broke all the glasses in the front parlour and threw a poor fellow, who had come in on Saturday night to taste the tap, out of the door with a broken head, and his fiddle smashed to firewood. For all that, mind you, it was not the money I thought so much of, but the fear. He was the terror of the neighbourhood, and the name of Captain was enough to bring all the countryfolk about our ears, begging us to turn him out. But who was to do that? He was strong and resolute, and knew the way to terrify a man. The doctor, indeed, talked big about arresting him for murder, if he stayed long and killed anyone; but he was gone himself every year to London, and said little when he was present; and my father was dying, and the business required all our attention, and we had none left to give to the captain. So that he continued to live among us, at a great expense, indeed, but much more annoyance, for he was the terror of the inn. In January, 17--, it was bitter cold and I could see the breath coming out of his nostrils as he lay in bed. One morning, about the middle of the month, he came down earlier than usual and I could hear him going about the room overhead. Then he came to the door and stood there for a long time, as if he was listening. I got up and went to the door and looked out. The captain was standing there, with his cutlass under his arm, and his brass telescope under his arm, and his hat tilted back on his head. He was breathing hard, and I could see the breath coming out of his nostrils. He stood there for a long time, as if he was listening. Then he turned and went out of the door and walked away. events.title: The Sinister Stranger's Arrival and Inquiry
characters: Captain (Billy Bones, referred to as 'mate Bill')
detailed_summary: While the narrator's mother attended to his sick father and he prepared the breakfast table for the captain, an unfamiliar man entered the inn's parlour.
The newcomer was described as having a pale, waxy complexion and was missing two fingers on his left hand; although he carried a cutlass, he didn't project the image of a skilled fighter.
The narrator, who often observed seafaring men, found this individual perplexing because he lacked a typical sailor's demeanor yet possessed an undeniable maritime aura.
When the narrator inquired about his needs, the man initially requested rum, but then gestured for the narrator to approach him before he could fetch it.
With a leering expression, the stranger asked if the breakfast table was intended for his associate, Bill.
The narrator replied that he was unacquainted with anyone named Bill and that the table was for a lodger they referred to as the captain.

The stranger insinuated that his 'mate Bill' and the captain were likely the same individual, describing Bill as having a scar on his cheek and a generally amiable disposition, particularly when intoxicated. He pressed the narrator to confirm if their captain had such a scar on his right cheek.
Upon learning that the captain was currently out walking, the stranger inquired about his direction and estimated time of return.
He made a disquieting remark that his arrival would be as satisfying as a drink to his 'mate Bill,' his facial expression causing the narrator unease.
The narrator privately suspected the stranger was either mistaken or insincere but felt it was not his place to intervene and was uncertain about how to proceed.

The stranger loitered near the inn's entrance, observing his surroundings with the watchfulness of a cat stalking prey. When the narrator briefly stepped outside, the stranger sharply summoned him back, his face contorting into a frightening expression when the narrator's response was not immediate enough.

Once the narrator was back inside, the stranger's demeanor shifted to a blend of ingratiating and scornful behavior; he patted the narrator's shoulder, expressed a newfound fondness for him, and likened him to his own son.
He pontificated on the importance of discipline for young boys, suggesting that experience sailing with Bill would have instilled prompt obedience, as that was characteristic of Bill and his crew.
Noticing the captain approaching with his spyglass, the stranger proposed that he and the narrator conceal themselves in the parlour to orchestrate a 'little surprise' for Bill.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: You and me’ll just go back into the parlour, sonny, and get behind the door, and we’ll give Bill a little surprise—bless his ’art, I say again.”

events.text_segment:
Well, mother was upstairs with father and I was laying the breakfast-table against the captain’s return when the parlour door opened and a man stepped in on whom I had never set my eyes before. He was a pale, tallowy creature, wanting two fingers of the left hand, and though he wore a cutlass, he did not look much like a fighter. I had always my eye open for seafaring men, with one leg or two, and I remember this one puzzled me. He was not sailorly, and yet he had a smack of the sea about him too.
I asked him what was for his service, and he said he would take rum; but as I was going out of the room to fetch it, he sat down upon a table and motioned me to draw near. I paused where I was, with my napkin in my hand.
“Come here, sonny,” says he. “Come nearer here.”
I took a step nearer.
“Is this here table for my mate Bill?” he asked with a kind of leer.
I told him I did not know his mate Bill, and this was for a person who stayed in our house whom we called the captain.
“Well,” said he, “my mate Bill would be called the captain, as like as not. He has a cut on one cheek and a mighty pleasant way with him, particularly in drink, has my mate Bill. We’ll put it, for argument like, that your captain has a cut on one cheek—and we’ll put it, if you like, that that cheek’s the right one. Ah, well! I told you. Now, is my mate Bill in this here house?”
I told him he was out walking.
“Which way, sonny? Which way is he gone?”
And when I had pointed out the rock and told him how the captain was likely to return, and how soon, and answered a few other questions, “Ah,” said he, “this’ll be as good as drink to my mate Bill.”
The expression of his face as he said these words was not at all pleasant, and I had my own reasons for thinking that the stranger was mistaken, even supposing he meant what he said. But it was no affair of mine, I thought; and besides, it was difficult to know what to do. The stranger kept hanging about just inside the inn door, peering round the corner like a cat waiting for a mouse. Once I stepped out myself into the road, but he immediately called me back, and as I did not obey quick enough for his fancy, a most horrible change came over his tallowy face, and he ordered me in with an oath that made me jump. As soon as I was back again he returned to his former manner, half fawning, half sneering, patted me on the shoulder, told me I was a good boy and he had taken quite a fancy to me. “I have a son of my own,” said he, “as like you as two blocks, and he’s all the pride of my ’art. But the great thing for boys is discipline, sonny—discipline. Now, if you had sailed along of Bill, you wouldn’t have stood there to be spoke to twice—not you. That was never Bill’s way, nor the way of sich as sailed with him. And here, sure enough, is my mate Bill, with a spy-glass under his arm, bless his old ’art, to be sure. You and me’ll just go back into the parlour, sonny, and get behind the door, and we’ll give Bill a little surprise—bless his ’art, I say again.”

He was pale and tallowy, and had lost the two middle fingers of his left hand, and though he wore a cutlass, he did not look much like a fighter. simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: Well, mother was upstairs with father and I was laying the breakfast-table against the captain’s return when the parlour door opened and a man stepped in on whom I had never set my eyes before. He was pale and tallowy, and had lost the two middle fingers of his left hand, and though he wore a cutlass, he did not look much like a fighter. He asked for a glass of rum, and when I brought it to him, he made me a sign to come near. 'Come here, sonny,' said he. 'Come nearer, if you please. Is this table for my mate Bill?' I told him I did not know his mate Bill, and this table was for a lodger that we called the captain. 'Well,' said he, 'my mate Bill would be called the captain, likely. He has a cut on one cheek, and a pleasant, genial countenance, has my mate Bill, and a most engaging way with him, particularly when drunk. Is that your captain, sonny?' 'Yes, sir,' said I. 'Has he a cut on his right cheek?' I told him he had. 'Come, no more words about it,' said he. 'See here, matey,' and he tapped me on the shoulder, 'I know where Bill is. Let him come when he will, he’s to have the Black Spot. When he gets that, he’ll know what it means.' He made me a sign to be silent, and then he went to the door and looked out. He stood there for a long time, looking up and down the road, and then he came back and sat down again. He was very restless, and he kept looking at the door. Presently, I saw the captain coming down the road with his spy-glass under his arm. 'Ah,' said the stranger, 'here comes my mate Bill. Now, sonny, you and me will just step back into the parlour and have a little surprise for Bill. I’ve a notion,' he added, 'that Bill will be glad to see me.'

events.title: Anxious Wait for the Captain's Return
detailed_summary: Following his suggestion, the stranger led the narrator into the parlour, positioning them both behind the open door to ensure they were concealed from view.
The narrator experienced intense unease and alarm due to the unfolding situation.
His apprehension was heightened by the observation that the stranger himself was evidently quite frightened.
The stranger readied his weapon, ensuring the hilt of his cutlass was free and the blade was loose within its scabbard.
During their period of waiting, the stranger frequently swallowed, an action indicative of nervousness, as if he were struggling with a constricted throat.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So saying, the stranger backed along with me into the parlour and put me behind him in the corner so that we were both hidden by the open door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He cleared the hilt of his cutlass and loosened the blade in the sheath; and all the time we were waiting there he kept swallowing as if he felt what we used to call a lump in the throat.

events.text_segment: So saying, the stranger backed along with me into the parlour and put me behind him in the corner so that we were both hidden by the open door. I was very uneasy and alarmed, as you may fancy, and it rather added to my fears to observe that the stranger was certainly frightened himself. He cleared the hilt of his cutlass and loosened the blade in the sheath; and all the time we were waiting there he kept swallowing as if he felt what we used to call a lump in the throat.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: So saying, the stranger backed along with me into the parlour and put me behind him in the corner so that we were both hidden by the open door. I was filled with terror, I knew not why. The stranger was looking pale and sweated freely, and his hands shook, and his voice trembled when he spoke to me. He had his cutlass ready, drawn only an inch or two from the sheath; and it seemed to me he was trying to keep back a cough, and swallowed a great deal, and kept licking his lips.

events.title: The Captain's Shocking Reunion with Black Dog
detailed_summary: The captain finally entered, closing the door forcefully behind him, and proceeded directly to his breakfast table without scanning the room.
The stranger, attempting a bold tone, called out the name "Bill."
The captain spun around, his face losing all color, his expression one of a man seeing a ghost or something even more dreadful; even his nose appeared blue.
The narrator momentarily felt sorry for the captain, who seemed to age and sicken instantly.
The stranger identified himself, reminding Bill that he was an old shipmate.
The captain audibly gasped and uttered the name, "Black Dog!"

Black Dog affirmed his identity, stating he had come to the Admiral Benbow inn to visit his old companion Billy, and made a reference to their shared past by displaying his mutilated hand, mentioning the loss of his "two talons."
The captain, acknowledging that Black Dog had found him, curtly asked him to state his business.

Black Dog confirmed the captain's understanding and then requested a glass of rum, to be fetched by the narrator, for whom he claimed to have developed a fondness. He proposed they sit down and converse frankly, as old shipmates would.
By the time the narrator returned with the rum, the captain and Black Dog were seated on opposite sides of the breakfast table.
Black Dog had chosen a seat near the door, positioned sideways, allowing him to watch both the captain and, as the narrator presumed, his own potential escape route.
He instructed the narrator to leave the room and to ensure the door remained wide open, explicitly stating he did not want to be spied upon through keyholes.
The narrator complied, leaving them alone and retreating to the bar area.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At last in strode the captain, slammed the door behind him, without looking to the right or left, and marched straight across the room to where his breakfast awaited him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “None of your keyholes for me, sonny,” he said; and I left them together and retired into the bar.

events.text_segment:
At last in strode the captain, slammed the door behind him, without looking to the right or left, and marched straight across the room to where his breakfast awaited him.
“Bill,” said the stranger in a voice that I thought he had tried to make bold and big.
The captain spun round on his heel and fronted us; all the brown had gone out of his face, and even his nose was blue; he had the look of a man who sees a ghost, or the evil one, or something worse, if anything can be; and upon my word, I felt sorry to see him all in a moment turn so old and sick.
“Come, Bill, you know me; you know an old shipmate, Bill, surely,” said the stranger.
The captain made a sort of gasp.
“Black Dog!” said he.
“And who else?” returned the other, getting more at his ease. “Black Dog as ever was, come for to see his old shipmate Billy, at the Admiral Benbow inn. Ah, Bill, Bill, we have seen a sight of times, us two, since I lost them two talons,” holding up his mutilated hand.
“Now, look here,” said the captain; “you’ve run me down; here I am; well, then, speak up; what is it?”
“That’s you, Bill,” returned Black Dog, “you’re in the right of it, Billy. I’ll have a glass of rum from this dear child here, as I’ve took such a liking to; and we’ll sit down, if you please, and talk square, like old shipmates.”
When I returned with the rum, they were already seated on either side of the captain’s breakfast-table—Black Dog next to the door and sitting sideways so as to have one eye on his old shipmate and one, as I thought, on his retreat.
He bade me go and leave the door wide open. “None of your keyholes for me, sonny,” he said; and I left them together and retired into the bar.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: At last in strode the captain, slammed the door behind him, without looking to the right or left, and marched straight across the room to where his breakfast awaited him. He was a tall, strong, heavy man; and his face was a nut-brown colour, seamed and scarred with sabre cuts, and marked with an ugly, livid scar of a dirty white. He had a pigtail, a soiled blue coat, which was all on one side, and a brass-buttoned coat, and a cutlass-hang of his coat-tails. He was a formidable-looking fellow, and I was always afraid of him. He sat down at the table, and without a word, began to eat his eggs and bacon. He ate heartily, and drank deeply of the rum that was always set before him. His eyes were restless, darting about the room, as if he expected someone or something. He never spoke to anyone unless he was spoken to, and then his replies were short and gruff. He paid his way, and paid well, but he was a terror to the neighbourhood. He would sit all day in the inn parlour, smoking his pipe and drinking his rum, and singing his old sea-songs at the top of his voice. Sometimes he would call for a glass of rum and water, and sometimes for a glass of rum neat. He was a man of few words, but when he did speak, it was usually to curse or to threaten. He had a large sea-chest in his room, which he kept locked at all times. He was very particular about who went near it, and he would often sit on it, as if guarding it. He was a mystery to us all, and we were all afraid of him. He had been with us for some time now, and we had grown used to his presence, but we never felt comfortable around him. He was a constant source of anxiety, and we were always on edge, waiting for something to happen. He finished his breakfast, wiped his mouth with the back of his hand, and then, without a word, he rose from the table and went back to his room. We breathed a sigh of relief when he was gone, but we knew he would be back. He was the captain, and he was here to stay

events.title: Violent Confrontation and Black Dog's Escape
detailed_summary: Although the narrator made an effort to eavesdrop from the bar, for a considerable duration he could only discern low, indistinct murmuring from the parlour.
Gradually, the voices escalated in volume, and he began to distinguish occasional words, predominantly curses uttered by the captain.
He distinctly heard the captain exclaim at one point, "No, no, no, no; and an end of it!" and later, a defiant statement: "If it comes to swinging, swing all, say I."
The argument culminated in a sudden eruption of loud swearing and other sounds indicative of a physical altercation: furniture was overturned, the clash of steel was heard, followed by a cry of pain.
Immediately thereafter, the narrator witnessed Black Dog fleeing the inn at full speed, with the captain in close pursuit, both men wielding drawn cutlasses.
Black Dog was visibly bleeding from his left shoulder.
As Black Dog reached the inn's doorway, the captain launched a final, formidable sword strike at him.

This powerful blow, which likely would have severely injured Black Dog, was instead intercepted by the large signboard of the Admiral Benbow inn, leaving a tangible mark that is reportedly still visible.
This action marked the conclusion of the physical confrontation.
Once on the road, Black Dog, despite his wound, demonstrated remarkable speed and agility, disappearing over the crest of the hill within half a minute.
The captain, in contrast, remained standing, gazing at the signboard with a perplexed and dazed expression.
He then rubbed his eyes multiple times before finally turning and re-entering the house.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: For a long time, though I certainly did my best to listen, I could hear nothing but a low gattling; but at last the voices began to grow higher, and I could pick up a word or two, mostly oaths, from the captain.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The captain, for his part, stood staring at the signboard like a bewildered man. Then he passed his hand over his eyes several times and at last turned back into the house.

events.text_segment:
For a long time, though I certainly did my best to listen, I could hear nothing but a low gattling; but at last the voices began to grow higher, and I could pick up a word or two, mostly oaths, from the captain.
“No, no, no, no; and an end of it!” he cried once. And again, “If it comes to swinging, swing all, say I.”
Then all of a sudden there was a tremendous explosion of oaths and other noises—the chair and table went over in a lump, a clash of steel followed, and then a cry of pain, and the next instant I saw Black Dog in full flight, and the captain hotly pursuing, both with drawn cutlasses, and the former streaming blood from the left shoulder. Just at the door the captain aimed at the fugitive one last tremendous cut, which would certainly have split him to the chine had it not been intercepted by our big signboard of Admiral Benbow. You may see the notch on the lower side of the frame to this day.
That blow was the last of the battle. Once out upon the road, Black Dog, in spite of his wound, showed a wonderful clean pair of heels and disappeared over the edge of the hill in half a minute. The captain, for his part, stood staring at the signboard like a bewildered man. Then he passed his hand over his eyes several times and at last turned back into the house.

Soon after this, there was a tremendous crash of furniture, and the sound of blows; and then I heard a scream, and the clash of steel, and the cry of a man in pain. That was all I heard, until suddenly the door flew open, and Black Dog bolted out bareheaded into the road, with the captain hot after him, and both of them cutlass in hand. I saw the blood run down Black Dog's shoulder. From the doorway, the captain made a blow in my direction, at the fleeing man, but it only struck the great oak board of the Admiral Benbow inn, and splintered it, and we could all see the mark for ever after. In the meantime, Black Dog had disappeared down the coast road as fast as his legs could carry him. The captain stood for a moment, staring at the signboard, like a man who had been struck; then he rubbed his eyes with his hand, and turned and staggered into the house.

events.title: The Captain's Sudden Collapse
detailed_summary: The captain addressed Jim, requesting rum; as he spoke, he seemed unsteady, staggering slightly and bracing himself with a hand against the wall.
Jim, alarmed, inquired if the captain was injured.
The captain disregarded the question, reiterating his demand for rum and expressing an urgent need to depart from the inn.
As Jim hurried to comply, deeply unsettled by the preceding events, he inadvertently broke a glass and struggled with the rum tap.
While Jim was still fumbling, he heard a significant thud emanating from the parlour.
Rushing into the room, he discovered the captain lying prostrate and unconscious on the floor.
At that very moment, Jim's mother, having been alerted by the sounds of the altercation and shouting, came running downstairs to offer assistance.

Together, Jim and his mother managed to lift the captain's head. He was breathing with great difficulty, making loud, harsh sounds, his eyes were shut, and his facial complexion was disturbingly abnormal.
Jim's mother cried out in distress, lamenting the shameful incident occurring in their home, especially given her husband's illness.
In the immediate aftermath, neither Jim nor his mother knew how to aid the captain, their primary assumption being that he had sustained a fatal injury during the fight with the stranger.
Jim did procure the rum and attempted to administer it to the captain, but his teeth were firmly clenched, and his jaw was rigid.
Their predicament was alleviated by the opportune arrival of Doctor Livesey, who was making a professional visit to Jim's father.

events.text_segment:
“Jim,” says he, “rum”; and as he spoke, he reeled a little, and caught himself with one hand against the wall.
“Are you hurt?” cried I.
“Rum,” he repeated. “I must get away from here. Rum! Rum!”
I ran to fetch it, but I was quite unsteadied by all that had fallen out, and I broke one glass and fouled the tap, and while I was still getting in my own way, I heard a loud fall in the parlour, and running in, beheld the captain lying full length upon the floor. At the same instant my mother, alarmed by the cries and fighting, came running downstairs to help me. Between us we raised his head. He was breathing very loud and hard, but his eyes were closed and his face a horrible colour.
“Dear, deary me,” cried my mother, “what a disgrace upon the house! And your poor father sick!”
In the meantime, we had no idea what to do to help the captain, nor any other thought but that he had got his death-hurt in the scuffle with the stranger. I got the rum, to be sure, and tried to put it down his throat, but his teeth were tightly shut and his jaws as strong as iron. It was a happy relief for us when the door opened and Doctor Livesey came in, on his visit to my father.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
```text
“Jim,” says he, “rum”; and as he spoke, he reeled a little, and caught himself with one hand against the wall.
“Are you hurt?” I said.
“Rum,” he repeated. “I must get away from here. Rum! Rum!”
I ran to fetch it, but I was quite beside myself with terror, and I think I should have got none had I not at that moment heard a loud cry from the parlour, and a heavy fall. I ran in, and there, sure enough, lay the captain by the wall where he had been standing, like a dead man. My mother, who had heard the cry and the fall, was running downstairs, and we both came to the captain’s side. We could get no help from him; he lay on his back with his eyes closed and his face a horrible colour. We tried to raise him, and succeeded in lifting his head. He was still breathing, with a loud, horrible noise, but was quite unconscious.
“Oh, dear, dear!” cried my mother, “what an unfortunate thing! and his poor father ill in bed! and his house, too!”
I ran and got the rum, but his teeth were shut, and his jaw as stiff as iron. It was no use trying to give him any. We could only stand there and look at him, and wonder what was to happen. We were both of us frightened enough, I am sure, the more so as we could not imagine what had happened to him. We thought he had been killed by the blow, and that his death was on our hands.
Just then, old Doctor Livesey happened to call at the inn, on his way to see my father.
```

events.title: Dr. Livesey's Intervention and Diagnosis
characters: Captain (Billy Bones, also referred to as Billy Bones/Mr. Bones)
detailed_summary: Jim and his mother anxiously appealed to Dr. Livesey, asking for guidance and inquiring about the location of the captain's supposed wound.
Dr. Livesey summarily dismissed the notion of a wound, asserting that the captain had suffered a stroke, an event he had previously warned the captain about.
He directed Mrs. Hawkins to return to her husband and, if feasible, to avoid alarming him with details of the incident.
Dr. Livesey expressed his resolve to attempt to save the captain's life, despite deeming it "trebly worthless," and requested Jim to bring him a basin.
Upon Jim's return with the basin, he found that Dr. Livesey had already cut open the captain's sleeve, exposing a brawny and muscular arm adorned with several tattoos.
Among the tattoos were inscriptions such as "Here’s luck," "A fair wind," and "Billy Bones his fancy," all legibly and skillfully inked on the forearm.
Higher up, near the shoulder, was a graphic illustration of a gallows with a figure hanging from it, which the narrator thought was rendered with considerable artistic flair.
Dr. Livesey touched the gallows tattoo with his finger and remarked that it was "Prophetic."
Addressing the still-unconscious captain as "Master Billy Bones," the doctor announced his intention to examine the captain's blood and casually asked Jim if he was squeamish about the sight of it.
Jim affirmed that he was not afraid of blood.
Dr. Livesey then instructed Jim to hold the basin, took out his lancet, and proceeded to open a vein on the captain's arm.
A substantial quantity of blood was drawn before the captain finally regained consciousness and looked about him with a hazy, unfocused gaze.

He initially recognized Dr. Livesey, his expression clearly one of displeasure; his gaze then shifted to Jim, and he appeared somewhat reassured. However, his complexion abruptly changed, and he made an effort to sit up, urgently asking about the whereabouts of Black Dog.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Oh, doctor,” we cried, “what shall we do? Where is he wounded?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: First he recognized the doctor with an unmistakable frown; then his glance fell upon me, and he looked relieved. But suddenly his colour changed, and he tried to raise himself, crying, “Where’s Black Dog?”

events.text_segment:
“Oh, doctor,” we cried, “what shall we do? Where is he wounded?”
“Wounded? A fiddle-stick’s end!” said the doctor. “No more wounded than you or I. The man has had a stroke, as I warned him. Now, Mrs. Hawkins, just you run upstairs to your husband and tell him, if possible, nothing about it. For my part, I must do my best to save this fellow’s trebly worthless life; Jim, you get me a basin.”
When I got back with the basin, the doctor had already ripped up the captain’s sleeve and exposed his great sinewy arm. It was tattooed in several places. “Here’s luck,” “A fair wind,” and “Billy Bones his fancy,” were very neatly and clearly executed on the forearm; and up near the shoulder there was a sketch of a gallows and a man hanging from it—done, as I thought, with great spirit.
“Prophetic,” said the doctor, touching this picture with his finger. “And now, Master Billy Bones, if that be your name, we’ll have a look at the colour of your blood. Jim,” he said, “are you afraid of blood?”
“No, sir,” said I.
“Well, then,” said he, “you hold the basin”; and with that he took his lancet and opened a vein.
A great deal of blood was taken before the captain opened his eyes and looked mistily about him. First he recognized the doctor with an unmistakable frown; then his glance fell upon me, and he looked relieved. But suddenly his colour changed, and he tried to raise himself, crying, “Where’s Black Dog?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Oh, doctor,” we cried, “what shall we do? Where is he wounded?”

“Wounded? A fiddle-stick’s end!” said the doctor, sharply. “Pooh, pooh, pooh! This man has had a stroke, as I told him. Now, Mrs. Hawkins, just you run home to your husband, and tell him, if you please, that he has nothing at all to fear from the captain. Send Jim to me when he can be spared, and I’ll have an eye upon him till morning. It is not very likely that he will be disturbed again. Business will be all over, I fancy.”

Poor Mrs. Hawkins hastened to obey me, while I remained by the captain, not knowing what I should do next. Still he lay, and still the colour kept mounting into his face. I remembered the doctor’s words about the stroke, and was dreadfully frightened. I felt sure he was dying. But presently he rallied a little, the colour lessened, the eyes again swam back into their places, and he gave a sigh. “Oh, Dr. Livesey,” said I, “what is the matter?”

“The matter?” repeated the doctor. “Why, he has had a stroke, as I told him. It is nothing more. I have bled him, and he will be all right in a day or two. Now, Jim,” he continued, “you are a good boy, and I have a great mind to tell you a secret. This man, Billy Bones, as he calls himself, is a pirate. He has been a pirate all his life, and a wicked old brute he is. But he has money, a great deal of money, and I am going to try and save his life for the sake of it. Now, you go home and tell your mother that I shall stay here all night, and that she is not to be uneasy about me. And mind you don’t tell her anything about the stroke. It would only frighten her.”

I went home and delivered the doctor’s message. My mother was very glad to hear that the captain was not wounded, but she was still very uneasy about the doctor staying all night at the inn. However, she made no objection, and I went back to the Admiral Benbow.

Dr. Livesey was sitting by the captain’s bedside, and the captain was lying on his back, with his eyes open, but looking very stupid. The doctor had cut off the sleeve of his coat, and his great brawny arm was exposed. It was tattooed in several places. “Here’s luck,” “A fair wind,” and “Billy Bones his fancy” were very legibly and neatly inked upon the forearm. And higher up, nearer the shoulder, was a sketch of a gallows with a man hanging from it. “Prophetic,” said the doctor, touching it with his finger. “And now, Master Billy Bones,” he added, with a smile, “you will be glad to hear that I have saved your life, though I am sure it is trebly worthless. But I have a fancy for trying to save you, and I have done it. Now, I must bleed you again, and then you will be all right.”

So he bled him again, and the captain seemed to come to himself a little more. He looked about him with a dull, stupid stare, and presently his eyes fell upon me. He seemed to know me, and a sort of smile passed over his face. But then he looked at the doctor, and his face changed. He scowled at him, and muttered something that I could not hear. Then he looked at me again, and his face cleared up. “Jim,” he said, “where is Black Dog?”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Oh, doctor,” we cried, “what shall we do? Where is he wounded?”

“Wounded? A fiddle-stick’s end!” said the doctor, sharply. “Pooh, pooh, pooh! This man has had a stroke, as I told him. Mrs. Hawkins, you will do well to return to your husband. If you please, try not to alarm him with this affair. Mr. Hawkins is not a strong man, and I would not wish him to be worried upon my account. Jim shall stay here to be of assistance. It is no use, I know,” he added, “to save this trebly worthless life; but he is still a fellow-creature, and I’ll do my best. Fetch me a basin, Jim.”

When I returned with the basin, he had already cut the captain’s sleeve up the arm, and that brawny member was exposed, white with the wet, where it had been washed clean. It was tattooed in several places. “Here’s luck,” “A fair wind,” and “Billy Bones his fancy” were very legibly and neatly inked upon the forearm. And higher up, near the shoulder, was a sketch of a gallows with a man hanging from it. “Prophetic,” said the doctor, touching it with his finger. “And now, Master Billy Bones,” he added, with a smile, “you must hold still, for I am about to examine your blood. Jim,” he said, “are you afraid of blood?”

“No, sir,” said I.

“Well, then,” said he, “you hold the basin;” and with that he took out his lancet and opened a vein. A great deal of blood was taken before the captain reeled up into a sitting position and looked about him with a dull, stupid stare. Then he fell back into his former place, only breathing heavily. The doctor, meanwhile, had bound up the arm and put away his instrument. “Now, Jim,” said he, “you see that he is not wounded, but has had a stroke. He will be all right in a day or two. But he must be kept quiet. And now, Mrs. Hawkins, I must be going. I will look in again in the morning.”

“No, no, no,” said the captain, suddenly sitting up again, and looking about him with a wilder and more intelligent air. “Black Dog?” he cried. “Where’s Black Dog?”
