events.text_segment:
Old Anchor Inn, Bristol, March 1, 17—.
Dear Livesey—As I do not know whether you are at the hall or still in London, I send this in double to both places.
The ship is bought and fitted. She lies at anchor, ready for sea. You never imagined a sweeter schooner—a child might sail her—two hundred tons; name, Hispaniola.
I got her through my old friend, Blandly, who has proved himself throughout the most surprising trump. The admirable fellow literally slaved in my interest, and so, I may say, did everyone in Bristol, as soon as they got wind of the port we sailed for—treasure, I mean.
“Redruth,” said I, interrupting the letter, “Dr. Livesey will not like that. The squire has been talking, after all.”
“Well, who’s a better right?” growled the gamekeeper. “A pretty rum go if squire ain’t to talk for Dr. Livesey, I should think.”
At that I gave up all attempts at commentary and read straight on:
Blandly himself found the Hispaniola, and by the most admirable management got her for the merest trifle. There is a class of men in Bristol monstrously prejudiced against Blandly. They go the length of declaring that this honest creature would do anything for money, that the Hispaniola belonged to him, and that he sold it me absurdly high—the most transparent calumnies. None of them dare, however, to deny the merits of the ship.
So far there was not a hitch. The workpeople, to be sure—riggers and what not—were most annoyingly slow; but time cured that. It was the crew that troubled me.
I wished a round score of men—in case of natives, buccaneers, or the odious French—and I had the worry of the deuce itself to find so much as half a dozen, till the most remarkable stroke of fortune brought me the very man that I required.
I was standing on the dock, when, by the merest accident, I fell in talk with him. I found he was an old sailor, kept a public-house, knew all the seafaring men in Bristol, had lost his health ashore, and wanted a good berth as cook to get to sea again. He had hobbled down there that morning, he said, to get a smell of the salt.
I was monstrously touched—so would you have been—and, out of pure pity, I engaged him on the spot to be ship’s cook. Long John Silver, he is called, and has lost a leg; but that I regarded as a recommendation, since he lost it in his country’s service, under the immortal Hawke. He has no pension, Livesey. Imagine the abominable age we live in!
Well, sir, I thought I had only found a cook, but it was a crew I had discovered. Between Silver and myself we got together in a few days a company of the toughest old salts imaginable—not pretty to look at, but fellows, by their faces, of the most indomitable spirit. I declare we could fight a frigate.
Long John even got rid of two out of the six or seven I had already engaged. He showed me in a moment that they were just the sort of fresh-water swabs we had to fear in an adventure of importance.
I am in the most magnificent health and spirits, eating like a bull, sleeping like a tree, yet I shall not enjoy a moment till I hear my old tarpaulins tramping round the capstan.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Old Anchor Inn, Bristol, March 1, 17—.

DEAR LIVESEY,—As I am sure you would wish to know, I write this to inform you that I have found the stoutest ship, and the best man, in Bristol. When I got here, not a ship, I could look at. The docks were full of named things, but they weren't the *Hispaniola*. No, I assure you, I had to search. But I found her, a schooner, 200 tons, clean built, and a master hand at sea. I've bought her and provisioned her, and she lies ready for sea. You never saw a sweeter craft. A man of my acquaintance, a Mr. Blandly, a most excellent fellow, by the by, but I fear not known to you, it was by his help that I got her so cheap and good. The country folks, to be sure, say it is a little dearer, but I am sure they are prejudiced. They are all mad to go after treasure, they are. And when I told them we were going after treasure, they were all as pleased as Punch. They are all as keen as mustard, I assure you. But the shipwrights were slow, and the difficulty was to get a crew. I have been nearly a month at it, and have had to look at a score of fellows before I could light on the right ones. But that is done now, and I have the pick of the port. I have a crew of twenty, all told, and I'll make them work. I have a cook, too, a man that I was very lucky to come across. I was standing on the dock, when I saw a fellow with one leg, and he was talking to a sailor. I went up to him, and I asked him if he knew of a cook. He said he was a cook himself, and that he had been a cook in the navy. He had lost his leg in the service of his country, under the immortal Hawke, and he had no pension. I was so much affected by his story that I hired him on the spot. His name is Long John Silver. He is a man of about fifty, and he has a wooden leg. He is a very good cook, and he is a very good man. He has been a great help to me in getting the crew together. He knows all the sailors in Bristol, and he has got me the best crew that ever sailed. He has also advised me to dismiss two of the men that I had hired, and I have done so. He says they are not fit for the voyage. I am very well myself, and I am looking forward to the voyage with the greatest pleasure. I hope you are well, and that you will come down as soon as you can. I am, dear Livesey, yours, T. TRELAWNEY.

I am very well myself, and I am looking forward to the voyage with the greatest pleasure. I hope you are well, and that you will come down as soon as you can. I am, dear Livesey, yours, T. TRELAWNEY.

“That was the letter with which Dr. Livesey returned to the Admiral Benbow, and which he read aloud to me and to Tom Redruth. Tom was a man of few words, and he said nothing. But I, who was young and had been brought up in a quiet country place, was much excited by the letter. I had never been to sea, and I had never seen a ship. I had never seen a sailor, except the captain, and I had never seen a man with a wooden leg. I was so excited that I could not sit still. I got up and walked about the room. I was so excited that I could not speak. I was so excited that I could not think. I was so excited that I could not do anything. I was so excited that I could not be quiet. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Old Anchor Inn, Bristol, March 1, 17—. It seems but yesterday that I sat down to write this account of my adventures, and yet the time has flown by like a dream. I had left the Admiral Benbow Inn behind, the scene of so many strange and terrible events, and found myself here in Bristol, a bustling, noisy city, full of ships and sailors and the smell of the sea. Squire Trelawney had brought me with him, promising me a berth as cabin-boy on the ship he was fitting out to search for Captain Flint’s treasure. Dr. Livesey was also here, though he had business of his own to attend to before the voyage. The Squire was in his element, full of energy and enthusiasm, though perhaps a little too free with his tongue and his money. He had bought a fine schooner, the Hispaniola, and was busy hiring a crew. This was a task that proved more difficult and vexing than he had anticipated. Good sailors were scarce, and those who presented themselves often seemed a rough and undesirable lot. The Squire, in his eagerness, was inclined to take anyone who looked the part, much to the Doctor’s quiet disapproval. It was in this very inn, the Old Anchor, that a remarkable piece of good fortune, or so it seemed at the time, befell us. The Squire was complaining loudly about the difficulty of finding a trustworthy crew when the landlord mentioned a man who might be of service. This man, he said, was a former sea-cook who kept a public-house down by the docks, and who knew more old salts than anyone in Bristol. His name was Long John Silver. The Squire was instantly taken with the idea and dispatched me to find this Silver. I remember the walk down to the docks, the narrow, winding streets, the tall houses leaning over, and the constant clamour of the port. I found the Spy-glass, Silver’s inn, and there, leaning in the doorway, was the man himself. He was a tall, strong fellow, with a pleasant, open face, and what struck me most was that he had lost his left leg and went about on a crutch. He was talking to two or three rough-looking seamen. When I delivered the Squire’s message, Silver’s face lit up. He welcomed me in, offered me a drink (which I politely refused), and listened attentively to my errand. He seemed genuinely pleased to hear of the Squire’s venture and readily agreed to come and see him. He told me he had been a sea-cook for twenty years and had sailed with some of the most famous captains. He spoke with such charm and good humour that I was immediately taken with him. He promised to help the Squire find the best crew in Bristol, men he could trust. And indeed, within a few days, Silver had brought forward a dozen or so men, all stout, weather-beaten fellows, who seemed just the sort we needed. The Squire was delighted and hired them on the spot, making Silver himself the ship’s cook. Dr. Livesey, though he said little, watched the proceedings with a thoughtful, perhaps even a little wary, expression. The Hispaniola was soon ready, provisioned and manned. She was a beautiful vessel, trim and fast-looking. The excitement in Bristol was palpable; everyone seemed to know about the treasure hunt. I spent my days running errands for the Squire and exploring the docks, my head full of dreams of adventure and riches. The day of departure drew near. My chest was packed, my sea-clothes ready. I said goodbye to the kind people at the Old Anchor Inn, my temporary home. The air was thick with anticipation. We were about to set sail for Treasure Island.

events.title: Further Instructions, Postscript Details, and Jim's Exuberance
detailed_summary: The Squire passionately urged Dr. Livesey to hasten to Bristol, exclaiming his current obsession was with the allure of the sea rather than the treasure itself.
He directed that young Hawkins should visit his mother, escorted by Redruth, before both of them proceeded swiftly to Bristol.
A postscript added that Blandly was arranged to send a support vessel if their party didn't return by August's end, and had also found an excellent, though rather formal, sailing master.
Long John Silver had also recruited a very capable mate named Arrow, and the ship even had a boatswain who used a pipe, indicating things would be run in a disciplined, naval style.

Another forgotten detail shared was that Silver was a man of some means, with a consistently solvent bank account. He was leaving his wife, a woman of color, to manage his inn, leading the Squire to jest that perhaps his wife, as much as his health, was his reason for returning to sea.
A final, brief postscript permitted Hawkins to spend one night with his mother.
This letter threw Jim into a state of extreme excitement and happiness.
He felt a strong disdain for old Tom Redruth, who could only complain and express regret about the situation.
While other under-gamekeepers would have eagerly taken Redruth's place, the Squire's preferences were treated as absolute commands, and only Redruth possessed the audacity to grumble.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Seaward, ho! Hang the treasure! It’s the glory of the sea that has turned my head. So now, Livesey, come post; do not lose an hour, if you respect me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Nobody but old Redruth would have dared so much as even to grumble.

events.text_segment:
Seaward, ho! Hang the treasure! It’s the glory of the sea that has turned my head. So now, Livesey, come post; do not lose an hour, if you respect me.
Let young Hawkins go at once to see his mother, with Redruth for a guard; and then both come full speed to Bristol. John Trelawney
Postscript.—I did not tell you that Blandly, who, by the way, is to send a consort after us if we don’t turn up by the end of August, had found an admirable fellow for sailing master—a stiff man, which I regret, but in all other respects a treasure. Long John Silver unearthed a very competent man for a mate, a man named Arrow. I have a boatswain who pipes, Livesey; so things shall go man-o’-war fashion on board the good ship Hispaniola.
I forgot to tell you that Silver is a man of substance; I know of my own knowledge that he has a banker’s account, which has never been overdrawn. He leaves his wife to manage the inn; and as she is a woman of colour, a pair of old bachelors like you and I may be excused for guessing that it is the wife, quite as much as the health, that sends him back to roving.
P.P.S.—Hawkins may stay one night with his mother.
You can fancy the excitement into which that letter put me. I was half beside myself with glee; and if ever I despised a man, it was old Tom Redruth, who could do nothing but grumble and lament. Any of the under-gamekeepers would gladly have changed places with him; but such was not the squire’s pleasure, and the squire’s pleasure was like law among them all. Nobody but old Redruth would have dared so much as even to grumble.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Seaward, ho! Hang the treasure! It’s the glory of the sea that has turned my head. So now, Livesey, come post; do not lose an hour, if you respect me. Choose your own doctor for the squire, and come to Bristol. Be sure to come, and tell Hawkins to come at once. I’ve written to him at the Admiral Benbow, to tell him to come to Bristol. We’ll have the best ship, and the best men, and the best of everything. I’ve found a ship, a schooner, a beauty. She’s called the HISPANIOLA. I’ve found a crew too, and a captain. The captain’s a man named Smollett. He’s a bit stiff, but he’s a good seaman. I’ve got a mate too, a man named Arrow. He’s a good man, though he drinks a bit. And I’ve got a boatswain, a man named Silver. He’s a one-legged man, but he’s a good man. He’s got a wife, a black woman, and she keeps an inn. He’s a man of means, Silver is. He’s got money in the bank. He’s leaving his wife to manage the inn while he’s away. Perhaps his wife is as much his reason for returning to sea as his health, eh, Livesey? I’ve also arranged with Blandly to send a support vessel if we don’t return by the end of August. He’s also found an excellent, though rather formal, sailing master. Tell Hawkins to come to Bristol at once. He can spend one night with his mother on the way. Tell him to bring Redruth with him. Redruth can look after him. I’ve told Redruth to go with him. He’s a good man, Redruth, though he grumbles a bit. He’s the only one of my under-gamekeepers who would have the audacity to grumble. All the others would have been eager to take his place. But my preferences are treated as absolute commands. So, come at once, Livesey. Don’t lose an hour. Yours, Trelawney. P.S. Hawkins can spend one night with his mother. P.P.S. Blandly will send a support vessel if we don’t return by the end of August. He’s also found an excellent, though rather formal, sailing master. P.P.P.S. Silver is a man of some means, with a consistently solvent bank account. He is leaving his wife, a woman of colour, to manage his inn, leading me to jest that perhaps his wife, as much as his health, is his reason for returning to sea. P.P.P.P.S. Silver has also recruited a very capable mate named Arrow, and the ship even has a boatswain who uses a pipe, indicating things will be run in a disciplined, naval style. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Seaward, ho! Hang the treasure! It’s the glory of the sea that has turned my head. So now, Livesey, come post; do not lose an hour, if you respect me. I am here, back in this quiet village, and the land feels like a cage after the boundless horizon. The smell of the salt, the feel of the deck beneath my feet, the roar of the wind in the rigging – these are the true riches, the ones that fill the soul, not a chest of doubloons buried in the sand. That island, with its dark secrets and bloody history, is a nightmare I wish to forget, save for the lessons learned and the friends made. But the sea itself, the vast, indifferent, magnificent sea, calls to me like a siren. I dream of voyages to distant lands, of charting unknown waters, of facing storms and calm alike with a stout heart and a good ship. The treasure was a means to an end, a catalyst for adventure, but the adventure itself, the life at sea, is the end I now seek. I cannot settle here, not yet. My blood is up, my spirit restless. The smell of tar and oakum is sweeter than any perfume. The creak of timbers is finer music than any symphony. Come, Livesey, and let us talk of ships and charts and the world beyond our shores. I have seen enough of land-locked life to know it is not for me, not now. The sea is my mistress, and I must follow her call. There are still islands to discover, still waves to ride, still horizons to chase. My sea-legs are strong, my eyes are keen, and my heart is ready for the next adventure. Do not delay; the tide waits for no man, and neither does my impatience to be back upon the waves.

events.title: A Bittersweet Farewell to Home and Mother
detailed_summary: The following day, Jim and Redruth journeyed on foot to the Admiral Benbow.
Jim was relieved to find his mother in good health and cheerful. The disruptive captain who had caused so much trouble was no longer a concern.
The Squire had funded various improvements: the inn was repaired, public areas and the sign repainted, and new furniture added, notably a comfortable armchair for Jim's mother in the bar.
The Squire had also arranged for an apprentice boy to assist her during Jim's absence.
It was the sight of this new boy that made Jim, for the first time, truly comprehend the reality of his departure and the home he was leaving behind.
Until that moment, his thoughts had been consumed by the adventures ahead, but seeing this unfamiliar boy who would take his place beside his mother brought on his first bout of tears.
Jim confesses he treated the new apprentice harshly, frequently correcting and belittling him, partly due to his own emotional state and the boy's inexperience.
After spending the night, Jim and Redruth set off again the next day following their midday meal.
Jim bid farewell to his mother, the familiar cove of his birth, and the Admiral Benbow, which felt slightly less dear to him after its repainting.
A final thought drifted to the deceased captain, whom he often pictured walking the beach with his distinctive hat, facial scar, and brass telescope.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next morning he and I set out on foot for the Admiral Benbow, and there I found my mother in good health and spirits.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: One of my last thoughts was of the captain, who had so often strode along the beach with his cocked hat, his sabre-cut cheek, and his old brass telescope.

events.text_segment:
The next morning he and I set out on foot for the Admiral Benbow, and there I found my mother in good health and spirits. The captain, who had so long been a cause of so much discomfort, was gone where the wicked cease from troubling. The squire had had everything repaired, and the public rooms and the sign repainted, and had added some furniture—above all a beautiful armchair for mother in the bar. He had found her a boy as an apprentice also so that she should not want help while I was gone.
It was on seeing that boy that I understood, for the first time, my situation. I had thought up to that moment of the adventures before me, not at all of the home that I was leaving; and now, at sight of this clumsy stranger, who was to stay here in my place beside my mother, I had my first attack of tears. I am afraid I led that boy a dog’s life, for as he was new to the work, I had a hundred opportunities of setting him right and putting him down, and I was not slow to profit by them.
The night passed, and the next day, after dinner, Redruth and I were afoot again and on the road. I said good-bye to Mother and the cove where I had lived since I was born, and the dear old Admiral Benbow—since he was repainted, no longer quite so dear. One of my last thoughts was of the captain, who had so often strode along the beach with his cocked hat, his sabre-cut cheek, and his old brass telescope.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The next morning he and I set out on foot for the Admiral Benbow, and there I found my mother in good health and spirits. The captain, who had so long been a cause of care, was gone. The squire had been most munificent. He had repaired the inn, and refitted it, and re-painted the sign, and added a neat little summer-house at the end of the garden, and bought new furniture for the bar. He had also set up a handsome armchair in the bar for my mother, and supplied her with a hired boy to give her assistance. He was a pale, tallowy creature, you may be sure, not like a man; but he was serviceable enough after a fashion, and was of a quiet spirit. Of course I was much too proud to let him understand I was jealous, but I was so, right at the bottom of my heart; and made it a point to treat him generously whenever I met him. The sight of this boy was the first thing that gave me a real national feeling of the object of my journey. Until that moment I had experienced nothing but pleasure and a cold sense of curiosity; but now I began to think of the great distance that was about to separate us, and the chances that might never bring me back. I suppose I was little more than a child, and I am sure it was the first time that I considered aught but pleasure; and at that moment I felt that I not only enjoyed pleasure, but was capable of sorrow. I cried, at least, and I am not ashamed to own it. I was very kind to the boy that day, and gave him a piece of money; but next morning, when I came to say good-bye to my mother, I found it was hard to part with her, and harder still to part with the old Admiral Benbow, which I had known all my life, and which was now all bright and clean and new-painted, and smelled of tar and oakum, and was altogether different from the old inn. I was not so much grieved at the thought of leaving my mother, as I was at the thought of leaving the old inn. I had never been away from it before, and I felt as if I was leaving a part of myself behind. I was a little comforted by the thought that I should soon be back again, and that I should have a great deal to tell them all. I said good-bye to my mother, and to the boy, and to the old inn, and set off with Redruth for Bristol. I had a last look at the old place, and at the cove, and at the sea, and then I turned my back upon them all, and set my face towards the unknown. I was full of hope and expectation, and I thought of the great things that I should do, and the great riches that I should find. I thought of the captain, too, and of his chart, and of the treasure that was hidden somewhere in the far-off island. I pictured him to myself, walking the beach with his brass telescope under his arm, and his old cocked hat on his head, and his great scar across his cheek. I wondered if he had ever found the treasure, and if he had, what he had done with it. I wondered if I should ever find it, and if I did, what I should do with it. I was so full of these thoughts that I did not speak a word to Redruth all the way to Bristol. He was a silent man, and did not seem to expect me to speak, so we walked on in silence, each with his own thoughts. We reached Bristol in the evening, and put up at a comfortable inn near the harbour. Redruth ordered supper, and while it was being prepared, I went out to look at the ships. There were a great many of them, of all sizes and shapes, and I had never seen so many together before. I walked along the quays, and looked at them all, and wondered where they came from, and where they were going to. I saw ships from all parts of the world, and I thought of the strange lands that they had visited, and the strange people that they had seen. I was so much interested in the ships that I forgot all about my supper, and when I went back to the inn, I found that Redruth had finished his, and was waiting for me. I ate my supper, and then we

events.title: The Journey to Bristol by Mail Coach
detailed_summary: Shortly after departing, Jim's childhood home vanished from his view as they rounded a bend.
Around dusk, they were picked up by the mail coach at an inn called the Royal George, located on the heath.
Jim found himself positioned between Redruth and a portly elderly gentleman during the coach ride.
Despite the swift movement of the coach and the chill of the night air, Jim quickly fell asleep and remained so for the majority of the journey, through various stages and terrains.
He was finally roused by a poke in his side, opening his eyes to discover they were stationary in front of a large building on a city street, and that day had broken some time ago.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Next moment we had turned the corner and my home was out of sight.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Where are we?” I asked.

events.text_segment:
Next moment we had turned the corner and my home was out of sight.
The mail picked us up about dusk at the Royal George on the heath. I was wedged in between Redruth and a stout old gentleman, and in spite of the swift motion and the cold night air, I must have dozed a great deal from the very first, and then slept like a log up hill and down dale through stage after stage, for when I was awakened at last it was by a punch in the ribs, and I opened my eyes to find that we were standing still before a large building in a city street and that the day had already broken a long time.
“Where are we?” I asked.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Next moment we had turned the corner and my home was out of sight. The mail picked us up about dusk at the Royal George on the heath. I was stiff and cold and sleepy, and was glad to get inside. The coach was full, and I was the youngest and smallest of the party. I was crowded in between Redruth and a stout old gentleman, and I was pretty well smothered in the road-coat that he wore and needed no other blanket. I knew nothing of the counties we passed through, and little of the great towns we were driven by. Something I remember of the pleasure of grubbing among the cushions for the foot-warmer, and of clambering among the legs and feet of the passengers. Something else I remember of hot punch to drink and sand to eat in the middle of the night. But for the most part I was asleep. In the morning, when I was shaken by the arm, and opened my eyes, I found myself in a loud, bustling city, and before a large hotel.

events.title: Arrival in Bristol and Awe at the Docks
detailed_summary: Tom Redruth identified their location as Bristol and told Jim to get out of the coach.
Mr. Trelawney had established his lodgings at an inn situated far down by the docks to personally oversee the preparations on the schooner.
Their route to this inn, much to Jim's pleasure, led them along the quays and past a vast array of ships of every conceivable size, type, and nationality.
He observed sailors singing as they worked on one vessel, and on another, men were high above him in the rigging, appearing to hang from threads no thicker than a spider's web.
Though he had spent his entire life by the coast, he felt as if he had never truly been near the sea until that moment.
The distinct smells of tar and salt were novel experiences for him.

He marveled at magnificent ship figureheads that had journeyed across vast oceans and saw numerous old sailors, with their characteristic earrings, curled whiskers, tarry pigtails, and distinctive, somewhat awkward, seafaring gait.
Jim felt that seeing such men was more thrilling than encountering kings or archbishops.

The overwhelming realization dawned on him: he was actually going to sea, on a schooner, complete with a boatswain using a pipe and singing, pig-tailed sailors, all bound for an uncharted island in pursuit of buried treasure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Bristol,” said Tom. “Get down.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And I was going to sea myself, to sea in a schooner, with a piping boatswain and pig-tailed singing seamen, to sea, bound for an unknown island, and to seek for buried treasure!

events.text_segment:
“Bristol,” said Tom. “Get down.”
Mr. Trelawney had taken up his residence at an inn far down the docks to superintend the work upon the schooner. Thither we had now to walk, and our way, to my great delight, lay along the quays and beside the great multitude of ships of all sizes and rigs and nations. In one, sailors were singing at their work, in another there were men aloft, high over my head, hanging to threads that seemed no thicker than a spider’s. Though I had lived by the shore all my life, I seemed never to have been near the sea till then. The smell of tar and salt was something new. I saw the most wonderful figureheads, that had all been far over the ocean. I saw, besides, many old sailors, with rings in their ears, and whiskers curled in ringlets, and tarry pigtails, and their swaggering, clumsy sea-walk; and if I had seen as many kings or archbishops I could not have been more delighted.
And I was going to sea myself, to sea in a schooner, with a piping boatswain and pig-tailed singing seamen, to sea, bound for an unknown island, and to seek for buried treasure!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Bristol,” said Tom. “Get down.”

Jim got down on the name, and found himself in a large, bustling city, which he knew for Bristol. Mr. Trelawney had taken lodgings at an inn far down by the docks, in order that he might be on the spot the more readily, to superintend the work upon the schooner. Thither we limped, Tom Redruth, the squire, and I. Indeed, so much had Mr. Trelawney the spirit of an admiral, that he wished to have me close at hand as his first officer, and Tom as his second. But my mother, God bless her, was wiser than the squire; she said quiet-like, and strong, that if I was not rich enough to hire a second man or a third man, I was rich enough to go to sea with one. So Tom and I were to go alone; and the squire, at this very moment, as I afterwards learned, was negotiating for a second mate, a boatswain, and a cook, besides five hands before the mast.

Tom Redruth and I, therefore, were sent off at once with a pleasant note to the innkeeper, the "Spy-glass," by the shore, to wait for the squire; and on the fourth day after our arrival we saw the "Hispaniola" brought round from the dock, and moored, a little farther out, with two anchors, in the roads. She was a fine vessel, trim and neat, and as she lay there, with her head to the westward, the sun upon her sails, it was a lovely sight to me. The squire came down that day to see her, and was greatly pleased. He ordered the boat to be manned, and went aboard himself, and was shown round by the captain. I was not suffered to go aboard, being told that I should be wanted, and bade to pace the quay. Accordingly, I paced the quay, and looked at the ships, and the sailors, and the sea, and the sky, and everything about me, and was as happy as I could be. I had never been in a large city before, and I was amazed at the number of people, and the noise, and the bustle, and the dirt, and the smells. But I liked the ships best of all. They were of all sizes and shapes, and from all countries. Some were loading, and some were unloading, and some were lying idle. Some had their sails set, and some had them furled. Some were painted black, and some were painted white, and some were painted green. Some had figure-heads, and some had none. Some were old, and some were new. Some were clean, and some were dirty. Some were large, and some were small. Some were high out of the water, and some were low. Some were sharp, and some were blunt. Some were long, and some were short. Some were broad, and some were narrow. Some were deep, and some were shallow. Some were fast, and some were slow. Some were good, and some were bad. Some were going, and some were coming. Some were here, and some were there. Some were everywhere. I looked at them all, and I liked them all. I liked the sailors too. They were of all sorts and sizes, and from all countries. Some were old, and some were young. Some were tall, and some were short. Some were fat, and some were thin. Some were clean, and some were dirty. Some were dressed in blue, and some were dressed in red, and some were dressed in green. Some had beards, and some had none. Some had whiskers, and some had none. Some had moustaches, and some had none. Some had earrings, and some had none

events.title: Reunion with the Squire and News of Imminent Departure
detailed_summary: Immersed in this wonderful reverie, Jim and Redruth suddenly found themselves before a large inn, where they encountered Squire Trelawney emerging from the doorway.
The Squire was impressively attired as a sea-officer in sturdy blue fabric, sporting a smile and playfully mimicking a sailor's distinctive walk.
He greeted them enthusiastically, announcing that Dr. Livesey had also arrived from London the previous night, thus completing their party.
When Jim eagerly inquired about their departure date, the Squire joyfully proclaimed that they would set sail the very next day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: While I was still in this delightful dream, we came suddenly in front of a large inn and met Squire Trelawney, all dressed out like a sea-officer, in stout blue cloth, coming out of the door with a smile on his face and a capital imitation of a sailor’s walk.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Sail!” says he. “We sail tomorrow!”

events.text_segment:
While I was still in this delightful dream, we came suddenly in front of a large inn and met Squire Trelawney, all dressed out like a sea-officer, in stout blue cloth, coming out of the door with a smile on his face and a capital imitation of a sailor’s walk.
“Here you are,” he cried, “and the doctor came last night from London. Bravo! The ship’s company complete!”
“Oh, sir,” cried I, “when do we sail?”
“Sail!” says he. “We sail tomorrow!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: While I was still in this delightful dream, we came suddenly in front of a large inn and met Squire Trelawney, all dressed out like a sea-officer, in stout blue cloth, coming out of the door with a smile on his face and a capital imitation of a sailor’s walk. “Come aboard, sir!” he cried. “Come aboard, and welcome to Bristol! I’m as pleased as Punch to see you; and Dr. Livesey after you! We will make the trip together!” “Dr. Livesey!” I cried. “Yes, he came last night from London. Capital! The ship is bought and fitted. All told, from the biggest gun to the least tin pannikin, everything is aboard. Redruth, you will want to go forward to the inn, and find rooms for Mr. Hawkins and yourself. Mr. Hawkins will come along with me, and hear the news. Come along, Hawkins!” I followed him readily. He told me that the ship was called the Hispaniola, that she was a schooner, of two hundred tons, that she had been found and fitted by himself, and that she was now lying at anchor, ready for sea. I asked him when we should sail. “Sail!” he repeated. “We sail tomorrow!”

He was full of spirits and told me the ship was bought, the Hispaniola, a capital schooner, and he had found a crew, though the captain was a bit difficult. We were ready to sail very soon indeed.

chapters.chapter_title: VIII-At the Sign of the Spy-glass

events.title: Jim's Journey to the Spy-glass Tavern and Initial Observations
detailed_summary: Jim Hawkins receives a note from Squire Trelawney to deliver to John Silver at the Spy-glass tavern.
Filled with anticipation to see more of the maritime environment, Jim navigates the crowded and bustling docks.
He successfully locates the Spy-glass tavern.
The tavern presents a welcoming appearance, with fresh paint, neat red window curtains, and a cleanly sanded floor.
Its interior, though permeated by tobacco smoke, is made fairly visible by open doors on two sides of the large, low room.
The clientele consists mainly of seafaring men whose loud conversations make Jim pause at the doorway, feeling somewhat intimidated to enter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I had done breakfasting the squire gave me a note addressed to John Silver, at the sign of the Spy-glass, and told me I should easily find the place by following the line of the docks and keeping a bright lookout for a little tavern with a large brass telescope for sign.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The customers were mostly seafaring men, and they talked so loudly that I hung at the door, almost afraid to enter.

events.text_segment:
When I had done breakfasting the squire gave me a note addressed to John Silver, at the sign of the Spy-glass, and told me I should easily find the place by following the line of the docks and keeping a bright lookout for a little tavern with a large brass telescope for sign. I set off, overjoyed at this opportunity to see some more of the ships and seamen, and picked my way among a great crowd of people and carts and bales, for the dock was now at its busiest, until I found the tavern in question.
It was a bright enough little place of entertainment. The sign was newly painted; the windows had neat red curtains; the floor was cleanly sanded. There was a street on each side and an open door on both, which made the large, low room pretty clear to see in, in spite of clouds of tobacco smoke.
The customers were mostly seafaring men, and they talked so loudly that I hung at the door, almost afraid to enter.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: When I had done breakfasting the squire gave me a note addressed to John Silver, at the sign of the Spy-glass, and told me I should easily find the place by following the line of the docks and keeping a bright lookout for a little tavern with a large brass telescope for sign. I set off, therefore, full of hope and expectation, and many pleasant visions of the sea took shape in my mind. I was pleased, too, to be thus sent for on a private errand for the squire, and to be at last engaged in the affairs of men. I found my way easily to the docks, and was a good deal pleased both by the sight of the ships and the busy hum of so many working people. The smell of tar and salt was pleasant to my nostrils. I saw some seamen going about with their cutlasses and pistols in their belts. and I envied them their liberty and their fine clothes. When I got to the docks, I found the Spy-glass close at hand. It was a clean, pleasant-looking house, outside, in a busy street, with a great sign swinging above the door: THE SPY-GLASS, by J. Silver. I went in, and found myself in a large, low room, full of seafaring men, and all talking loudly. The floor was sanded, the walls were clean, and the windows were neat with red curtains. There was a bar at one end, and a great fire at the other. The room was full of smoke, but it was not unpleasant. I stood for a moment at the door, for I was a little shy of going in among so many strangers.

events.title: First Encounter with Long John Silver
detailed_summary: As Jim hesitates, a man emerges from a side room, and Jim is immediately certain this must be Long John Silver.
Long John is described as having his left leg amputated high up by the hip, and he uses a crutch under his left shoulder with impressive dexterity, moving with a bird-like agility.
He is a tall, strong man with a large, plain, and pale face, which nonetheless conveys intelligence and a smile.
He appears to be in high spirits, whistling as he moves among the tables, offering cheerful words or a friendly slap on the shoulder to his favored patrons.
Jim reflects on his earlier fear that Long John might be the one-legged pirate he had been wary of at the Admiral Benbow.
However, the sight of this clean, pleasant-tempered landlord dispels Jim's apprehension, as he seems markedly different from the buccaneers (Captain, Black Dog, Pew) Jim had previously encountered.
Mustering his courage, Jim crosses the threshold and walks directly to Long John, who is propped on his crutch conversing with a customer.
Jim addresses him as Mr. Silver and hands over the note.
Long John confirms his identity and, upon seeing the squire's letter, shows a slight, almost startled reaction.
He then loudly and warmly acknowledges Jim as the new cabin boy, expressing pleasure at meeting him and firmly grasping Jim's hand.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As I was waiting, a man came out of a side room, and at a glance I was sure he must be Long John.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And he took my hand in his large firm grasp.

events.text_segment:
As I was waiting, a man came out of a side room, and at a glance I was sure he must be Long John. His left leg was cut off close by the hip, and under the left shoulder he carried a crutch, which he managed with wonderful dexterity, hopping about upon it like a bird. He was very tall and strong, with a face as big as a ham—plain and pale, but intelligent and smiling. Indeed, he seemed in the most cheerful spirits, whistling as he moved about among the tables, with a merry word or a slap on the shoulder for the more favoured of his guests.
Now, to tell you the truth, from the very first mention of Long John in Squire Trelawney’s letter I had taken a fear in my mind that he might prove to be the very one-legged sailor whom I had watched for so long at the old Benbow. But one look at the man before me was enough. I had seen the captain, and Black Dog, and the blind man, Pew, and I thought I knew what a buccaneer was like—a very different creature, according to me, from this clean and pleasant-tempered landlord.
I plucked up courage at once, crossed the threshold, and walked right up to the man where he stood, propped on his crutch, talking to a customer.
“Mr. Silver, sir?” I asked, holding out the note.
“Yes, my lad,” said he; “such is my name, to be sure. And who may you be?” And then as he saw the squire’s letter, he seemed to me to give something almost like a start.
“Oh!” said he, quite loud, and offering his hand. “I see. You are our new cabin-boy; pleased I am to see you.”
And he took my hand in his large firm grasp.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: As I was waiting, a man came out of a side room, and at a glance I was sure he must be Long John. His left leg was cut off close by the hip, and under the left shoulder he carried a crutch, which he managed with wonderful dexterity, hopping about upon it like a bird. He was very tall and strong, with a great, pale, clean-shaven face and a pleasant, smiling expression. Next moment he whistled the tune and disappeared into the bar. All the time he was on the move he was whistling, and all the time he was whistling he was making a tune with his voice to words that he made up as he went along. He was a man of about fifty, and his hair was tied in a queue behind. He was dressed in a clean, blue suit, and his face was as open as day. I never saw a more pleasant, smiling face; and yet I was sure he was the man I had been warned against. I had seen the Captain, Black Dog, and Pew, and I knew the sort of men that they were. Long John Silver was a different sort of man altogether. He was clean and pleasant-tempered, and he was a landlord. I had been told that he was a sailor, and I had expected to see a man with a tarry pigtail, and a face that was all over wrinkles. I had not expected to see a man with a clean face, and a pleasant smile, and a blue suit. I was so surprised that I stood stock-still for a moment. Then I pulled myself together and walked right up to him. He was standing by the bar, talking to a customer. I touched him on the arm. 'Mr. Silver, sir?' I said. He turned round and looked at me. 'Yes, my lad,' he said. 'What is it?' I held out the letter. He took it and looked at the address. 'Ah,' he said, 'from the squire. And who may you be?' 'I am Jim Hawkins,' I said. 'I am the new cabin boy.' 'Ah,' he said, 'Jim Hawkins. So you are the new cabin boy. Well, I am very pleased to make your acquaintance, Jim. And so you are going to sea with us. That is fine. And you have brought the letter from the squire. That is fine too.' He opened the letter and read it. As he read it, his face changed. He looked surprised, and then he looked pleased. 'Well, Jim,' he said, 'this is a surprise. The squire tells me that you are a good lad, and that you are to be cabin boy. Well, I am very pleased to hear it. And so you are going to sea with us. That is fine.' He folded up the letter and put it in his pocket

events.title: Black Dog's Unexpected Appearance and Flight
detailed_summary: At that moment, a customer from the far side of the room abruptly gets up and makes a dash for the door, quickly disappearing into the street.
The man's hurried departure catches Jim's attention, and he instantly recognizes him as the pale-faced man missing two fingers, Black Dog, who had previously visited the Admiral Benbow.
Jim cries out, identifying the man as Black Dog and urging others to stop him.
Silver, initially feigning unconcern for the man's identity beyond an unpaid bill, shouts for someone named Harry to pursue him.
Another patron nearest the door also leaps up to join the chase.
Silver exclaims that even an admiral would have to pay his score, then, releasing Jim's hand, asks Jim to clarify who he said the man was.
Jim reiterates that it was Black Dog and asks if Mr. Trelawney hadn't informed Silver about the buccaneers, confirming Black Dog was one of them.

Silver reacts with feigned astonishment and outrage that such a person was in his establishment, ordering another man, Ben, to help Harry in the pursuit, and then calls over Morgan, who was seen drinking with Black Dog.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Just then one of the customers at the far side rose suddenly and made for the door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Was that you drinking with him, Morgan? Step up here.”

events.text_segment:
Just then one of the customers at the far side rose suddenly and made for the door. It was close by him, and he was out in the street in a moment. But his hurry had attracted my notice, and I recognized him at glance. It was the tallow-faced man, wanting two fingers, who had come first to the Admiral Benbow.
“Oh,” I cried, “stop him! It’s Black Dog!”
“I don’t care two coppers who he is,” cried Silver. “But he hasn’t paid his score. Harry, run and catch him.”
One of the others who was nearest the door leaped up and started in pursuit.
“If he were Admiral Hawke he shall pay his score,” cried Silver; and then, relinquishing my hand, “Who did you say he was?” he asked. “Black what?”
“Dog, sir,” said I. “Has Mr. Trelawney not told you of the buccaneers? He was one of them.”
“So?” cried Silver. “In my house! Ben, run and help Harry. One of those swabs, was he? Was that you drinking with him, Morgan? Step up here.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Just then one of the customers at the far side rose suddenly and made for the door. I at once recognized him for the two-fingered cripple who had visited my father's inn, and knew that I must look for trouble. The man was gone before I could do anything but half cry out. Silver sprang, I thought, upon his feet; yet he was less apparently moved than anybody else in the house. For the others, in a moment, were all out in the street. He only cried, "Catch him, Harry, catch him!" and then, poising his crutch, waited with an unmoved countenance till the hubbub should die down. "Meantime," said he, "fetch me my score, and hold on to the tally. Let's see what this comes to." He paid the bill, and asking for the tally, he plunged his hand into his fob and produced a few coppers, which he threw upon the table. "There," said he, "bring me back my coppers, for I 'm not going to beg; and now, Jim, cut along to the back door and look after that doctor if you see that doctor, you understand. And be smart, for I've a word to say to him myself." I obeyed, and was back again in a moment. The bar-room was empty of all but Silver, Morgan, and me. "Is Dr. Livesey gone?" he asked. "I told you to look after him." "I did, sir," said I. "He's gone. There's not a soul in the street." "Well," said Silver, "I'll be hanged if that was n't Black Dog, now!" And he looked at me as if he meant me to understand that he was surprised. "Black Dog?" said I, a little startled myself. "Why, you told Mr. Trelawney you'd never seen him!" "Well, and so I haven't," said Silver. "He's a mate of mine, right enough. But I haven't seen him for years. And I never knew him by sight, you may depend upon it. He was a mate of the captain's, you see, and I was only a boy in the cook-house. Well," he added, starting up, "if that was Black Dog, I'll lay my hand on my heart and swear he was a buccaneer!" And he looked at me again, with a queer smile, as if he were trying to read my thoughts. "And if he was a buccaneer," he went on, "I'll be hanged if he was n't after the treasure!" And he sat down again, and looked at me with a still queerer smile. "Now, Jim," said he, "you're a smart lad, and I'll tell you what it is. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Just then one of the customers at the far side rose suddenly and made for the door. He was a man of a tallowy face, with a missing finger on his left hand. He wore a cutlass scar across one cheek, giving him a sinister look. He paused just inside the threshold, peering around the room with a searching gaze. His eyes fell upon my father and then swept past, finally fixing on the captain, old Billy Bones, who sat hunched by the fire, nursing his rum. A strange, expectant silence fell over the room. The captain's face, usually ruddy and fierce, turned a ghastly white. He half rose from his seat, his hand instinctively going to the pistol tucked in his belt. The newcomer, whom I later knew as Black Dog, advanced slowly, his eyes never leaving the captain's face. "Bill," he said, in a voice that was low but carried clearly across the room, "you know me." The captain's lips moved, but no sound came out. The air crackled with tension.

events.title: Silver's Cunning Interrogation and Deception of Jim
detailed_summary: Morgan, an elderly, grey-haired sailor with a weather-beaten face, approaches Silver rather sheepishly, chewing on his tobacco.
Long John sternly questions Morgan, who denies having ever seen Black Dog before or knowing his name, punctuating his denial with a salute.

Silver warns Morgan that it's fortunate for him he wasn't truly acquainted with Black Dog, threatening that he would have been barred from the tavern otherwise, and then presses Morgan about their conversation.
Morgan claims he doesn't rightly know what they were discussing.
Long John berates Morgan for his lack of awareness, sarcastically questioning his intelligence, and demands to know the topic of their conversation—voyages, captains, ships.
Morgan replies that they were talking about keel-hauling.
Silver sardonically agrees it's a suitable topic for Morgan and dismisses him back to his seat, calling him a lubber.
As Morgan retreats, Silver whispers confidentially to Jim, in a manner Jim finds flattering, that Morgan is an honest man, just unintelligent.
Silver then aloud feigns difficulty recalling the name Black Dog, but then pretends to remember seeing him with a blind beggar.
Jim confirms this and adds that he knew the blind man, whose name was Pew.

Silver reacts with apparent excitement to the name Pew, remarking on his shark-like appearance and expressing eagerness to capture Black Dog for Captain Trelawney, praising Ben's running abilities and vowing to 'keel-haul' Black Dog himself.
Throughout this performance, Silver moves animatedly, slapping tables and displaying such convincing excitement that Jim notes it would have fooled legal authorities.
Jim's earlier suspicions, rekindled by finding Black Dog at the Spy-glass, lead him to watch Silver closely, but Silver's depth, readiness, and cleverness are too much for Jim.

By the time the two pursuers return breathless, confessing they lost Black Dog in a crowd and are subsequently scolded by Silver, Jim is so thoroughly deceived that he would have vouched for Long John Silver's innocence.

events.text_segment:
The man whom he called Morgan—an old, grey-haired, mahogany-faced sailor—came forward pretty sheepishly, rolling his quid.
“Now, Morgan,” said Long John very sternly, “you never clapped your eyes on that Black—Black Dog before, did you, now?”
“Not I, sir,” said Morgan with a salute.
“You didn’t know his name, did you?”
“No, sir.”
“By the powers, Tom Morgan, it’s as good for you!” exclaimed the landlord. “If you had been mixed up with the like of that, you would never have put another foot in my house, you may lay to that. And what was he saying to you?”
“I don’t rightly know, sir,” answered Morgan.
“Do you call that a head on your shoulders, or a blessed dead-eye?” cried Long John. “Don’t rightly know, don’t you! Perhaps you don’t happen to rightly know who you was speaking to, perhaps? Come, now, what was he jawing—v’yages, cap’ns, ships? Pipe up! What was it?”
“We was a-talkin’ of keel-hauling,” answered Morgan.
“Keel-hauling, was you? And a mighty suitable thing, too, and you may lay to that. Get back to your place for a lubber, Tom.”
And then, as Morgan rolled back to his seat, Silver added to me in a confidential whisper that was very flattering, as I thought, “He’s quite an honest man, Tom Morgan, on’y stupid. And now,” he ran on again, aloud, “let’s see—Black Dog? No, I don’t know the name, not I. Yet I kind of think I’ve—yes, I’ve seen the swab. He used to come here with a blind beggar, he used.”
“That he did, you may be sure,” said I. “I knew that blind man too. His name was Pew.”
“It was!” cried Silver, now quite excited. “Pew! That were his name for certain. Ah, he looked a shark, he did! If we run down this Black Dog, now, there’ll be news for Cap’n Trelawney! Ben’s a good runner; few seamen run better than Ben. He should run him down, hand over hand, by the powers! He talked o’ keel-hauling, did he? I’ll keel-haul him!”
All the time he was jerking out these phrases he was stumping up and down the tavern on his crutch, slapping tables with his hand, and giving such a show of excitement as would have convinced an Old Bailey judge or a Bow Street runner. My suspicions had been thoroughly reawakened on finding Black Dog at the Spy-glass, and I watched the cook narrowly. But he was too deep, and too ready, and too clever for me, and by the time the two men had come back out of breath and confessed that they had lost the track in a crowd, and been scolded like thieves, I would have gone bail for the innocence of Long John Silver.

events.title: Silver's Calculated Lament and Shared Merriment with Jim
detailed_summary: Silver addresses Jim, lamenting the difficult situation Black Dog's escape has placed him in, particularly concerning Captain Trelawney's likely opinion.
He complains about the audacity of Black Dog sitting in his establishment, drinking his rum, and then managing to escape despite Jim plainly identifying him.
Silver pleads for Jim to represent him fairly to the captain, acknowledging Jim's youth but praising his astuteness.
He emphasizes his helplessness due to his wooden leg, claiming that in his prime as an able-bodied master mariner, he would have swiftly apprehended Black Dog.
Suddenly, Silver stops, his jaw dropping as if a crucial thought has just struck him.
He exclaims about Black Dog's unpaid bill for three measures of rum, feigning astonishment at having forgotten it.
He then collapses onto a bench, laughing until tears stream down his face. Jim cannot help but join in, and they laugh together boisterously until the tavern resounds.
Wiping his cheeks, Silver self-deprecatingly calls himself a 'precious old sea-calf' and suggests that he and Jim will get on well, humorously proposing he should be rated as a ship's boy.
He then abruptly shifts to a serious demeanor, stating that 'duty is duty' and they must go to Captain Trelawney to report the incident.

Silver acknowledges the seriousness of the matter and that neither of them has emerged from it with credit, then laughs heartily again about the unpaid score, compelling Jim to join in his mirth once more, despite not fully grasping the joke as Silver does.

events.text_segment:
“See here, now, Hawkins,” said he, “here’s a blessed hard thing on a man like me, now, ain’t it? There’s Cap’n Trelawney—what’s he to think? Here I have this confounded son of a Dutchman sitting in my own house drinking of my own rum! Here you comes and tells me of it plain; and here I let him give us all the slip before my blessed deadlights! Now, Hawkins, you do me justice with the cap’n. You’re a lad, you are, but you’re as smart as paint. I see that when you first come in. Now, here it is: What could I do, with this old timber I hobble on? When I was an A B master mariner I’d have come up alongside of him, hand over hand, and broached him to in a brace of old shakes, I would; but now—”
And then, all of a sudden, he stopped, and his jaw dropped as though he had remembered something.
“The score!” he burst out. “Three goes o’ rum! Why, shiver my timbers, if I hadn’t forgotten my score!”
And falling on a bench, he laughed until the tears ran down his cheeks. I could not help joining, and we laughed together, peal after peal, until the tavern rang again.
“Why, what a precious old sea-calf I am!” he said at last, wiping his cheeks. “You and me should get on well, Hawkins, for I’ll take my davy I should be rated ship’s boy. But come now, stand by to go about. This won’t do. Dooty is dooty, messmates. I’ll put on my old cockerel hat, and step along of you to Cap’n Trelawney, and report this here affair. For mind you, it’s serious, young Hawkins; and neither you nor me’s come out of it with what I should make so bold as to call credit. Nor you neither, says you; not smart—none of the pair of us smart. But dash my buttons! That was a good un about my score.”
And he began to laugh again, and that so heartily, that though I did not see the joke as he did, I was again obliged to join him in his mirth.

events.title: An Informative Stroll and Silver's Report to the Squire and Doctor
detailed_summary: During their walk along the quays to the inn, Long John Silver makes himself an exceptionally engaging companion for Jim.
He identifies the various ships they pass, explaining details about their rigging, tonnage, and country of origin.
Silver also clarifies the different types of work happening at the docks—one ship unloading cargo, another loading, a third preparing to set sail.
He frequently shares brief stories about ships or sailors, or repeats nautical terms until Jim has learned them thoroughly.
Through these interactions, Jim starts to view Silver as one of the best possible shipmates.
When they arrive at the inn, they find Squire Trelawney and Dr. Livesey finishing a quart of ale, containing a piece of toast, before their intended visit to inspect the schooner.

Long John recounts the story of Black Dog's appearance and escape from beginning to end, doing so with great animation and, in Jim's assessment, perfect truthfulness. He would occasionally turn to Jim for confirmation, saying something like, 'That was how it was, wasn't it, Hawkins?', and Jim was always able to fully support his account.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On our little walk along the quays, he made himself the most interesting companion, telling me about the different ships that we passed by, their rig, tonnage, and nationality, explaining the work that was going forward—how one was discharging, another taking in cargo, and a third making ready for sea—and every now and then telling me some little anecdote of ships or seamen or repeating a nautical phrase till I had learned it perfectly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “That was how it were, now, weren’t it, Hawkins?” he would say, now and again, and I could always bear him entirely out.

events.text_segment:
On our little walk along the quays, he made himself the most interesting companion, telling me about the different ships that we passed by, their rig, tonnage, and nationality, explaining the work that was going forward—how one was discharging, another taking in cargo, and a third making ready for sea—and every now and then telling me some little anecdote of ships or seamen or repeating a nautical phrase till I had learned it perfectly. I began to see that here was one of the best of possible shipmates.
When we got to the inn, the squire and Dr. Livesey were seated together, finishing a quart of ale with a toast in it, before they should go aboard the schooner on a visit of inspection.
Long John told the story from first to last, with a great deal of spirit and the most perfect truth. “That was how it were, now, weren’t it, Hawkins?” he would say, now and again, and I could always bear him entirely out.

events.title: Gentlemen's Approval of Silver and Jim's Invitation Aboard
detailed_summary: Squire Trelawney and Dr. Livesey express their regret that Black Dog managed to escape, but everyone concurs that nothing further could have been done.
After receiving compliments for his handling of the situation, Long John Silver takes his crutch and departs.
As he leaves, the squire calls after him, reminding him that all crew members are to be aboard the ship by four o'clock that afternoon.
Silver, from the passage, responds affirmatively.
Once Silver is gone, Dr. Livesey comments to the squire that while he generally doesn't place much confidence in the squire's discoveries, he finds John Silver to his liking.
The squire enthusiastically agrees, declaring Silver to be 'a perfect trump.'
Dr. Livesey then suggests that Jim might be allowed to come aboard the ship with them.
The squire readily agrees and tells Jim to get his hat, as they are all going to see the ship.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Take your hat, Hawkins, and we’ll see the ship.”

events.text_segment:
The two gentlemen regretted that Black Dog had got away, but we all agreed there was nothing to be done, and after he had been complimented, Long John took up his crutch and departed.
“All hands aboard by four this afternoon,” shouted the squire after him.
“Aye, aye, sir,” cried the cook, in the passage.
“Well, squire,” said Dr. Livesey, “I don’t put much faith in your discoveries, as a general thing; but I will say this, John Silver suits me.”
“The man’s a perfect trump,” declared the squire.
“And now,” added the doctor, “Jim may come on board with us, may he not?”
“To be sure he may,” says squire. “Take your hat, Hawkins, and we’ll see the ship.”

events.title: Arrival at Hispaniola and Initial Tensions
detailed_summary: The narrator describes their boat journey to the Hispaniola, navigating among other ships.
Upon boarding, they are greeted by Mr. Arrow, the mate, characterized as an old, squinting sailor with earrings.
The narrator observes a strong friendship between Mr. Arrow and Squire Trelawney.
A noticeable contrast in demeanor is apparent between Mr. Trelawney and Captain Smollett.
Captain Smollett is depicted as a sharp-looking individual who seemed displeased with everything on the ship.
Shortly after they enter the cabin, a sailor informs Squire Trelawney that Captain Smollett wishes to speak with him.
Captain Smollett promptly enters the cabin, following his messenger, and closes the door.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Hispaniola lay some way out, and we went under the figureheads and round the sterns of many other ships, and their cables sometimes grated underneath our keel, and sometimes swung above us.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The captain, who was close behind his messenger, entered at once and shut the door behind him.

events.text_segment:
The Hispaniola lay some way out, and we went under the figureheads and round the sterns of many other ships, and their cables sometimes grated underneath our keel, and sometimes swung above us. At last, however, we got alongside, and were met and saluted as we stepped aboard by the mate, Mr. Arrow, a brown old sailor with earrings in his ears and a squint. He and the squire were very thick and friendly, but I soon observed that things were not the same between Mr. Trelawney and the captain.
This last was a sharp-looking man who seemed angry with everything on board and was soon to tell us why, for we had hardly got down into the cabin when a sailor followed us.
“Captain Smollett, sir, axing to speak with you,” said he.
“I am always at the captain’s orders. Show him in,” said the squire.
The captain, who was close behind his messenger, entered at once and shut the door behind him.

events.title: Captain Smollett's Unveiled Discontent
detailed_summary: Squire Trelawney initiates the conversation, asking Captain Smollett for his assessment of the ship and preparations.
Captain Smollett responds directly and bluntly, stating his dissatisfaction with the cruise, the crew, and his officer, Mr. Arrow.
Squire Trelawney, visibly angered, challenges Smollett, questioning if he also dislikes the ship and, implicitly, his employer.
Dr. Livesey calmly intervenes, advising against questions likely to cause ill feeling and insists that Smollett must elaborate on his stark pronouncements.
Smollett explains that he was hired under "sealed orders" but has discovered that every crew member below officer rank is better informed about the voyage's details than he is, which he deems unfair.
He reveals that he has learned from his own men that the voyage is a treasure hunt.

Smollett expresses his deep apprehension about treasure voyages in general, particularly those that are meant to be secret but have clearly been compromised, alluding to the widespread knowledge by suggesting the secret was "told to the parrot."
He concludes by stating his belief that neither Trelawney nor Livesey fully comprehend the severe risks involved, which he characterizes as a matter of life or death.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, Captain Smollett, what have you to say? All well, I hope; all shipshape and seaworthy?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It’s my belief neither of you gentlemen know what you are about, but I’ll tell you my way of it—life or death, and a close run.”

events.text_segment:
“Well, Captain Smollett, what have you to say? All well, I hope; all shipshape and seaworthy?”
“Well, sir,” said the captain, “better speak plain, I believe, even at the risk of offence. I don’t like this cruise; I don’t like the men; and I don’t like my officer. That’s short and sweet.”
“Perhaps, sir, you don’t like the ship?” inquired the squire, very angry, as I could see.
“I can’t speak as to that, sir, not having seen her tried,” said the captain. “She seems a clever craft; more I can’t say.”
“Possibly, sir, you may not like your employer, either?” says the squire.
But here Dr. Livesey cut in.
“Stay a bit,” said he, “stay a bit. No use of such questions as that but to produce ill feeling. The captain has said too much or he has said too little, and I’m bound to say that I require an explanation of his words. You don’t, you say, like this cruise. Now, why?”
“I was engaged, sir, on what we call sealed orders, to sail this ship for that gentleman where he should bid me,” said the captain. “So far so good. But now I find that every man before the mast knows more than I do. I don’t call that fair, now, do you?”
“No,” said Dr. Livesey, “I don’t.”
“Next,” said the captain, “I learn we are going after treasure—hear it from my own hands, mind you. Now, treasure is ticklish work; I don’t like treasure voyages on any account, and I don’t like them, above all, when they are secret and when (begging your pardon, Mr. Trelawney) the secret has been told to the parrot.”
“Silver’s parrot?” asked the squire.
“It’s a way of speaking,” said the captain. “Blabbed, I mean. It’s my belief neither of you gentlemen know what you are about, but I’ll tell you my way of it—life or death, and a close run.”

```text
“Well, Captain Smollett, what have you to say? All well, I hope; all shipshape and seaworthy?” asked the squire.

“All as bad as can be, I am afraid, Mr. Trelawney,” replied the captain very gloomily. “I don’t like this cruise; I don’t like the men; and I don’t like my officer. That’s what I have to say.”

“Perhaps you don’t like the ship either, sir?” exclaimed the squire, very angry, and I must say, not without cause.

“I don’t like anything about her but the voyage,” replied the captain. “I say, sir,” he went on, “I was engaged as captain of the ship, to obey orders, not to be told secrets. When I am told you are to sail at such a time, and for such a place, it is as much as I require to know. But I find that every man before the mast knows more than I do. I don’t call that fair, sir.”

“No,” said Dr. Livesey, “I don’t call that fair either.”

“Good heavens!” cried the squire, “you don’t mean to say that the voyage is a secret from the captain?”

“No, sir,” replied Smollett. “On the contrary, I find that all the men know more about it than I do.”

“I see,” said the doctor. “You mean that the secret has been told to the parrot?”

“It has been told to the parrot, sir,” cried the captain, “and to the whole crew. And I can tell you, sir, I don’t like it. I don’t like treasure voyages at all, and I don’t like them when they are secret and the secret has been told to the whole crew. It’s a matter of life and death, sir, and I don’t think you and Mr. Trelawney understand it.”
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Well, Captain Smollett, what have you to say? All well, I hope; all shipshape and seaworthy?”

“Well, sir,” said the captain, “I am not very well pleased. I do not like the cruise; I do not like the men; and I do not like my officer. That is what I have to say.”

“Perhaps, sir,” said I, “you do not like the ship either?”

“I do not like anything about her,” returned Smollett. “I am afraid the cruise is of such a nature, sir, as to be extremely dangerous.”

“Dangerous!” cried the squire. “Why, now, I am glad to hear that! I like danger! I am the man to meet danger head on!”

“The men, sir,” continued the captain, “are not to be trusted. I have heard them talking. They are too familiar, too ready with their tongues. And they know too much. They know the object of the cruise. I do not like that, sir. I wish a ship’s company to be all of a piece, and not mixed up with shore-loafers, as I see some of these are.”

“Come, come, Captain,” said the squire, a little nettled, “you are too particular. These are excellent fellows, I tell you. And as for the officer, Mr. Arrow, I have found him a first-rate seaman.”

“Mr. Arrow, sir,” replied the captain, “is a man I don’t approve of. He has no command among the men, and I don’t like his looks. And as for the cruise itself, sir, I think it is a most imprudent business. I have heard too much talk about treasure. It is not a thing to be talked about. I don’t like secrets of that kind on board a ship. I fear it will breed trouble.”

events.title: Further Complaints and Strategic Precautions
detailed_summary: Dr. Livesey acknowledges the captain's points as clear and likely true, accepting the inherent risks of their venture but asserting they are not as naive as Smollett presumes.
Smollett continues his list of grievances, stating he dislikes the crew and believes he should have been responsible for selecting them.
Dr. Livesey concedes that Trelawney perhaps should have involved the captain in hiring, attributing any slight as unintentional.

When questioned about Mr. Arrow, Smollett clarifies that while he considers Arrow a good seaman, he believes Arrow is too informal and familiar with the crew to be an effective officer, emphasizing a mate should maintain distance and not fraternize with ordinary sailors; he specifies this isn't about Arrow drinking, but about undue familiarity.
Pressed by Dr. Livesey for his demands, and after confirming the gentlemen are resolute in proceeding with the cruise (“Like iron,” affirms the Squire), Smollett outlines specific changes.
He proposes relocating the ship's powder and firearms from the fore hold to a more secure position beneath the cabin as his first point.
His second suggestion is to assign berths near the cabin to the four personal retainers Trelawney is bringing, rather than having them berthed forward.

Smollett then raises his third point: the excessive "blabbing" about the mission, revealing he has heard that they possess a treasure map marked with crosses and knows the island's exact latitude and longitude, information the crew also possesses.
Squire Trelawney vehemently denies ever sharing the island's specific location with anyone.

The narrator observes that neither Dr. Livesey nor Captain Smollett seems to give much weight to Trelawney's denial, and indeed, the narrator himself, while acknowledging Trelawney's tendency to be a loose talker, believes Trelawney was truthful in this specific instance about not revealing the island's coordinates.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “That is all clear, and, I dare say, true enough,” replied Dr. Livesey.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Neither did I, to be sure, he was so loose a talker; yet in this case I believe he was really right and that nobody had told the situation of the island.

events.text_segment:
“That is all clear, and, I dare say, true enough,” replied Dr. Livesey. “We take the risk, but we are not so ignorant as you believe us. Next, you say you don’t like the crew. Are they not good seamen?”
“I don’t like them, sir,” returned Captain Smollett. “And I think I should have had the choosing of my own hands, if you go to that.”
“Perhaps you should,” replied the doctor. “My friend should, perhaps, have taken you along with him; but the slight, if there be one, was unintentional. And you don’t like Mr. Arrow?”
“I don’t, sir. I believe he’s a good seaman, but he’s too free with the crew to be a good officer. A mate should keep himself to himself—shouldn’t drink with the men before the mast!”
“Do you mean he drinks?” cried the squire.
“No, sir,” replied the captain, “only that he’s too familiar.”
“Well, now, and the short and long of it, captain?” asked the doctor. “Tell us what you want.”
“Well, gentlemen, are you determined to go on this cruise?”
“Like iron,” answered the squire.
“Very good,” said the captain. “Then, as you’ve heard me very patiently, saying things that I could not prove, hear me a few words more. They are putting the powder and the arms in the fore hold. Now, you have a good place under the cabin; why not put them there?—first point. Then, you are bringing four of your own people with you, and they tell me some of them are to be berthed forward. Why not give them the berths here beside the cabin?—second point.”
“Any more?” asked Mr. Trelawney.
“One more,” said the captain. “There’s been too much blabbing already.”
“Far too much,” agreed the doctor.
“I’ll tell you what I’ve heard myself,” continued Captain Smollett: “that you have a map of an island, that there’s crosses on the map to show where treasure is, and that the island lies—” And then he named the latitude and longitude exactly.
“I never told that,” cried the squire, “to a soul!”
“The hands know it, sir,” returned the captain.
“Livesey, that must have been you or Hawkins,” cried the squire.
“It doesn’t much matter who it was,” replied the doctor. And I could see that neither he nor the captain paid much regard to Mr. Trelawney’s protestations. Neither did I, to be sure, he was so loose a talker; yet in this case I believe he was really right and that nobody had told the situation of the island.

But at the same time, living in a glass house, as you are pleased to say, we are bound to be on the alert, and my conscience is quite clear. At least, of course, it would be if I had not had the misfortune to sail with you.”

“Well, sir, you laugh,” said the captain. “I shall say no more. Here is my report.” And he handed me a list of grievances. “There, sir,” he continued, turning to the squire, “that’s what I complain of. First, I’ve no liking for this cruise altogether; and I think it’s a damned dangerous cruise, too. But there’s a man’s duty, sir, and I’ll do it. Second, I consider I was treated shamefully. I am the captain, you see, and the owner of the ship is here, aboard, sir, so is the doctor, and there’s what you call gentlemen of fortune aboard, by your own account. Well, sir, I’ve not been consulted at all in the choice of men. If you had asked me, I would have told you what I knew of some of these fellows. Ay, doctor, you may stare, but it’s true. That Rogue’s Harbour boatswain, I don’t like him. And Mr. Arrow, I don’t like him. And if I was to be hanged, I couldn’t tell you what I dislike them for, but I don’t like them. And that’s enough. By God, I’ll not have it. This is irregular, and you may take my word for it, sir, with no common sailors, not a man of them but knows more than I do. I don’t like it, sir, not I.”

“I don’t understand,” said Squire Trelawney, with a trembling voice. “I don’t understand what you mean, sir.”

“Why, sir,” returned the captain, “I mean that the ship is loaded with powder and arms, and that you have been blabbing. That’s what I mean.”

The squire and Dr. Livesey looked at each other, and then at the captain. “No, sir,” said the doctor, “you are mistaken. The squire has not blabbed. He is a gentleman, sir, and a man of honour.”

“Ay, sir,” said the captain, “so he may be. But I say he has blabbed. I say he has blabbed, sir, and I say the crew knows all about it. They know the island, sir, and they know the latitude and longitude, and they know there’s a map with crosses on it. And that’s what I mean, sir.”
