events.title: Mutineers Plan Murder; Jim Overhears Crucial News and Land is Sighted
detailed_summary: Dick inquires about the intended fate of the loyal crew members after the mutineers seize control.

Silver commends Dick for his pragmatic question and contrasts two historical approaches: Captain England's method of marooning captives, versus the more brutal tactic of outright slaughter favored by Captain Flint or Billy Bones.
Israel Hands affirms Billy Bones's ruthlessness, recalling his maxim that 'dead men don't bite,' and noting that Bones himself is now deceased.

Silver acknowledges Billy's 'rough and ready' nature but asserts that despite his own generally amiable disposition, the current situation demands severity; he casts his vote for killing all loyalists.

He explains his reasoning: he wants no survivors ('sea-lawyers') to potentially reappear and threaten his comfortable retirement. He advocates patience until the opportune moment, then decisive, lethal action.
Israel Hands expresses admiration for Silver's resolute stance.
Silver then declares his personal intention to kill Trelawney, graphically vowing to wring his neck. He then abruptly asks Dick to fetch him an apple to 'wet his pipe'.
Jim, still hidden in the apple barrel, is overcome with terror at Silver's request, feeling too paralyzed to escape.
As Dick begins to rise, Israel Hands intervenes, suggesting they have rum instead, disparaging the apples as 'bilge'.
Silver agrees, providing Dick with the key to the rum keg but cautioning him about the gauge, implying a need for rationing.
Jim reflects that this secretive provision of alcohol must have been how Mr. Arrow, a former officer, was supplied with the spirits that led to his downfall.

While Dick is briefly absent fetching the rum, Jim overhears a crucial snippet of conversation between Israel and Silver: 'Not another man of them'll jine.' This reveals to Jim that there are still crew members loyal to the captain.

Upon Dick's return, the three mutineers take turns drinking from the pannikin, offering toasts to 'luck,' 'old Flint,' and Silver leading a chant-like toast to themselves, future prizes, and plentiful food.
At that moment, moonlight illuminates Jim's hiding place in the barrel. Simultaneously, the lookout's cry of 'Land ho!' pierces the night.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “But,” asked Dick, “when we do lay ’em athwart, what are we to do with ’em, anyhow?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Just then a sort of brightness fell upon me in the barrel, and looking up, I found the moon had risen and was silvering the mizzen-top and shining white on the luff of the fore-sail; and almost at the same time the voice of the lookout shouted, “Land ho!”

events.text_segment:
“But,” asked Dick, “when we do lay ’em athwart, what are we to do with ’em, anyhow?”
“There’s the man for me!” cried the cook admiringly. “That’s what I call business. Well, what would you think? Put ’em ashore like maroons? That would have been England’s way. Or cut ’em down like that much pork? That would have been Flint’s, or Billy Bones’s.”
“Billy was the man for that,” said Israel. “‘Dead men don’t bite,’ says he. Well, he’s dead now hisself; he knows the long and short on it now; and if ever a rough hand come to port, it was Billy.”
“Right you are,” said Silver; “rough and ready. But mark you here, I’m an easy man—I’m quite the gentleman, says you; but this time it’s serious. Dooty is dooty, mates. I give my vote—death. When I’m in Parlyment and riding in my coach, I don’t want none of these sea-lawyers in the cabin a-coming home, unlooked for, like the devil at prayers. Wait is what I say; but when the time comes, why, let her rip!”
“John,” cries the coxswain, “you’re a man!”
“You’ll say so, Israel when you see,” said Silver. “Only one thing I claim—I claim Trelawney. I’ll wring his calf’s head off his body with these hands, Dick!” he added, breaking off. “You just jump up, like a sweet lad, and get me an apple, to wet my pipe like.”
You may fancy the terror I was in! I should have leaped out and run for it if I had found the strength, but my limbs and heart alike misgave me. I heard Dick begin to rise, and then someone seemingly stopped him, and the voice of Hands exclaimed, “Oh, stow that! Don’t you get sucking of that bilge, John. Let’s have a go of the rum.”
“Dick,” said Silver, “I trust you. I’ve a gauge on the keg, mind. There’s the key; you fill a pannikin and bring it up.”
Terrified as I was, I could not help thinking to myself that this must have been how Mr. Arrow got the strong waters that destroyed him.
Dick was gone but a little while, and during his absence Israel spoke straight on in the cook’s ear. It was but a word or two that I could catch, and yet I gathered some important news, for besides other scraps that tended to the same purpose, this whole clause was audible: “Not another man of them’ll jine.” Hence there were still faithful men on board.
When Dick returned, one after another of the trio took the pannikin and drank—one “To luck,” another with a “Here’s to old Flint,” and Silver himself saying, in a kind of song, “Here’s to ourselves, and hold your luff, plenty of prizes and plenty of duff.”
Just then a sort of brightness fell upon me in the barrel, and looking up, I found the moon had risen and was silvering the mizzen-top and shining white on the luff of the fore-sail; and almost at the same time the voice of the lookout shouted, “Land ho!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“But,” asked Dick, “when we do lay ’em athwart, what are we to do with ’em, anyhow?”

“Ah, Dick,” said Silver, “when we lay ’em athwart, they’ll miss their pigtail, that’s what, and the cabin passengers too. See here, lad, I’ve sailed with a lad that’s sailed with England, the great England of the south, that would never work to windward with less than thirty hands, messmates, no, nor a dozen pound of powder below the gangway. And what did he do with captives? Show ’em the cabin door? No. He kept ’em prisoners, Dick, and he’d have none of their combings and he’d be the boy to go against ’em clear. And what was the upshot? He was marooned and died of starvation in the end, no doubt of it. Now, Flint, he was bad; he was, and hands down; but he weren’t so bad either. He would have them slung to the yardarm, all of ’em, and a short shrift; and so would Billy Bones and his crew, ay, and so would this Silver, by the Lord, if that was what the rules required. But what’s the good of that? I’m not Billy, nor I ain’t Flint. I’m myself, and I got my own way to get my living. I’m for saving all I can, that’s my way. It’s good policy, besides. And I ain’t so sure about killing. It’s a kind of a risk, you see. Dead men don’t bite, says the old saw. But they don’t tell no tales either. And I’d have no tales told about me. I’d have no man live to come back and find me. I’d have no sea-lawyer in the world to go about and speak of me as a pirate. I’m for a quiet life, I am. I’m for a comfortable retirement, and I wouldn’t risk it for a dozen of your sea-lawyers. No, I’ll have no survivors, not one. I’ll have them all swing, every man of them, and the cabin passengers too. And as for that there Squire Trelawney, I’ll wring his neck myself!”

And he made a gesture with his hands that made Jim’s blood run cold.

“Ay,” said Israel Hands, “Billy was the boy for that. ‘Dead men don’t bite,’ says he. Well, he’s dead himself now; he knows the truth of it.”

“Billy was rough and ready,” said Silver, “and a man of few words. But he knew his business. And so do I. I’m for a clean sweep, I am. I’m for a clean sweep and a clear conscience. I’m for a comfortable retirement, and I’ll have it. And I’ll have no man live to come back and find me. I’ll have them all swing, every man of them, and the cabin passengers too. And as for that there Squire Trelawney, I’ll wring his neck myself!”

And again he made the gesture.

“Well, I see I’m of your opinion, John,” said Israel. “It’s the safest way, and it’s the shortest. Dead men don’t bite.”

“Ay, dead men don’t bite,” said Dick. “But I wish I’d known it sooner. I’d have been easier in my mind.”

“Well, you know it now,” said Silver. “And you know my mind. I’m for a clean sweep. And I’ll have it. And now, Dick, fetch me an apple to wet my pipe. It’s a long story, and I’m dry.”

Jim was so terrified at the thought of Silver’s coming near the barrel that he could not move. He lay there, for all the world, as if he were dead. And the mutineers continued their talk, as if there were no such person as Jim Hawkins in the world.

“Apples is bilge,” said Israel. “They ain’t no good for a man. Give him rum.”

“Rum it is,” said Silver. “Dick, fetch the key of the rum keg. And mind the gauge, lad, it’s low.”

Dick was gone but a little while, and during his absence, Israel said to Silver:

“Not another man of them’ll jine.”

This was a great relief to Jim, for it showed him that there were still some loyal hands aboard.

events.title: Island Sighted and Silver's Cartographic Deception
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jim Hawkins, after hastily exiting the apple barrel, manages to join Hunter and Dr. Livesey on deck without being seen by those he was spying on, as everyone hurried towards the weather bow.

The timely lifting of a fog bank coincided with the moon's appearance, revealing two low hills to the south-west, approximately two miles apart, with a taller, fog-enshrouded peak rising behind one of them, all appearing conical.
Still reeling from his recent fear, Jim observed these sights as if in a dream.
Captain Smollett then gave commands, altering the Hispaniola's course to pass the island to its east.
The captain inquired if any of the crew recognized the newly sighted land.
Long John Silver stepped forward, claiming prior knowledge of the island from a time he was a cook on a trading vessel that had stopped there for water.

Silver confidently provided details, stating the anchorage was south, behind an islet, and that the island was called Skeleton Island, a former pirate hub. He identified the northern hill as Foremast Hill and a southern trio as fore, main, and mizzen, with the main, cloud-topped hill commonly known as the Spy-glass, used by pirates as a lookout.

Captain Smollett produced a chart, and Silver, though his eyes gleamed with interest, quickly perceived it was an accurate copy but lacked the crucial treasure markings from the original map found in Billy Bones's chest.

Despite his evident annoyance, Silver adeptly masked his disappointment, affirming the chart's accuracy, pointing out features like 'Capt. Kidd’s Anchorage,' and discussing currents, thereby substantiating his supposed familiarity and appearing cooperative.
Captain Smollett thanked Silver for the information, indicated he might seek his assistance later, and then dismissed him.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: You may go.”

events.text_segment:
There was a great rush of feet across the deck. I could hear people tumbling up from the cabin and the forecastle, and slipping in an instant outside my barrel, I dived behind the fore-sail, made a double towards the stern, and came out upon the open deck in time to join Hunter and Dr. Livesey in the rush for the weather bow.
There all hands were already congregated. A belt of fog had lifted almost simultaneously with the appearance of the moon. Away to the south-west of us we saw two low hills, about a couple of miles apart, and rising behind one of them a third and higher hill, whose peak was still buried in the fog. All three seemed sharp and conical in figure.
So much I saw, almost in a dream, for I had not yet recovered from my horrid fear of a minute or two before. And then I heard the voice of Captain Smollett issuing orders. The Hispaniola was laid a couple of points nearer the wind and now sailed a course that would just clear the island on the east.
“And now, men,” said the captain, when all was sheeted home, “has any one of you ever seen that land ahead?”
“I have, sir,” said Silver. “I’ve watered there with a trader I was cook in.”
“The anchorage is on the south, behind an islet, I fancy?” asked the captain.
“Yes, sir; Skeleton Island they calls it. It were a main place for pirates once, and a hand we had on board knowed all their names for it. That hill to the nor’ard they calls the Foremast Hill; there are three hills in a row running south’ard—fore, main, and mizzen, sir. But the main—that’s the big un, with the cloud on it—they usually calls the Spy-glass, by reason of a lookout they kept when they was in the anchorage cleaning, for it’s there they cleaned their ships, sir, asking your pardon.”
“I have a chart here,” says Captain Smollett. “See if that’s the place.”
Long John’s eyes burned in his head as he took the chart, but by the fresh look of the paper I knew he was doomed to disappointment. This was not the map we found in Billy Bones’s chest, but an accurate copy, complete in all things—names and heights and soundings—with the single exception of the red crosses and the written notes. Sharp as must have been his annoyance, Silver had the strength of mind to hide it.
“Yes, sir,” said he, “this is the spot, to be sure, and very prettily drawed out. Who might have done that, I wonder? The pirates were too ignorant, I reckon. Aye, here it is: ‘Capt. Kidd’s Anchorage’—just the name my shipmate called it. There’s a strong current runs along the south, and then away nor’ard up the west coast. Right you was, sir,” says he, “to haul your wind and keep the weather of the island. Leastways, if such was your intention as to enter and careen, and there ain’t no better place for that in these waters.”
“Thank you, my man,” says Captain Smollett. “I’ll ask you later on to give us a help. You may go.”

I could see a captain’s boat, loaded with lads, pulling away from the schooner, and the rest of the hands hurrying to the weather bow. I was just wondering what could be to do, when I saw the dark face of Silver rise from over the bulwarks, and caught the glint of a musket barrel. I should have cried out, but I caught a sight of Hunter and Dr. Livesey in the waist of the ship looking astern. I thought I should be safer with them, and I slipped out of the barrel and ran as fast as I could to their side. They were talking together, and looking very grave. “Don’t you hear it?” said Dr. Livesey. “I heard it plain. It was a man groaning.” “Well, it’s not much to make a fuss about,” said Hunter. “We’re all pretty tired and stiff. I dare say it’s only one of the men asleep and dreaming.” “The groans came from the apple barrel,” said the doctor. “Well, then, it’s not one of the men asleep and dreaming,” said Hunter. “It’s one of the mutineers.” “That’s what I think,” said the doctor. “And I think it’s Silver.” “But what are we to do?” said Hunter. “We can’t fight the whole crew.” “No,” said the doctor. “But we can be ready for them. We must get the captain to arm us.” Just then Captain Smollett came up. “Well, gentlemen,” said he, “what’s the matter?” “Captain,” said the doctor, “we have just heard a man groaning in the apple barrel. We think it’s Silver.” “Indeed,” said the captain. “Well, we must look into this.” He went to the apple barrel and looked in. “There’s no one here,” said he. “He must have got out.” “He must have heard us talking,” said the doctor. “Well, gentlemen,” said the captain, “this is a serious business. We must be on our guard.” He went to the cabin and came back with three muskets and a powder horn. “Here, gentlemen,” said he, “take these. And be ready for anything.” We took the muskets and loaded them. We then went to the waist of the ship and stood by the doctor. The captain went to the forecastle and spoke to the men. “Now, my lads,” said he, “we’re going to land on this island. I want you all to be on your best behaviour. There’s to be no drinking and no fighting. And I want you all to obey orders.” The men cheered. The captain then came back to us. “Well, gentlemen,” said he, “they seem to be in a good humour. But I don’t trust them.” Just then, the fog began to lift, and we saw the island. It was a low island, with two hills on it. The hills were about two miles apart. Behind the northern hill, there was a taller hill, which was covered with fog. The island was about two miles long and a mile wide. It was covered with trees. The trees came down to the water’s edge. There was a sandy beach in front of the trees. The water was clear and blue. There were a few rocks in the water. The rocks were covered with seaweed. There were a few birds flying about. The birds were gulls. We could hear the sound of the waves breaking on the beach. We could also hear the sound of the wind in the trees. The air was warm and humid. The sun was shining. It was a beautiful day. I stood there, looking at the island, as if in a dream. I had never seen anything so beautiful. I forgot all about the mutineers. I forgot all about the treasure. I forgot all about everything. I just stood there, looking at the island. Just then, Captain Smollett gave the order to change course. The Hispaniola turned to the east, and we sailed along the coast of the island. The captain then asked if any of the crew knew the island. Long John Silver stepped forward. “I know this island, sir,” said he. “I was here once before, in a trading vessel. We put in here for water.” “Indeed,” said the captain. “Can you tell us anything about it?” “Yes, sir,” said Silver. “The anchorage is on the south side, behind an islet. The island is called Skeleton Island. It used to be a pirate rendezvous.” “Indeed,” said the captain. “And what about the hills?” “The northern hill is called Foremast Hill,” said Silver. “The three hills on the south are called Fore, Main, and Mizzen. The main hill, the one with the cloud on it, is called the Spy-glass. It’s a famous landmark. The pirates used it as a lookout.” “Indeed,” said the captain. He then produced a chart. “Is this chart correct?” said he. Silver took the chart and looked at it. His eyes gleamed with interest. He saw that it was an accurate copy of the chart that Jim had found in Billy Bones’s chest. But he also saw that it did not have the treasure marks on it. He was clearly disappointed, but he did not show it. “Yes, sir,” said he. “This chart is correct. It shows the anchorage, and the hills, and everything. It even shows Capt. Kidd’s Anchorage.” He pointed to a spot on the chart. “That’s where he used to anchor,” said

events.title: Silver's Unsettling Overture to Jim
detailed_summary: Jim was unsettled by Silver's composure as he discussed the island and felt a growing sense of fear when Silver approached him directly.
Silver, seemingly oblivious to Jim having overheard his mutinous plotting, exuded an aura of cruelty, duplicity, and power that made Jim shudder involuntarily when Silver placed a hand on his arm.
In a deceptively warm tone, Silver described the island as a wonderful place for a young lad, painting pictures of enjoyable activities like swimming, climbing trees, and hunting goats.
He remarked that the island's allure made him feel rejuvenated, momentarily forgetting his prosthetic leg, and praised the benefits of youth and having all one's toes.
Silver then offered to prepare provisions for Jim should he wish to explore the island, maintaining his facade of a kindly old seaman.
With a final, seemingly amicable pat on Jim's shoulder, Silver moved towards the front of the ship and descended below deck.

events.text_segment:
I was surprised at the coolness with which John avowed his knowledge of the island, and I own I was half-frightened when I saw him drawing nearer to myself. He did not know, to be sure, that I had overheard his council from the apple barrel, and yet I had by this time taken such a horror of his cruelty, duplicity, and power that I could scarce conceal a shudder when he laid his hand upon my arm.
“Ah,” says he, “this here is a sweet spot, this island—a sweet spot for a lad to get ashore on. You’ll bathe, and you’ll climb trees, and you’ll hunt goats, you will; and you’ll get aloft on them hills like a goat yourself. Why, it makes me young again. I was going to forget my timber leg, I was. It’s a pleasant thing to be young and have ten toes, and you may lay to that. When you want to go a bit of exploring, you just ask old John, and he’ll put up a snack for you to take along.”
And clapping me in the friendliest way upon the shoulder, he hobbled off forward and went below.

But come, now, I’ll tell you what. You and me, we’ll be friends, you and me. And I’ll make your fortune, I will. I’ll make a man of you, Hawkins. I’ll make you as rich as a king, I will. And all you’ve got to do is to stand by me, and do as I bid you. That’s all. And you’ll never repent it, Hawkins, never. You’ll be a gentleman, you will. events.title: Jim's Urgent Warning and the Captain's Strategic Deception
detailed_summary: Jim observed Captain Smollett, Squire Trelawney, and Dr. Livesey in conversation on the quarter-deck, feeling a pressing need to convey his alarming discovery but reluctant to interrupt their discussion.
As Jim was contemplating how to approach them, Dr. Livesey summoned him, using the pretext of needing Jim to fetch his pipe from below.

When Jim was close enough to speak privately, he urgently informed the doctor of his 'terrible news' and requested that the captain and squire be brought to the cabin, after which Jim should be sent for under some guise.
Dr. Livesey's expression briefly betrayed surprise, but he quickly regained his composure.
In a loud voice, as if Jim had just provided some requested information, Dr. Livesey thanked him and then rejoined the captain and the squire.
The three men conversed briefly; although their behavior showed no outward signs of alarm, it was evident that Dr. Livesey had conveyed Jim's urgent request.
Subsequently, Captain Smollett ordered Job Anderson to summon all crew members to the deck.

Captain Smollett addressed the assembled crew, stating that the sighted land was their intended destination. He announced that Mr. Trelawney, in his generosity and satisfaction with the crew's performance, had invited the captain and doctor to the cabin to drink to the crew's health and good fortune.
He further declared that grog would be distributed for the crew to reciprocate the toast, praising Trelawney's munificence.
The crew responded with a powerful and enthusiastic cheer for Mr. Trelawney, a display Jim found deeply ironic given his knowledge of their treacherous plans.
Following this, Long John Silver initiated another cheer, this time for Captain Smollett, which the crew delivered with equal vigor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Captain Smollett, the squire, and Dr. Livesey were talking together on the quarter-deck, and anxious as I was to tell them my story, I durst not interrupt them openly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And this also was given with a will.

events.text_segment:
Captain Smollett, the squire, and Dr. Livesey were talking together on the quarter-deck, and anxious as I was to tell them my story, I durst not interrupt them openly. While I was still casting about in my thoughts to find some probable excuse, Dr. Livesey called me to his side. He had left his pipe below, and being a slave to tobacco, had meant that I should fetch it; but as soon as I was near enough to speak and not to be overheard, I broke immediately, “Doctor, let me speak. Get the captain and squire down to the cabin, and then make some pretence to send for me. I have terrible news.”
The doctor changed countenance a little, but next moment he was master of himself.
“Thank you, Jim,” said he quite loudly, “that was all I wanted to know,” as if he had asked me a question.
And with that he turned on his heel and rejoined the other two. They spoke together for a little, and though none of them started, or raised his voice, or so much as whistled, it was plain enough that Dr. Livesey had communicated my request, for the next thing that I heard was the captain giving an order to Job Anderson, and all hands were piped on deck.
“My lads,” said Captain Smollett, “I’ve a word to say to you. This land that we have sighted is the place we have been sailing for. Mr. Trelawney, being a very open-handed gentleman, as we all know, has just asked me a word or two, and as I was able to tell him that every man on board had done his duty, alow and aloft, as I never ask to see it done better, why, he and I and the doctor are going below to the cabin to drink your health and luck, and you’ll have grog served out for you to drink our health and luck. I’ll tell you what I think of this: I think it handsome. And if you think as I do, you’ll give a good sea-cheer for the gentleman that does it.”
The cheer followed—that was a matter of course; but it rang out so full and hearty that I confess I could hardly believe these same men were plotting for our blood.
“One more cheer for Cap’n Smollett,” cried Long John when the first had subsided.
And this also was given with a will.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Captain Smollett, the squire, and Dr. Livesey were talking together on the quarter-deck, and anxious as I was to tell them my story, I durst not interrupt them openly. While I stood by the weather bulwarks, I could overhear now and then a word of their conversation, but not enough to follow it. Presently the doctor strolled towards me. He was pale and grave. "Jim," says he, "fetch me a brier-root pipe from the locker," and he pointed at the cabin companion. I understood right away, and ran down. The pipe was not there, nor anywhere else in the cabin. I looked all round, but the thing had vanished. So I came up again with a pale face and told the doctor. He looked at me hard, and at the others, and seemed to pull himself together. "Well, never mind the pipe," says he, civilly, "bring me my pouch. But I suppose it's too much to expect," he added, with a chuckle, "that you should find the pipe, for you weren't there when I laid it down." I saw in a moment he was acting a part, and I knew that the others knew it too. They were all three of them pale and grave, and they all three of them looked at me with a kind of expectation. "Doctor," I whispered, "I have terrible news." He nodded, and I went on: "I have heard the whole story. The mutiny is to begin to-night." He nodded again. "The captain and the squire must be told," said I. "And you must send for me to the cabin, and I must tell you the whole story. I am afraid it is too long to tell you here." "Right," said he. "I'll see to it. Now, Jim," he added, aloud, "you can go." And so he went back to the others, and they talked together for a little, and I could see by their faces that they were very grave. Presently Captain Smollett hailed the deck. "Job Anderson," says he, "go below and get the hands up. Mr. Trelawney wants to speak to them." Job Anderson went below, and presently the men began to come up, one after another, till the whole ship's company was on deck. Captain Smollett stood on the quarter-deck, and the squire and the doctor stood by him. "Now, men," says the captain, "you all know that we are here to find treasure. We have sighted the island, and we shall be there to-morrow. Mr. Trelawney, in his great generosity, and because he is so well pleased with you all, has invited me and the doctor to the cabin to drink to your health and good fortune. And he has ordered a double allowance of grog to be served out to you all, so that you may drink to his health and good fortune in return." The men gave a great cheer for Mr. Trelawney, which, knowing what I knew, was a strange sound in my ears. "And now," says Silver, "three cheers for Captain Smollett!" And the men gave three more cheers, as hearty as the first.

events.title: Jim's Revelation of the Mutiny Plot
detailed_summary: After the crew's cheers, Captain Smollett, Squire Trelawney, and Dr. Livesey descended to the cabin.
A short while later, a message was sent to summon Jim Hawkins to join them.

Jim entered the cabin to find the three men seated around a table, with Spanish wine and raisins before them. Dr. Livesey was smoking, his wig resting on his lap, a detail Jim recognized as a sign of the doctor's agitation. The warm night air entered through the open stern window, which offered a view of the moonlit ship's wake.
Squire Trelawney prompted Jim to share his information.
Jim proceeded to recount, as succinctly as he could, all the details of Long John Silver's mutinous conversation that he had overheard from the apple barrel.
Throughout Jim's narration, none of the three listeners interrupted or made any movement, their gazes fixed intently on his face from beginning to end.
When Jim concluded his account, Dr. Livesey invited him to take a seat.
They seated Jim at the table with them, poured him a glass of wine, and offered him raisins.
Then, each of the three men, in turn and with a formal bow, toasted Jim's health, acknowledged his courage and good fortune, and expressed their gratitude for his service.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On the top of that the three gentlemen went below, and not long after, word was sent forward that Jim Hawkins was wanted in the cabin.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And all three, one after the other, and each with a bow, drank my good health, and their service to me, for my luck and courage.

events.text_segment:
On the top of that the three gentlemen went below, and not long after, word was sent forward that Jim Hawkins was wanted in the cabin.
I found them all three seated round the table, a bottle of Spanish wine and some raisins before them, and the doctor smoking away, with his wig on his lap, and that, I knew, was a sign that he was agitated. The stern window was open, for it was a warm night, and you could see the moon shining behind on the ship’s wake.
“Now, Hawkins,” said the squire, “you have something to say. Speak up.”
I did as I was bid, and as short as I could make it, told the whole details of Silver’s conversation. Nobody interrupted me till I was done, nor did any one of the three of them make so much as a movement, but they kept their eyes upon my face from first to last.
“Jim,” said Dr. Livesey, “take a seat.”
And they made me sit down at table beside them, poured me out a glass of wine, filled my hands with raisins, and all three, one after the other, and each with a bow, drank my good health, and their service to me, for my luck and courage.

What have you to say?" I sat down at the table and told them all that I had been able to hear. They listened like stone images. Dr. Livesey put down his pipe, and never moved, nor changed colour, nor so much as winked. When I was done, Mr. Trelawney sat still and looked at me, and seemed to think of nothing else. Captain Smollett was the first to speak. He turned to Dr. Livesey and said, "Is there a doctor aboard?" "Yes, sir," replied the doctor. "A man with a wig on his lap?" continued the captain. "I am that man," replied the doctor. "Why, then, doctor," cried the captain, "chances are you're right. I've no doubt of that. You are as smart as paint. I hate the doctor's wig, but I'll be hanged if I don't take off my hat to his head. If we save our skins, it will be your doing." "No, by the living jingo," cried the squire. "It shall be Jim's!" events.title: Council of War: Assessing the Odds and Formulating a Plan
detailed_summary: Squire Trelawney conceded to Captain Smollett that the captain's earlier suspicions about the crew had been correct and his own judgment flawed, placing himself under the captain's orders.
Captain Smollett admitted his own surprise, stating he had never encountered a crew that concealed mutinous intentions so effectively from anyone observant.
Dr. Livesey attributed the crew's successful deception to the cunning of Long John Silver, whom he described as a truly 'remarkable man'.
Captain Smollett grimly agreed with the assessment of Silver, suggesting a yard-arm would be a fitting end for him, but then steered the conversation towards actionable points.

Smollett outlined their predicament and strategy: first, they had no choice but to proceed, as an attempt to turn back would incite immediate mutiny; second, they had some time before the treasure was located; third, there were some loyal men among them.
He proposed that they bide their time and choose a moment for confrontation when the mutineers were least expecting it, aiming to 'take time by the forelock'.
The captain confirmed with Trelawney the loyalty of his personal servants.
They calculated their loyal faction to consist of seven individuals: the captain, the doctor, the squire, Jim Hawkins, and Trelawney's three servants.
They briefly discussed other potential loyalists, with the squire clarifying that Israel Hands, whom the captain had also thought trustworthy, was one of his own hires.
The squire expressed his profound disappointment and anger that the mutineers were all Englishmen, stating he felt like blowing up the entire ship.

Captain Smollett concluded that their best, albeit difficult, course of action was to remain on alert, maintain a constant watch, and wait until they could more clearly identify their allies and enemies before making any overt moves.
Dr. Livesey pointed out that Jim could be invaluable in gathering intelligence, as the crew members were generally unguarded around him and Jim was an observant boy.
Squire Trelawney affirmed his immense trust in Jim.
Jim felt a sense of desperation and helplessness despite their confidence in him, though he also noted, with hindsight, that safety eventually did come about through his actions.
The chapter ends on a somber note, emphasizing the precariousness of their situation: only seven trustworthy individuals, including Jim (a boy), against nineteen hostile crew members.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Now, captain,” said the squire, “you were right, and I was wrong.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In the meantime, talk as we pleased, there were only seven out of the twenty-six on whom we knew we could rely; and out of these seven one was a boy, so that the grown men on our side were six to their nineteen.

events.text_segment:
“Now, captain,” said the squire, “you were right, and I was wrong. I own myself an ass, and I await your orders.”
“No more an ass than I, sir,” returned the captain. “I never heard of a crew that meant to mutiny but what showed signs before, for any man that had an eye in his head to see the mischief and take steps according. But this crew,” he added, “beats me.”
“Captain,” said the doctor, “with your permission, that’s Silver. A very remarkable man.”
“He’d look remarkably well from a yard-arm, sir,” returned the captain. “But this is talk; this don’t lead to anything. I see three or four points, and with Mr. Trelawney’s permission, I’ll name them.”
“You, sir, are the captain. It is for you to speak,” says Mr. Trelawney grandly.
“First point,” began Mr. Smollett. “We must go on, because we can’t turn back. If I gave the word to go about, they would rise at once. Second point, we have time before us—at least until this treasure’s found. Third point, there are faithful hands. Now, sir, it’s got to come to blows sooner or later, and what I propose is to take time by the forelock, as the saying is, and come to blows some fine day when they least expect it. We can count, I take it, on your own home servants, Mr. Trelawney?”
“As upon myself,” declared the squire.
“Three,” reckoned the captain; “ourselves make seven, counting Hawkins here. Now, about the honest hands?”
“Most likely Trelawney’s own men,” said the doctor; “those he had picked up for himself before he lit on Silver.”
“Nay,” replied the squire. “Hands was one of mine.”
“I did think I could have trusted Hands,” added the captain.
“And to think that they’re all Englishmen!” broke out the squire. “Sir, I could find it in my heart to blow the ship up.”
“Well, gentlemen,” said the captain, “the best that I can say is not much. We must lay to, if you please, and keep a bright lookout. It’s trying on a man, I know. It would be pleasanter to come to blows. But there’s no help for it till we know our men. Lay to, and whistle for a wind, that’s my view.”
“Jim here,” said the doctor, “can help us more than anyone. The men are not shy with him, and Jim is a noticing lad.”
“Hawkins, I put prodigious faith in you,” added the squire.
I began to feel pretty desperate at this, for I felt altogether helpless; and yet, by an odd train of circumstances, it was indeed through me that safety came. In the meantime, talk as we pleased, there were only seven out of the twenty-six on whom we knew we could rely; and out of these seven one was a boy, so that the grown men on our side were six to their nineteen.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Now, captain,” said the squire, “you were right, and I was wrong. I own myself an ass, and I await your orders.”
“It’s a pleasure to hear you say so, sir,” said Captain Smollett. “I expect I’ll have that pleasure often enough before all is done. I object, as I said, to this cruise altogether; I think it dangerous and foolhardy; a dam’ bad cruise, sir. But since you and the doctor are aboard of her, I’ll do my duty, and see you through it if I can. For that’s what I signed for, I’ll have you know. Well, now, look here. You and the doctor and I are patriotic Englishmen, I take it. We can stick together. Yonder are twenty supernumerary hands besides the officers and ship’s company. None of them are so much as English.
“Indeed not,” said the doctor. “For the most part, they are the very scum of the earth.”
“Well, then,” continued the captain, “there are the doctor, and you, and I, and Benjamin Gunn, a man who has been marooned for years, and is likely to be loyal. That makes five. Then there are your three servants, Redruth, Joyce, and Hunter. That makes eight. Now, I can’t answer for the men, but I believe we can count on these eight. The rest are the mutineers.”
“I see,” said the squire. “We are eight against nineteen. I should like to blow the ship up.”
“Well, sir,” said the captain, “the odds are heavy, to be sure. But we have the advantage of knowing, and they don’t know that we know. We have time before us, and they have none. They must find the treasure, and they must load it. For the matter of that, they may not find it. And if they do, it’s not easy to carry it aboard.”
“Right,” said the doctor. “We must bide our time.”
“Yes,” said Smollett, “we must bide our time, and take them when they least expect it. It will be a touch-and-go business, sir, but I’ll risk my neck for it, and so, I am sure, will the doctor and you. As for the boy, I don’t know that we can count on him.”
“Jim is as true as steel,” said the doctor. “He is the soul of honour, and brave as a lion. He is the best of us all.”
“Well,” said the captain, “I am glad to hear it. For we shall need all the help we can get. Now, sir, I have a plan. We must get the treasure aboard, and then we must sail away. But we must do it secretly, and we must do it quickly. For if they suspect, we are lost.”
“I see,” said the squire. “We must work like beavers.”
“Yes,” said the captain, “and we must be ready for anything. For they are a desperate crew, and they have a desperate leader. Long John Silver is a remarkable man.”
“He is indeed,” said the doctor. “I have never seen his like.”
“Nor I,” said the captain. “He is a man to be feared. But he is also a man to be admired. He is a great rogue, but he is a great man.”
“I agree,” said the squire. “I wish we had him on our side.”
“It is a pity,” said the captain. “But we must make the best of it. Now, sir, I have a proposal. We must land the treasure, and then we must make a stand. We must fortify ourselves, and we must defend ourselves. For they will attack us, and they will attack us fiercely.”
“I see,” said the doctor. “We must fight for our lives.”
“Yes,” said the captain, “and we must fight to the death. For there is no quarter to be given or taken. It is a war to the knife.”
“I am ready,” said the squire. “I will fight with you.”
“And I,” said the doctor. “We will stand together.”
“Good,” said the captain. “Then we are agreed. We will land the treasure, and we will make a stand. We will fortify ourselves, and we will defend ourselves. And we will fight to the death.”
“So be it,” said the squire.
“So be it,” said the doctor.
And so the council of war came to an end. We were seven against nineteen, and the odds were heavy. But we had hope, and we had courage. And we had a plan. It was a desperate plan, but it was our only hope. And as I lay in my bunk that night, I thought of the treasure, and I thought of the mutineers, and I thought of Long John Silver. And I wondered what the morrow would bring.

“Indeed not,” said the doctor. “For the most part, they are the very scum of the earth.”
“Well, then,” continued the captain, “there are the doctor, and you, and I, and Benjamin Gunn, a man who has been marooned for years, and is likely to be loyal. That makes five. “I see,” said the squire. “We must work like beavers.”
“Yes,” said the captain, “and we must be ready for anything. For they are a desperate crew, and they have a desperate leader. Long John Silver is a remarkable man.”
“He is indeed,” said the doctor. “I have never seen his like.”
“Nor I,” said the captain. “He is a man to be feared. But he is also a man to be admired. He is a great rogue, but he is a great man.”
“I agree,” said the squire. “I wish we had him on our side.”
“It is a pity,” said the captain. “But we must make the best of it. Now, sir, I have a proposal. We must land the treasure, and then we must make a stand. We must fortify ourselves, and we must defend ourselves. For they will attack us, and they will attack us fiercely.”

And I wondered what the morrow would bring.

chapters.chapter_title: XIII-How I Began My Shore Adventure

events.title: Island's Unsettling Appearance and Jim's Foreboding
detailed_summary: The island presented a drastically different and unsettling appearance when Jim came on deck in the morning.
Despite making considerable headway during the night, the Hispaniola was now becalmed about half a mile from the low eastern coast.
The island was largely covered in grey-coloured woods, giving it a sad and uniform tint, broken only by streaks of yellow sand and taller pine trees.
The hills rose as strangely shaped spires of bare rock, with the Spy-glass being the tallest and most unusually configured, resembling a pedestal.
The ship was rolling heavily in the ocean swell, with booms straining, the rudder banging, and the entire vessel creaking and groaning.
Jim, despite being a decent sailor when underway, felt seasick and dizzy from the stationary rolling, particularly on an empty stomach.
He attributed his sinking feeling not just to seasickness but also to the island's grey, melancholy woods, wild stone spires, and the thundering surf.
Despite the bright sun and active shore birds, which might normally be welcoming, Jim felt his heart sink and conceived an immediate, strong aversion to Treasure Island from his first sight of it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The appearance of the island when I came on deck next morning was altogether changed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and from the first look onward, I hated the very thought of Treasure Island.

events.text_segment:
The appearance of the island when I came on deck next morning was altogether changed. Although the breeze had now utterly ceased, we had made a great deal of way during the night and were now lying becalmed about half a mile to the south-east of the low eastern coast. Grey-coloured woods covered a large part of the surface. This even tint was indeed broken up by streaks of yellow sand-break in the lower lands, and by many tall trees of the pine family, out-topping the others—some singly, some in clumps; but the general colouring was uniform and sad. The hills ran up clear above the vegetation in spires of naked rock. All were strangely shaped, and the Spy-glass, which was by three or four hundred feet the tallest on the island, was likewise the strangest in configuration, running up sheer from almost every side and then suddenly cut off at the top like a pedestal to put a statue on.
The Hispaniola was rolling scuppers under in the ocean swell. The booms were tearing at the blocks, the rudder was banging to and fro, and the whole ship creaking, groaning, and jumping like a manufactory. I had to cling tight to the backstay, and the world turned giddily before my eyes, for though I was a good enough sailor when there was way on, this standing still and being rolled about like a bottle was a thing I never learned to stand without a qualm or so, above all in the morning, on an empty stomach.
Perhaps it was this—perhaps it was the look of the island, with its grey, melancholy woods, and wild stone spires, and the surf that we could both see and hear foaming and thundering on the steep beach—at least, although the sun shone bright and hot, and the shore birds were fishing and crying all around us, and you would have thought anyone would have been glad to get to land after being so long at sea, my heart sank, as the saying is, into my boots; and from the first look onward, I hated the very thought of Treasure Island.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The appearance of the island when I came on deck next morning was altogether changed. Although the breeze had now entirely died away, and we lay becalmed about half a mile to the south-east of the island, the current had carried us considerably north-west during the hours of darkness, and we were now opposite the middle of the eastern coast, and about half a mile away. The air was hot and close, and smelt of ague and decay—a sweetish, sickly smell, that was half pleasant, half repulsive to me. And in spite of the brightness of the sunshine and the blue of the sky, there was a haunting taint of death in the melancholy-looking woods, and the ragged moorlands, and the grey melancholy rocks, that all composed the face of that desolate island. I remember I was horribly depressed and seasick. I could have thought it was a nightmare. It is not (as I have since heard) a healthy place, and when the isle was at its prettiest, this eastern coast, where we were now lying, was the most abominable. A few miserable pines stood here and there among the scrubby woods; some tall, grey cliffs barricaded the interior; and all along the coast the surf broke in a thick white line, the sound of it continuing without interruption. The mail boat had passed us at daylight, bound for the south; and we had all been on deck to wave her good-bye, and cheer. We were now alone. I could see the Spy-glass, a tall peak, as sharp as a needle, and as white as snow, standing out above the green woods. It was the only landmark. All the rest was a confused mass of hills and valleys, of woods and rocks. And the whole island was covered with a greyish-green, or rather a greenish-grey, tint, that was at once sad and uniform. I felt my heart sink. I had a great aversion to the island, and the sight of it filled me with a sort of horror. I was not myself, I was seasick, and I had been up all night; but I am sure I should have felt the same, had I been in the best health. I had a sort of presentiment of evil.

events.title: Warping the Hispaniola and Silver's Navigational Skill
detailed_summary: A challenging morning's work awaited the crew due to the lack of wind, requiring the ship to be moved using boats.
The Hispaniola needed to be warped three or four miles around the island's corner and through a narrow passage to reach the haven behind Skeleton Island.
Jim volunteered to help in one of the boats, a task not typically his.
The heat was oppressive, and the men grumbled fiercely about their labor.
Anderson, in command of Jim's boat, complained as loudly as the others, ominously stating that their current hardship wouldn't last forever.
Jim perceived this remark and the general mood as a very negative indication that discipline, which had been good until then, was deteriorating due to the island's influence.
Throughout the maneuver, Long John Silver expertly directed the ship's course from beside the steersman.
He demonstrated an intimate knowledge of the passage, navigating with confidence even when soundings indicated more water than the chart showed.
Silver explained that a strong ebb tide had effectively deepened the passage over time.
The ship eventually anchored at the precise location indicated on the chart, about a third of a mile from both the mainland and Skeleton Island, over a clean sandy bottom.
The anchor's descent caused a flurry of birds to rise from the woods, but they soon settled, and silence returned to the anchorage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We had a dreary morning’s work before us, for there was no sign of any wind, and the boats had to be got out and manned, and the ship warped three or four miles round the corner of the island and up the narrow passage to the haven behind Skeleton Island.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The plunge of our anchor sent up clouds of birds wheeling and crying over the woods, but in less than a minute they were down again and all was once more silent.

events.text_segment:
We had a dreary morning’s work before us, for there was no sign of any wind, and the boats had to be got out and manned, and the ship warped three or four miles round the corner of the island and up the narrow passage to the haven behind Skeleton Island. I volunteered for one of the boats, where I had, of course, no business. The heat was sweltering, and the men grumbled fiercely over their work. Anderson was in command of my boat, and instead of keeping the crew in order, he grumbled as loud as the worst.
“Well,” he said with an oath, “it’s not forever.”
I thought this was a very bad sign, for up to that day the men had gone briskly and willingly about their business; but the very sight of the island had relaxed the cords of discipline.
All the way in, Long John stood by the steersman and conned the ship. He knew the passage like the palm of his hand, and though the man in the chains got everywhere more water than was down in the chart, John never hesitated once.
“There’s a strong scour with the ebb,” he said, “and this here passage has been dug out, in a manner of speaking, with a spade.”
We brought up just where the anchor was in the chart, about a third of a mile from each shore, the mainland on one side and Skeleton Island on the other. The bottom was clean sand. The plunge of our anchor sent up clouds of birds wheeling and crying over the woods, but in less than a minute they were down again and all was once more silent.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: We had a dreary morning’s work before us, for there was no sign of any wind, and the boats had to be got out and manned, and the ship warped three or four miles round the corner of the island and up the narrow passage to the haven behind Skeleton Island. I volunteered for one of the boats, where I not only pulled an oar, but got the chance of a good look at the coast. But after a bit I began to be sorry for my pains; the heat was sweltering, and the men grumbled fiercely over their labour. Anderson was in command of my boat, and he made no secret of his discontent. He said if ever he got ashore again, he should not be in so much hurry to get aboard ship. “It’s not the work that kills a man,” said he, “but the cussed heat. I’ve been close to a sunstroke already. If it ain’t soon over, I’ll tell you what it is, I’ll just go straight into the water and swim ashore. See if I don’t.” These were burning words, and the faces of the other men showed they sympathized. They were all overdone with heat and toil, and lacked spirit to answer or to rise even to such a menace as this. Long John Silver was the only man who cheered us. He sang an old sea-song with a piping voice, and now and again stopped to call an order or a piece of nautical advice to the steersman. The channels were very narrow, and required the most careful handling. Not only the steersman, but myself, and the coxswain of the pinnace, and other experienced seamen, were all kept upon the alert. Silver, with his long pale face and his cowl drawn forward on his head, was ever beside the steersman, and ever now and again gave an order which was obeyed instantly and with much care. His look was steady and fierce and his soul was manifestly labouring with impatience. Eight bells struck, it was noon, and the sun blazed overhead. We were now got far advanced in the passage, had passed the Skeleton Island, and were drawing near the place for anchoring. It was a large open bay, a few miles more in extent than the Spy-glass Hill, which had formed such a conspicuous object from the sea. The bottom was clean sand. The anchor was let go, and a great shudder ran through the vessel. Everything burst at once into a great clamour, the cable rumbled, the sails were furled, and the boats were hauled aboard. The birds flew up in a cloud from the woods, but in a moment or two they settled again, and the silence fell once more upon the anchorage.

events.title: Ominous Anchorage and Rising Mutiny
detailed_summary: The anchorage was completely enclosed by land, with dense woods reaching down to the high-water mark and mostly flat shores, while hills formed a sort of amphitheater in the distance.
Two small rivers, described more like swamps, emptied into this basin, and the foliage around that area had a disturbingly bright, potentially poisonous look.

From the ship, there was no sign of the house or stockade, as they were hidden among the trees; without the chart, they might have believed themselves the first to anchor there since the island's creation.
A profound stillness pervaded the air, disturbed only by the distant booming of the surf against the beaches and rocks.
A peculiar, stagnant smell of sodden leaves and rotting tree trunks hung over the anchorage.
Jim observed Doctor Livesey repeatedly sniffing the air, much like someone testing a bad egg.
The doctor stated he would wager his wig that there was fever on the island, regardless of any treasure.
The crew's conduct, already alarming in the boat, became overtly threatening once they were back aboard the ship.
They congregated on deck, muttering and growling amongst themselves.
The slightest order was met with hostile glares and was obeyed grudgingly and carelessly.
Even the usually honest hands seemed to have caught the rebellious mood, as no man attempted to correct another's behavior.
It was clear to Jim that mutiny was imminent, like a gathering thunder-cloud.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The place was entirely land-locked, buried in woods, the trees coming right down to high-water mark, the shores mostly flat, and the hilltops standing round at a distance in a sort of amphitheatre, one here, one there.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mutiny, it was plain, hung over us like a thunder-cloud.

events.text_segment:
The place was entirely land-locked, buried in woods, the trees coming right down to high-water mark, the shores mostly flat, and the hilltops standing round at a distance in a sort of amphitheatre, one here, one there. Two little rivers, or rather two swamps, emptied out into this pond, as you might call it; and the foliage round that part of the shore had a kind of poisonous brightness. From the ship we could see nothing of the house or stockade, for they were quite buried among trees; and if it had not been for the chart on the companion, we might have been the first that had ever anchored there since the island arose out of the seas.
There was not a breath of air moving, nor a sound but that of the surf booming half a mile away along the beaches and against the rocks outside. A peculiar stagnant smell hung over the anchorage—a smell of sodden leaves and rotting tree trunks. I observed the doctor sniffing and sniffing, like someone tasting a bad egg.
“I don’t know about treasure,” he said, “but I’ll stake my wig there’s fever here.”
If the conduct of the men had been alarming in the boat, it became truly threatening when they had come aboard. They lay about the deck growling together in talk. The slightest order was received with a black look and grudgingly and carelessly obeyed. Even the honest hands must have caught the infection, for there was not one man aboard to mend another. Mutiny, it was plain, hung over us like a thunder-cloud.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The place was entirely land-locked, buried in woods, the trees coming right down to high-water mark, the shores mostly flat, and the hilltops standing round at a distance in a sort of amphitheatre, one here, one there. Two rivers, or rather two swamps, emptied into this basin, the one to the southeast, the other to the south. And all round the basin the shores are low and marshy, and liable to floods. Upon the northwest, I saw two small hills, nothing but sand-hills in fact, and down behind them the masts and sails of a ship were just visible over the trees, not mine, I was sure. I knew that must be the schooner we had left anchored to the southwest. See, said I, they have changed their anchorage. Their captain is more careful than ours, and has got this birth to windward. By this time the jolly-boat was alongside, and we were all shaking hands with Captain Smollett, and the doctor, and the squire. What cheer, and what cheer, were exchanged, and Captain Smollett said we were just in time. For, said he, with one voice, they were all crying out for liberty, and to go ashore. I have tried to keep them back, but it is of no use. I am sure there is mischief brewing. They are all discontented, and I fear they will break out in open mutiny. I have been expecting you this hour back. I have had a boat out all the morning, but they could not find you. I am glad you are come. I have a great mind to give up the ship, and go home. I am sure there is something wrong. I have never seen the men so unruly. They are all ripe for mischief. I have no doubt they have been tampered with. I have been expecting this. I have had my eye upon them. I have seen them whispering together. I have seen them looking at the chart. I have seen them with their heads together. I have seen them with their hands together. I have seen them with their schemes together. I have seen them with their plots together. I have seen them with their conspiracies together. I have seen them with their treasons together. I have seen them with their murmurings together. I have seen them with their whisperings together. I have seen them with their mutterings together. I have seen them with their growlings together. I have seen them with their snarlings together. I have seen them with their barkings together. I have seen them with their howlings together. I have seen them with their yell

events.title: Silver's Alarming Charade of Loyalty
detailed_summary: The danger of the situation was apparent not only to the cabin party.
Long John Silver was conspicuously busy, moving from one group of men to another, ostensibly offering good advice and setting an example of perfect conduct.
He exaggerated his helpfulness and civility, bestowing smiles upon everyone.
If an order was given, Silver would immediately be on his crutch, responding with the most cheerful 'Aye, aye, sir!' imaginable.
When there were no specific tasks, he sang one song after another, as if trying to mask the crew's underlying discontent.
Jim found this overt display of anxiety from Long John to be the most disturbing feature of that gloomy afternoon.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Of all the gloomy features of that gloomy afternoon, this obvious anxiety on the part of Long John appeared the worst.

events.text_segment:
And it was not only we of the cabin party who perceived the danger. Long John was hard at work going from group to group, spending himself in good advice, and as for example no man could have shown a better. He fairly outstripped himself in willingness and civility; he was all smiles to everyone. If an order were given, John would be on his crutch in an instant, with the cheeriest “Aye, aye, sir!” in the world; and when there was nothing else to do, he kept up one song after another, as if to conceal the discontent of the rest.
Of all the gloomy features of that gloomy afternoon, this obvious anxiety on the part of Long John appeared the worst.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: And it was not only we of the cabin party who perceived the danger. Long John was hard at work going from group to group, now expostulating, now advising, now laughing with them and patting them on the back. From time to time he would hold forth in loud, clear tones. "Friends," he would say, "another cheer for the squire and the doctor!" or "Stand by to board her, mates!" or "All's well!" and other words of like effect. He would walk slowly to and fro, crutch under arm, with the bright face of a man who does his duty and begs everyone to be his fellow. If an order was given, you might be sure that Long John would be first to bow his head. If danger was to be faced, you might be sure Long John would be there, crutch and all, with the merriest word. In all the great miry tangle of the anchorage, whole ships went by it, nobody was so conspicuously active, nobody so ready to bow and scrape as Long John. And to him who had been the mainspring of the plot and the ringleader of the mutiny all this seemed just the one thing needful to complete his character. Though I had little time to think of him at the moment, I remember observing this much with pleasure. But the rest of the crew were not so ready. They hung about like sheep, or ran aimlessly here and there in a slovenly manner. They were not sailors, and they did not know their work. They were not pirates, and they did not dare to be idle. They were in a fix, to use the common phrase, and they did not know what to do. The captain and the squire were on the poop, and Jim Hawkins was on the forecastle. We could see the island clearly now, and the anchorage was in sight. The ship was being steered by the captain himself, and the squire was standing by him. The doctor was on the quarterdeck, and I was on the forecastle. The rest of the crew were scattered about the deck. Long John was everywhere, giving orders and setting an example. He was the only one who seemed to know what he was about. The others were like men in a dream. They were not mutineers, and they were not honest men. They were in a fix. events.title: Cabin Council and the Captain's Risky Strategy
detailed_summary: The leaders convened for a council in the ship's cabin.
Captain Smollett informed the Squire that giving another order would likely trigger an immediate mutiny.
He outlined their predicament: if he responded forcefully to insubordination, violence would erupt; if he didn't, Silver would perceive their weakness, and their authority would be lost.
The captain stated that Long John Silver was the only individual they could currently rely on to manage the crew.
He believed Silver was as anxious as they were to prevent an immediate confrontation, viewing the current unrest as a minor dispute that Silver could resolve if given the chance.
The captain proposed a strategy: to allow the men an afternoon ashore.

He explained the potential outcomes: if all the men went ashore, the cabin party could attempt to reclaim the ship; if none went, they would fortify the cabin and defend themselves; if only some went, he was confident Silver would ensure their peaceful return.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We held a council in the cabin.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If some go, you mark my words, sir, Silver’ll bring ’em aboard again as mild as lambs.”

events.text_segment:
We held a council in the cabin.
“Sir,” said the captain, “if I risk another order, the whole ship’ll come about our ears by the run. You see, sir, here it is. I get a rough answer, do I not? Well, if I speak back, pikes will be going in two shakes; if I don’t, Silver will see there’s something under that, and the game’s up. Now, we’ve only one man to rely on.”
“And who is that?” asked the squire.
“Silver, sir,” returned the captain; “he’s as anxious as you and I to smother things up. This is a tiff; he’d soon talk ’em out of it if he had the chance, and what I propose to do is to give him the chance. Let’s allow the men an afternoon ashore. If they all go, why we’ll fight the ship. If they none of them go, well then, we hold the cabin, and God defend the right. If some go, you mark my words, sir, Silver’ll bring ’em aboard again as mild as lambs.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: We held a council in the cabin. "Sir," said the captain, addressing the squire, who was by far the most greatly disturbed, "you and I are about as good as gone, I think, in this world. I do not know that I ever had a box into which I durst not dip my fingers; but I would not touch a penny of this money now. As for the schooner, it seems she is mine no longer, and I may go home when I please. Oh, sir," said he, "had you never given that coxswain the order to pull back to the ship, this disaster had never happened." "But who could dream they were such rogues?" cried the squire. "Come, squire," said the captain, "we'll be frank and above-board, every one of us. It's not the time for blaming any one. But as you say, who would have dreamt they were such rogues? If we get out of this alive, you may thank me. They have fooled me, I grant; but not so much as they have fooled you. I had suspicions, sir, I had suspicions; but pretty near all I have heard this afternoon confirms them. Silver's a very remarkable man, with a head on his shoulders. I should say that man Silver's a good half of my crew, and the whole of your danger." "Fancy!" cried the squire. "That is the worst news of all. That fellow Silver I mean to bring home to answer for this." "Well, well, sir," said the captain, "don't be too sure of that. He's by no means certain to come home at all, and if he does, it won't be in irons, you may be sure. He's a good man, Silver; a man you'd like to have by you in a brush." "The man's a villain," cried the squire. "No, no, sir," said the captain. "Let him alone for a bit; he's your best card for the moment, and we'll see. He's a man who'll pretty soon discover how he stands. I've a notion he'll be as anxious to get out of this scrape as you or I. You see, sir, he's a man of sense and education. Dr. Livesey, ever calm and practical, offered shrewd advice. And I, Jim Hawkins, sat listening, my heart pounding with a mixture of fear and excitement. The air was thick with the gravity of our situation. Silver's treachery was laid bare, the scale of the mutiny chillingly clear. We were outnumbered

events.title: Executing the Plan: Shore Leave and Tenuous Alliances
detailed_summary: The captain's plan to allow the men ashore was approved.
Loaded pistols were distributed to all the dependable members of their party.
Hunter, Joyce, and Redruth were brought into their confidence regarding the situation and the plan; they reacted with less surprise and greater resolve than had been anticipated.
The captain then went on deck and addressed the crew.
He announced that due to the hot day and general fatigue, anyone who wished could take the ship's gigs for an afternoon ashore, with a gun to be fired as a recall signal half an hour before sunset.
Jim surmised that the crew, in their naivety, must have imagined they would immediately find treasure upon landing.
Their sullenness vanished instantly, and they let out a cheer that echoed from a distant hill, once again disturbing the birds around the anchorage.
The captain, displaying his astuteness, quickly withdrew from sight, leaving Silver to organize the shore party, a decision Jim considered prudent.
Jim reflected that if the captain had remained on deck, he could no longer have feigned ignorance of the true state of affairs: Silver was effectively in command of a highly rebellious crew.

He pondered the nature of the 'honest hands' aboard, concluding they were either exceptionally dull or, more likely, that all crew members were disaffected by the ringleaders' influence to varying degrees, though only a few were good men at heart who couldn't be pushed further into outright villainy.
He acknowledged the significant difference between idleness and disobedience versus actively seizing a ship and murdering innocent people.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was so decided; loaded pistols were served out to all the sure men; Hunter, Joyce, and Redruth were taken into our confidence and received the news with less surprise and a better spirit than we had looked for, and then the captain went on deck and addressed the crew.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It is one thing to be idle and skulk and quite another to take a ship and murder a number of innocent men.

events.text_segment:
It was so decided; loaded pistols were served out to all the sure men; Hunter, Joyce, and Redruth were taken into our confidence and received the news with less surprise and a better spirit than we had looked for, and then the captain went on deck and addressed the crew.
“My lads,” said he, “we’ve had a hot day and are all tired and out of sorts. A turn ashore’ll hurt nobody—the boats are still in the water; you can take the gigs, and as many as please may go ashore for the afternoon. I’ll fire a gun half an hour before sundown.”
I believe the silly fellows must have thought they would break their shins over treasure as soon as they were landed, for they all came out of their sulks in a moment and gave a cheer that started the echo in a faraway hill and sent the birds once more flying and squalling round the anchorage.
The captain was too bright to be in the way. He whipped out of sight in a moment, leaving Silver to arrange the party, and I fancy it was as well he did so. Had he been on deck, he could no longer so much as have pretended not to understand the situation. It was as plain as day. Silver was the captain, and a mighty rebellious crew he had of it. The honest hands—and I was soon to see it proved that there were such on board—must have been very stupid fellows. Or rather, I suppose the truth was this, that all hands were disaffected by the example of the ringleaders—only some more, some less; and a few, being good fellows in the main, could neither be led nor driven any further. It is one thing to be idle and skulk and quite another to take a ship and murder a number of innocent men.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was so decided; loaded pistols were served out to all the sure men; Hunter, Joyce, and Redruth were taken into our confidence and received the news with less surprise and a better spirit than we had looked for, and then the captain went on deck and addressed the crew. "My lads," said he, "we've had a pretty hot day, and perhaps a pretty hard day, too. For my part, I was glad of a breath of air this morning; but I think there's not a man among you that (setting aside the little boat business) has worked harder or more handsomely than you have to-day. And as I understand there are some among you who like the shore, I propose, for the sake of your health, to let you have an afternoon ashore. You will take the gigs, and as many as please may go that wish to. The gun will be fired half an hour before sunset." The word was passed along my shipmates, and I promise you a cheer went up from them that made the hills ring. The cheer was not exactly musical, but it pleased us just as well. It was a sure sign of delight; and the young fellows, I thought, looked even more pleased than the old hands, and Gronge Merry was one of them. They seemed to think they were going to find treasure ashore, and I believe they would have been content to wait for it for a week. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It was so decided; loaded pistols were served out to all the sure men; Hunter, Joyce, and Redruth were taken into our confidence and received the news with less surprise and a better spirit than we had looked for, and then the captain went on deck and addressed the crew. He stood by the mainmast, a figure of quiet authority, his voice clear and steady in the morning air. He spoke of the long voyage nearing its end, of the island ahead, and of the work that lay before them in seeking the treasure. He laid down the law plainly: discipline must be maintained, orders obeyed without question, and any sign of insubordination would be met with swift and severe punishment. He did not mention the word 'mutiny,' but his eyes swept over the faces of the men, lingering perhaps a fraction longer on those he suspected. The crew listened, some with genuine attention, others with a forced air of innocence that was almost comical. Long John Silver, leaning against the bulwarks, wore a mask of perfect respectability, nodding occasionally as if in hearty agreement with the captain's words. The tension, though unspoken, was palpable to those of us in the know. Smollett finished his address, reiterating the importance of unity and hard work. The men dispersed to their duties, the air thick with unspoken suspicion. We knew the confrontation was inevitable, but for now, a fragile peace held. The island loomed larger on the horizon, a green and mysterious shape promising both immense wealth and deadly peril. We were sailing into the heart of danger, with enemies surrounding us even within the confines of our own ship.

events.title: Jim's Impulsive Escape Ashore
detailed_summary: Eventually, the shore party was formed, with six men designated to stay aboard the Hispaniola, while the remaining thirteen, Silver among them, prepared to embark.
At this point, Jim conceived the first of several impulsive ideas that would ultimately contribute significantly to saving their lives.
He reasoned that since Silver was leaving only six men on the ship, the cabin party could not successfully retake it at that moment.
Conversely, with only six adversaries remaining on board, the cabin party did not immediately require his assistance for their defense.
He instantly decided to go ashore himself.
In a swift movement, he slipped over the side of the Hispaniola and concealed himself in the fore-sheets of the nearest boat just as it was pushing off.
Most of the boat's occupants did not notice him, apart from the bow oarsman, who casually asked if it was Jim and told him to keep his head down.
However, Long John Silver, in the other boat, looked over sharply and called out, questioning if it was indeed Jim.
From that moment, Jim began to feel regret for his hasty decision.
The crews of both boats raced towards the beach.
The boat Jim was in, having a slight lead and being both lighter and better manned, quickly outpaced its companion.
As his boat's bow struck the shore among the trees, Jim seized a branch, swung himself out, and plunged into the nearest thicket, while Silver and the others were still a hundred yards behind.
He heard Silver shouting his name, "Jim, Jim!".
Jim, however, paid no attention, instead jumping, ducking, and forcing his way through the undergrowth, running straight ahead until he could run no more.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At last, however, the party was made up.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But you may suppose I paid no heed; jumping, ducking, and breaking through, I ran straight before my nose till I could run no longer.

events.text_segment:
At last, however, the party was made up. Six fellows were to stay on board, and the remaining thirteen, including Silver, began to embark.
Then it was that there came into my head the first of the mad notions that contributed so much to save our lives. If six men were left by Silver, it was plain our party could not take and fight the ship; and since only six were left, it was equally plain that the cabin party had no present need of my assistance. It occurred to me at once to go ashore. In a jiffy I had slipped over the side and curled up in the fore-sheets of the nearest boat, and almost at the same moment she shoved off.
No one took notice of me, only the bow oar saying, “Is that you, Jim? Keep your head down.” But Silver, from the other boat, looked sharply over and called out to know if that were me; and from that moment I began to regret what I had done.
The crews raced for the beach, but the boat I was in, having some start and being at once the lighter and the better manned, shot far ahead of her consort, and the bow had struck among the shore-side trees and I had caught a branch and swung myself out and plunged into the nearest thicket while Silver and the rest were still a hundred yards behind.
“Jim, Jim!” I heard him shouting.
But you may suppose I paid no heed; jumping, ducking, and breaking through, I ran straight before my nose till I could run no longer.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
At last, however, the party was made up. Six were to remain on board, and the stockade was to be garrisoned by the remaining thirteen. The six chosen for the ship's company were Redruth, the gamekeeper, Abraham Gray, a carpenter, and four of the hands besides Silver. The other hands were going ashore. 

As soon as they were told, this party went to the boats. That was the last I saw of the captain and Squire Trelawney until they were brought aboard again, but I must not anticipate. As for myself, I was thinking of nothing but to get ashore. 

Since they were so few aboard, I thought, the first thing they would do would be to get the guns ready and open fire at once upon the boats. If they did that, I thought, I had no business staying to be shot at. Nor, so long as I was there, could I be much help to the captain. And besides, to be quite frank, I was hankering to go ashore and see the island and tune up with the rest of them in the adventure. 

I was pulling on my boots and thought of nothing else. By the time I had them on, two of the boats were already manned and pushing off from the ship's side. One was the big yawl, and Silver himself was in the stern sheets, shaking his finger at the coxswain and giving him some last orders. The other was the jolly-boat, and it was almost due astern of her. At that second, with a sudden impulse, I slipped over the side and dropped in the stern sheets of the jolly-boat. 

Neither the coxswain nor the men aboard noticed me, and the boat was already moving. But Silver, in the yawl, caught sight of me and hailed me. 

"Who's that?" he cried. "That's Jim Hawkins, ain't it? Jim, you boy, you stand by to come aboard again." 

I paid no heed to him. I was already regretting my haste, but I was in for it now, and I resolved to see it through. 

The two boats raced for the shore. The jolly-boat, being lighter and better manned, had a slight lead. As her bow struck the sand, I caught a branch of a tree, swung myself out, and plunged into the nearest thicket. I heard Silver shouting my name, "Jim, Jim!" but I paid no attention. I was running, jumping, and forcing my way through the undergrowth, running straight ahead until I could run no more.
