events.title: Jim Hawkins' Miraculous and Unexpected Return
detailed_summary: A shout is heard from the landward side of the stockade.
Hunter, who is on guard duty, announces that someone is hailing them.
The cries are recognized as belonging to Jim Hawkins, calling out to Dr. Livesey, the Squire, the Captain, and Hunter.
Dr. Livesey rushes to the stockade entrance just in time to witness Jim Hawkins, alive and well, climbing over the defensive wall.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A hail on the land side.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And I ran to the door in time to see Jim Hawkins, safe and sound, come climbing over the stockade.

events.text_segment:
A hail on the land side.
“Somebody hailing us,” said Hunter, who was on guard.
“Doctor! Squire! Captain! Hullo, Hunter, is that you?” came the cries.
And I ran to the door in time to see Jim Hawkins, safe and sound, come climbing over the stockade.

'Somebody hailing us,' said Hunter, who was on guard.

'Doctor! Squire! Captain! Hunter! Hollo, Hunter, is that you?' came the cries.

'Here I am,' sung out Hunter.

And I, who had just come out of the log-house, hurrying to the gate, heard Jim Hawkins' voice and saw Jim Hawkins himself, just passing the corner of the stockade and clambering over the wall.

chapters.chapter_title: XIX-Narrative Resumed by Jim Hawkins: The Garrison in the Stockade

events.title: Ben Gunn's Counsel and Conditions
detailed_summary: Upon seeing the flag flown at the stockade, Ben Gunn stops Jim, believing it to be Jim's friends rather than the mutineers.
He reasons that Silver, if in control, would display the Jolly Roger.
Ben Gunn praises the deceased pirate Flint's intellect, noting that only Silver, due to his genteel nature, was someone Flint was wary of, aside from rum.
While Jim is eager to rejoin his party, Ben Gunn cautions him, emphasizing Jim's youth and his own cunning.
He states he will not approach the stockade until he can speak directly with one of Jim's gentlemen companions and receive their word of honor, particularly due to the presence of rum.
Ben Gunn entrusts Jim with specific phrases to deliver: "A precious sight (that’s what you’ll say), a precious sight more confidence" and to explain that "Ben Gunn has reasons of his own."
He instructs Jim that he can be found in the same location where they met, between noon and six bells, and that anyone seeking him must come alone, holding a white object.
Anxiously, Ben Gunn makes Jim promise not to reveal his whereabouts to Silver and cryptically warns of fatal consequences for any pirates who might camp ashore.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As soon as Ben Gunn saw the colours he came to a halt, stopped me by the arm, and sat down.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And if them pirates camp ashore, Jim, what would you say but there’d be widders in the morning?”

events.text_segment:
As soon as Ben Gunn saw the colours he came to a halt, stopped me by the arm, and sat down.
“Now,” said he, “there’s your friends, sure enough.”
“Far more likely it’s the mutineers,” I answered.
“That!” he cried. “Why, in a place like this, where nobody puts in but gen’lemen of fortune, Silver would fly the Jolly Roger, you don’t make no doubt of that. No, that’s your friends. There’s been blows too, and I reckon your friends has had the best of it; and here they are ashore in the old stockade, as was made years and years ago by Flint. Ah, he was the man to have a headpiece, was Flint! Barring rum, his match were never seen. He were afraid of none, not he; on’y Silver—Silver was that genteel.”
“Well,” said I, “that may be so, and so be it; all the more reason that I should hurry on and join my friends.”
“Nay, mate,” returned Ben, “not you. You’re a good boy, or I’m mistook; but you’re on’y a boy, all told. Now, Ben Gunn is fly. Rum wouldn’t bring me there, where you’re going—not rum wouldn’t, till I see your born gen’leman and gets it on his word of honour. And you won’t forget my words; ‘A precious sight (that’s what you’ll say), a precious sight more confidence’—and then nips him.”
And he pinched me the third time with the same air of cleverness.
“And when Ben Gunn is wanted, you know where to find him, Jim. Just wheer you found him today. And him that comes is to have a white thing in his hand, and he’s to come alone. Oh! And you’ll say this: ‘Ben Gunn,’ says you, ‘has reasons of his own.’”
“Well,” said I, “I believe I understand. You have something to propose, and you wish to see the squire or the doctor, and you’re to be found where I found you. Is that all?”
“And when? says you,” he added. “Why, from about noon observation to about six bells.”
“Good,” said I, “and now may I go?”
“You won’t forget?” he inquired anxiously. “Precious sight, and reasons of his own, says you. Reasons of his own; that’s the mainstay; as between man and man. Well, then”—still holding me—“I reckon you can go, Jim. And, Jim, if you was to see Silver, you wouldn’t go for to sell Ben Gunn? Wild horses wouldn’t draw it from you? No, says you. And if them pirates camp ashore, Jim, what would you say but there’d be widders in the morning?”

But look here; would Silver a-run up the Jolly Roger, eh? No, not he. He wouldn't dare, mate. And besides, look at that house. That's not the like of anything that they had the wit to build. That's the house of gentlemen. Blame my eyes, Mr. Hawkins, if I haven't said the same to myself a hundred times since Sunday, and if I haven't given it up as impossible. But see now!" He had jumbled two things together; the sight of the colours and the thought of the house; and his head was so red-hot with hopes and fears that he won't scarce understand me when I told him I had seen the stockade long before and knew it was there. He had jumbled two things together; the sight of the colours and the thought of the house; and his head was so red-hot with hopes and fears that he won't scarce understand me when I told him I had seen the stockade long before and knew it was there. He was all in a tremble to go on. "Hold up!" said I. "Don't you see it's not safe? They might shoot you from behind a tree." "No," said he, "no fear of that. They'd be glad to see me, Ben Gunn is he that's come for to save his old companions." "Them that killed the others?" I asked. "Yes, mate," said he. "Those are the fellows. I thought they had been gone years ago. Oh, Lord, how glad I am!" "They are not your friends," said I; "they are Silver and the mutineers that you were so afraid of." He considered a moment. "O' course," said he. "It's God's truth. I was thinking of the others. The pirates!" He cried, and seemed to lose all presence of mind. events.title: Cannonade Interruption and Jim's Evasion
detailed_summary: Ben Gunn's conversation with Jim is abruptly cut short by the sound of a cannon firing and a cannonball landing perilously close.
In response to the immediate danger, both Jim and Ben Gunn instantly flee in separate directions.
For approximately an hour, the island is subjected to frequent cannon fire, with projectiles crashing through the forest.
Jim moves from one hiding spot to another, feeling constantly targeted by the terrifying bombardment.
As the cannonade eventually lessens, Jim begins to regain his composure, though he still avoids heading towards the stockade, which appeared to be the primary target.
He takes a lengthy detour eastward, eventually making his way down towards the trees along the shore.

The narrative describes the setting: the sun had dipped below the horizon, a sea breeze was active in the woods and on the water, the tide was out exposing large sandy areas, and the evening air felt cool after the day's warmth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Here he was interrupted by a loud report, and a cannonball came tearing through the trees and pitched in the sand not a hundred yards from where we two were talking.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The sun had just set, the sea breeze was rustling and tumbling in the woods and ruffling the grey surface of the anchorage; the tide, too, was far out, and great tracts of sand lay uncovered; the air, after the heat of the day, chilled me through my jacket.

events.text_segment:
Here he was interrupted by a loud report, and a cannonball came tearing through the trees and pitched in the sand not a hundred yards from where we two were talking. The next moment each of us had taken to his heels in a different direction.
For a good hour to come frequent reports shook the island, and balls kept crashing through the woods. I moved from hiding-place to hiding-place, always pursued, or so it seemed to me, by these terrifying missiles. But towards the end of the bombardment, though still I durst not venture in the direction of the stockade, where the balls fell oftenest, I had begun, in a manner, to pluck up my heart again, and after a long detour to the east, crept down among the shore-side trees.
The sun had just set, the sea breeze was rustling and tumbling in the woods and ruffling the grey surface of the anchorage; the tide, too, was far out, and great tracts of sand lay uncovered; the air, after the heat of the day, chilled me through my jacket.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Here he was interrupted by a loud report, and a cannonball came tearing through the trees and pitched in the sand not a hundred yards from where we two were talking.  'Ah!' cried Ben Gunn, 'the schooner's doglegged. See what I told you.'  And he sprang to his feet, and instantly after we were both scrambling away in different directions.  Soon I lost sight of my friend, and thought no more of him for the moment. The bombardment lasted long. It might have been a good hour, during a great part of which I lay under the shelter of a rock, or in a dense thicket, listening to the rattle of the grape, and the crash of the cannonballs among the wood.  When I was weary of waiting, and the fire seemed to slacken, I began to move again, and was now thinking of getting back to the stockade. I was not a little surprised when I came to the edge of the wood, and saw that all three of the boats were gone from the beach, and the schooner under way. I instantly understood what had happened. The pirates, in spite of their losses and so many wounded, had determined to strike that night; and if I were to judge by the frequency of the cannon shots, they had thought to knock the stockade about our ears, and come in unopposed. I did not wish to come to the stockade, of which I supposed they were now masters, and I began to move again with the greatest care, and keeping always in the thickest part of the wood. I was not long of finding a good hiding-place, where I lay till the sun went down. The sun, to my great joy, was already below the horizon, and the sea-breeze was beginning to blow in the woods and on the water. events.title: Observation of Mutineers and Discovery of White Rock
detailed_summary: Jim observes the Hispaniola at anchor, now clearly flying the Jolly Roger, the pirates' black flag.
Another cannon shot flashes and resounds from the ship, which turns out to be the final one of the bombardment.
Jim takes some time to watch the activity that follows the cessation of the attack.
He sees men on the beach near the stockade using axes to destroy something, which he later learns was the jolly-boat.

Further away, near the river's mouth, a large fire glows, and one of the ship's gigs is seen moving back and forth between the fire and the Hispaniola, with the men aboard shouting in a manner that suggests they have been drinking rum.
Feeling it might be safe, Jim considers returning to the stockade.
Positioned on a low, sandy spit of land, he spots a distinctive, high, white rock rising from some low bushes further down the spit.
He realizes this might be the white rock Ben Gunn had mentioned, potentially indicating the location of a hidden boat, a useful piece of information for the future.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Hispaniola still lay where she had anchored; but, sure enough, there was the Jolly Roger—the black flag of piracy—flying from her peak.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It occurred to me that this might be the white rock of which Ben Gunn had spoken and that some day or other a boat might be wanted and I should know where to look for one.

events.text_segment:
The Hispaniola still lay where she had anchored; but, sure enough, there was the Jolly Roger—the black flag of piracy—flying from her peak. Even as I looked, there came another red flash and another report that sent the echoes clattering, and one more round-shot whistled through the air. It was the last of the cannonade.
I lay for some time watching the bustle which succeeded the attack. Men were demolishing something with axes on the beach near the stockade—the poor jolly-boat, I afterwards discovered. Away, near the mouth of the river, a great fire was glowing among the trees, and between that point and the ship one of the gigs kept coming and going, the men, whom I had seen so gloomy, shouting at the oars like children. But there was a sound in their voices which suggested rum.
At length I thought I might return towards the stockade. I was pretty far down on the low, sandy spit that encloses the anchorage to the east, and is joined at half-water to Skeleton Island; and now, as I rose to my feet, I saw, some distance further down the spit and rising from among low bushes, an isolated rock, pretty high, and peculiarly white in colour. It occurred to me that this might be the white rock of which Ben Gunn had spoken and that some day or other a boat might be wanted and I should know where to look for one.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Hispaniola still lay where she had anchored; but, sure enough, there was the Jolly Roger—the black flag of piracy—flying from her peak. It was not slung like a flag, but hoisted up and spread out in its own folds as though to be seen from a distance; and at that same moment, with a loud report, the cannon flashed, and the ball flew clean over the stockade and fell somewhere far away in the wood. "Over," said I to myself. And with that, the cannon of the Hispaniola ceased from firing, and the attack was over. But the attack was not all. About the middle of the afternoon I could hear great outbursts of cheering from the ship's company, and presently I could see men going to and fro in the boats, and carrying ashore what I supposed to be provisions and ammunition. And at last, about sundown, when I was beginning to think of getting back into the stockade, I saw the jolly-boat shoved off from her moorings and sail slowly for the mouth of the river, and presently, with a loud splash, she sank. All at the same time, too, there came from the shore a sound of many voices singing, and when I looked that way, there was a great fire glowing on the beach, and round it a crowd of men, and the gig with the two oarsmen that I had seen before was pulling to and fro between the Hispaniola and the shore. For the most part, the men were singing sea songs; but now and again, one different from the rest would break out, and I could hear the name of Flint repeatedly mentioned, and the name of the "Walrus" as often, with a great deal of cursing. I could tell, too, that good deal of rum was being drunk; and I thought it was to that I owed the singing and the cursing. It was lucky for me that I was not then a little nearer, but I had given them a wide berth, and was content to sit hidden, and to watch them, and to wonder what they were at. Presently I began to think of my own affairs. I had been all day in the marshes, in company with the mosquitoes and the crabs. My clothes were torn, my skin was scratched, and I felt drowsy almost to death. I determined to get back to the stockade at once, and not to wait till dark. I was about to rise and set off, but I abstained at the sight of a large white rock which lay a little below me, and which I had not till that moment observed. It lay by itself, and was so conspicuous that I could not choose but wonder how I came to overlook it. It was like a block of marble, and it rose from the sand to the height of about twenty feet. "I declare," I said, "that must be the white rock that Ben Gunn spoke of!" In the same instant I remembered the words of the maroon: "Look here, Jim," he had said, "here's a thing that you'll soon understand, if you keep your eyes open and don't hurry your head. Ben Gunn's boat is there, but it's not what you would call a boat. It's a thing that he made himself, and it's big enough to hold a man, and it's light enough to carry. And it's hidden in the sand, and it's marked by a white rock." So that was the white rock! And it was there that Ben Gunn had hidden his boat—a thing that might be useful to me by and by.

events.title: Reunion at the Stockade and Description of the Fortification
detailed_summary: Jim cautiously makes his way through the woods to the shoreward side of the stockade, where he is greeted warmly by his loyal companions.
He quickly shares his recent adventures and then takes in his surroundings.
The log-house is constructed from rough, unsquared pine trunks for its roof, walls, and floor, with the floor raised a foot to a foot and a half above the sandy ground.

A porch is situated at the entrance, beneath which a small spring provides fresh water, channeled into an improvised basin made from a large ship’s iron kettle with its bottom removed and sunk into the sand.
Little remains of the original house structure beyond its basic framework; however, a stone slab serves as a hearth in one corner, accompanied by an old, rusty iron basket for holding the fire.
The knoll's slopes and the entire area within the stockade have been cleared of timber to build the house, the remaining stumps indicating the destruction of a once fine and tall grove of trees.
Much of the topsoil has eroded or been buried by drifting sand following the tree removal, though a patch of moss, ferns, and small bushes remains green where the streamlet from the kettle runs.
Dense woods still stand very close to the stockade, which is considered a defensive liability, consisting mainly of fir trees on the landward side and a mix including live-oaks towards the sea.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then I skirted among the woods until I had regained the rear, or shoreward side, of the stockade, and was soon warmly welcomed by the faithful party.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Very close around the stockade—too close for defence, they said—the wood still flourished high and dense, all of fir on the land side, but towards the sea with a large admixture of live-oaks.

events.text_segment:
Then I skirted among the woods until I had regained the rear, or shoreward side, of the stockade, and was soon warmly welcomed by the faithful party.
I had soon told my story and began to look about me. The log-house was made of unsquared trunks of pine—roof, walls, and floor. The latter stood in several places as much as a foot or a foot and a half above the surface of the sand. There was a porch at the door, and under this porch the little spring welled up into an artificial basin of a rather odd kind—no other than a great ship’s kettle of iron, with the bottom knocked out, and sunk “to her bearings,” as the captain said, among the sand.
Little had been left besides the framework of the house, but in one corner there was a stone slab laid down by way of hearth and an old rusty iron basket to contain the fire.
The slopes of the knoll and all the inside of the stockade had been cleared of timber to build the house, and we could see by the stumps what a fine and lofty grove had been destroyed. Most of the soil had been washed away or buried in drift after the removal of the trees; only where the streamlet ran down from the kettle a thick bed of moss and some ferns and little creeping bushes were still green among the sand. Very close around the stockade—too close for defence, they said—the wood still flourished high and dense, all of fir on the land side, but towards the sea with a large admixture of live-oaks.

I quickly recounted my adventures: the cutting adrift of the Hispaniola, the terrible fight with Israel Hands, and the final grounding of the schooner in the North Inlet. They listened with breathless attention, interrupting only with exclamations of wonder and horror. The news of the ship's recovery, albeit grounded, brought a flicker of hope, though the loss of Hands and the continued presence of the remaining mutineers outside the stockade kept spirits low. We were few, and our provisions were dwindling. The pirates, though reduced in number, still held the advantage of mobility and knowledge of the island. We discussed our situation, the Doctor pointing out that while the ship was secured, getting to her and making her seaworthy was a formidable task, especially with the enemy lurking. For now, our best course was to remain within the stockade, conserve our strength and supplies, and hope that either the pirates would make a mistake or that some unforeseen chance might favour us. The night was drawing in, and the forest around us seemed to hold its breath, full of unseen dangers. We posted our watches and settled down, the relief of my return mingled with the ever-present anxiety of our precarious position.

events.title: Harsh Conditions and Smollett's Order in the Stockade
detailed_summary: A cold evening breeze permeates the crudely built log-house through numerous gaps, constantly dusting the interior with fine sand.
Sand becomes a pervasive nuisance, getting into their eyes, teeth, food, and even the spring water, which appears to churn like boiling porridge.
The chimney, merely a square opening in the roof, fails to draw out most of the smoke, leaving the house filled with it and causing constant coughing and eye irritation.
Adding to the grim atmosphere, Gray, a recent loyalist, has his face bandaged due to an injury from his escape from the mutineers.
The unburied body of Tom Redruth lies stiffly along a wall, covered by the Union Jack.
Captain Smollett, determined to prevent idleness and despair, calls all hands and divides them into two watches for guard duty.
Doctor Livesey, Gray, and Jim form one watch, while the squire, Hunter, and Joyce constitute the other.
Despite widespread exhaustion, tasks are assigned: two men are sent for firewood, two to dig a grave for Redruth, the doctor is appointed cook, and Jim is posted as sentry at the door.
Captain Smollett moves among the group, offering encouragement and assistance wherever needed.
The doctor periodically steps outside for fresh air, his eyes heavily affected by the smoke, and on these occasions, he exchanges a few words with Jim.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The cold evening breeze, of which I have spoken, whistled through every chink of the rude building and sprinkled the floor with a continual rain of fine sand.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: From time to time the doctor came to the door for a little air and to rest his eyes, which were almost smoked out of his head, and whenever he did so, he had a word for me.

events.text_segment:
The cold evening breeze, of which I have spoken, whistled through every chink of the rude building and sprinkled the floor with a continual rain of fine sand. There was sand in our eyes, sand in our teeth, sand in our suppers, sand dancing in the spring at the bottom of the kettle, for all the world like porridge beginning to boil. Our chimney was a square hole in the roof; it was but a little part of the smoke that found its way out, and the rest eddied about the house and kept us coughing and piping the eye.
Add to this that Gray, the new man, had his face tied up in a bandage for a cut he had got in breaking away from the mutineers and that poor old Tom Redruth, still unburied, lay along the wall, stiff and stark, under the Union Jack.
If we had been allowed to sit idle, we should all have fallen in the blues, but Captain Smollett was never the man for that. All hands were called up before him, and he divided us into watches. The doctor and Gray and I for one; the squire, Hunter, and Joyce upon the other. Tired though we all were, two were sent out for firewood; two more were set to dig a grave for Redruth; the doctor was named cook; I was put sentry at the door; and the captain himself went from one to another, keeping up our spirits and lending a hand wherever it was wanted.
From time to time the doctor came to the door for a little air and to rest his eyes, which were almost smoked out of his head, and whenever he did so, he had a word for me.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The cold evening breeze, of which I have spoken, whistled through every chink of the rude building and sprinkled the floor with a continual rain of fine sand. There was sand in our eyes, sand in our teeth, sand in our dinner, sand in our spring water, sand on our beds, sand in our clothes, to say nothing of the great sand-heap that had spread itself about the house and was now only kept out by the men standing guard at the door. No fire was lit, for we feared to attract attention, and I was quite chilled with the evening air, and wet with the dew, besides smarting from my cut hand. The chimney was an open hole in the roof; it was not properly constructed, and there was no draught. The smoke hung in the house and smarted our eyes. I was so used to it, however, that I hardly noticed it. Gray was sitting by the fire, his face bandaged; he had been hurt in the escape. Tom Redruth lay stiff and stark along the wall, his face covered with the Union Jack. Captain Smollett, ever on the alert, called all hands and divided them into two watches. Dr. Livesey, Gray, and I were in one watch; the squire, Hunter, and Joyce were in the other. We were all tired, but we had to work. Two men were sent for firewood, two to dig a grave for Redruth, the doctor was appointed cook, and I was posted as sentry at the door. Captain Smollett went about among us, encouraging us and helping us. The doctor, from time to time, stepped out for a breath of fresh air, his eyes smarting dreadfully from the smoke, and on these occasions he would exchange a word or two with me.

events.title: Doctor Livesey's Commendation and Ben Gunn Inquiry
detailed_summary: During one of his breaks for fresh air, Doctor Livesey tells Jim that he considers Captain Smollett a better man than himself, a statement he emphasizes as carrying significant weight.
On another occasion, after a period of silence, the doctor inquires about Ben Gunn, asking Jim if he is indeed a man.
Jim expresses his uncertainty, particularly regarding Ben Gunn's sanity.

The doctor opines that any doubt about his humanity, given his circumstances, confirms he is a man, as three years of isolation on a deserted island would understandably affect anyone's apparent sanity.
He then recalls Jim mentioning Ben Gunn's fondness for cheese.

Revealing a personal quirk, the doctor explains that he carries a piece of Parmesan cheese in his snuff-box instead of snuff, and declares that this very cheese is destined for Ben Gunn, illustrating an unexpected benefit of his particular habits.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “That man Smollett,” he said once, “is a better man than I am.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Well, that’s for Ben Gunn!”

events.text_segment:
“That man Smollett,” he said once, “is a better man than I am. And when I say that it means a deal, Jim.”
Another time he came and was silent for a while. Then he put his head on one side, and looked at me.
“Is this Ben Gunn a man?” he asked.
“I do not know, sir,” said I. “I am not very sure whether he’s sane.”
“If there’s any doubt about the matter, he is,” returned the doctor. “A man who has been three years biting his nails on a desert island, Jim, can’t expect to appear as sane as you or me. It doesn’t lie in human nature. Was it cheese you said he had a fancy for?”
“Yes, sir, cheese,” I answered.
“Well, Jim,” says he, “just see the good that comes of being dainty in your food. You’ve seen my snuff-box, haven’t you? And you never saw me take snuff, the reason being that in my snuff-box I carry a piece of Parmesan cheese—a cheese made in Italy, very nutritious. Well, that’s for Ben Gunn!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
That man Smollett,” he said once, “is a better man than I am. And when I say that it means a great deal, Jim.”

In the course of the same walk he stopped suddenly, and laid his hand upon my shoulder.

“And now, Jim,” said he, “that we are alone, will you tell me about this Ben Gunn?”

I told him the whole particulars, showing but little favour to the island man, for even with Dr. Livesey I felt something of my old repugnance.

“Well,” said he, “that man is not sane, Jim.”

“I should think not,” I returned.

“He’s no doubt alive,” said the doctor. “There’s not a doubt about that; but do you think his head is quite right? Five minutes ago you called him a man, and now you deny his sanity. The truth is, Jim, these岛屿 men, they get peculiar. But I was sure of him. The question is, are we to use him? And if so, how? I told you, you were the man to help us, Jim. What do you think?”

I could think of nothing but the cheese. “Well, sir,” said I, “Ben Gunn is a man of his word. He said he would help us, and I believe him. And he is very fond of cheese, sir.”

“Fond of cheese!” cried the doctor. “Ay, but that’s not the point. The point is, can he help us?”

“I think he can, sir,” said I. “He knows the island well, and he is not afraid of the pirates.”

“Not afraid of the pirates!” cried the doctor. “Why, he is afraid of his own shadow! But never mind that. Fond of cheese, you say? Well, Jim, I have a piece of Parmesan cheese that I brought aboard for a special purpose. It’s in my snuff-box, and I’ve had it there these six years. It was destined for Ben Gunn, Jim, the very cheese. You see, I am not a man of snuff, Jim, but I am a man of cheese. And this cheese, Jim, is for Ben Gunn.”

events.title: Tom Redruth's Burial, War Council, and Strategic Outlook
detailed_summary: Prior to their evening meal, the group buries Tom Redruth in the sand, standing bare-headed in the breeze to pay their respects.
Captain Smollett expresses dissatisfaction with the amount of firewood collected, indicating they will need to gather more vigorously the following day.
After eating pork and drinking brandy grog, the three leaders—Captain Smollett, Doctor Livesey, and Squire Trelawney—convene to discuss their precarious situation.
They acknowledge that their provisions are so low they risk starvation long before any rescue could arrive.
Their agreed-upon strategy is to persistently attack and reduce the number of buccaneers until the mutineers either surrender or flee with the Hispaniola.
They calculate the mutineers' strength has diminished from nineteen to fifteen, with two others wounded, and one potentially fatally so.
The plan is to engage the enemy at every opportunity, while taking extreme care to preserve their own lives.
They identify two significant, albeit unconventional, allies: the pirates' penchant for rum, evident from their audible revelry, and the island's climate.
The doctor confidently predicts that the mutineers, camped in a marshy area without medical supplies, will suffer significant illness, with half of them likely incapacitated within a week.
He concludes that if the loyal party is not defeated first, the mutineers will eventually be eager to depart on the schooner to resume their piratical activities.
Captain Smollett poignantly remarks that the Hispaniola is the first ship he has ever lost.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Before supper was eaten we buried old Tom in the sand and stood round him for a while bare-headed in the breeze.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “First ship that ever I lost,” said Captain Smollett.

events.text_segment:
Before supper was eaten we buried old Tom in the sand and stood round him for a while bare-headed in the breeze. A good deal of firewood had been got in, but not enough for the captain’s fancy, and he shook his head over it and told us we “must get back to this tomorrow rather livelier.” Then, when we had eaten our pork and each had a good stiff glass of brandy grog, the three chiefs got together in a corner to discuss our prospects.
It appears they were at their wits’ end what to do, the stores being so low that we must have been starved into surrender long before help came. But our best hope, it was decided, was to kill off the buccaneers until they either hauled down their flag or ran away with the Hispaniola. From nineteen they were already reduced to fifteen, two others were wounded, and one at least—the man shot beside the gun—severely wounded, if he were not dead. Every time we had a crack at them, we were to take it, saving our own lives, with the extremest care. And besides that, we had two able allies—rum and the climate.
As for the first, though we were about half a mile away, we could hear them roaring and singing late into the night; and as for the second, the doctor staked his wig that, camped where they were in the marsh and unprovided with remedies, the half of them would be on their backs before a week.
“So,” he added, “if we are not all shot down first they’ll be glad to be packing in the schooner. It’s always a ship, and they can get to buccaneering again, I suppose.”
“First ship that ever I lost,” said Captain Smollett.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Before supper was eaten we buried old Tom in the sand and stood round him for a while bare-headed in the breeze. A good deal of firewood had been collected, and the fire was kept brightly going, but the Captain was dissatisfied with the quantity, and told us all that we must be more diligent next day. Then we fell to supper, and ate heartily, no wise disturbed by the firing that still went on intermittently among the trees overhead. For the pirates were evidently making merry, drinking rum, and firing guns for pleasure. There was no doubt of that, we could hear them singing. And the singing, I will say, was not a little cheery to hear, for though we had every cause to dread them, our hearts were lightened by the thought of all the rum they had, and the number of delirious drunkards that we might expect to find among them next morning. But that was not all that we had to look forward to. A great deal of our provisions was lost or damaged, and what remained would not much more than, if it went to the worst, keep us alive for ten days. The great majority of the buccaneers were now ashore. The Captain reckoned they were fifteen, pirates and seamen, and all told; but he allowed not above ten to be effective. And that being so, he thought it would be an easy matter to drive them into the boats and sink the Hispaniola. We were, on the other hand, six all told, and one of us wounded, and another sick. So you see we were not very strong. "Well," said the Captain, "we must just do the best we can. We have a good stockade here, and a good supply of powder and ball. We have a good doctor, and a good squire. We have a good ship's company, and a good ship. We have everything but time and provisions. And as for time, we must just make the best of it. We must not be in a hurry. We must not be in a hurry to fight. We must not be in a hurry to die. We must just take things as they come, and hope for the best." "And as for provisions," said the Doctor, "we must just make the best of them. We have enough for ten days, and that is a great deal. We must not be in a hurry to eat. We must not be in a hurry to drink. We must just take things as they come, and hope for the best." "And as for the ship," said the Squire, "we must just make the best of her. simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: Before supper was eaten we buried old Tom in the sand and stood round him for a while bare-headed in the breeze. A good deal of firewood had been collected, but not enough, the Captain said; and we were told to get more next day. Then we fell to supper, and ate heartily, though the fire was not great. Afterwards, when we had drunk a little brandy grog, the three chiefs got together in a corner to discuss our prospects. It appeared to me that they were all pretty low. The buccaneers had couped us up into a corner of the island, as they had desired to do; and where our provisions were so low that it was a question whether we should not starve long before they thought of giving in. Our only hope, it appeared, was to attack them at once, and reduce their numbers, so that they might be glad to surrender or else flee with the Hispaniola. From nineteen they were now reduced to fifteen, two of whom were wounded, and one, we had reason to believe, fatally. Six were we—stockade, ship's company, and all—two of us wounded, and one sick. So you see we were not very strong; but the Captain said we were enough to fight, and we must fight. We must take the offensive, he said. It was no use waiting to be attacked. We must attack them, and keep attacking them, until they were all killed or driven away. We must be very careful, he said, and not expose ourselves unnecessarily. We must take every advantage of the ground and the stockade. We must be very watchful, and not be surprised. We must be very patient, and not be in a hurry. We must be very determined, and not give up. We had two allies, he said—rum and the climate. It was probable that the buccaneers, living in the marsh and drinking rum, would be down with fever in a week or two. The doctor said he was sure of it. Half of them, he said, would be down in a week. And then, if we were not all killed, we should be able to do something. The Captain said it was the first ship he had ever lost.

events.title: Silver's Unexpected Arrival Under a Flag of Truce
detailed_summary: Jim, utterly exhausted, struggles to fall asleep but eventually succumbs to a deep slumber after much restlessness.
He is awakened later by a bustle of activity and the sound of voices, finding that the rest of the group had been up for some time, had breakfasted, and added to the firewood pile.
He hears someone announce the arrival of a "Flag of truce."
This announcement is immediately followed by a cry of astonishment: "Silver himself!"
Startled by this news, Jim quickly gets to his feet, rubs his eyes, and hurries to a loophole in the stockade wall to see what is happening.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was dead tired, as you may fancy; and when I got to sleep, which was not till after a great deal of tossing, I slept like a log of wood.

events.text_segment:
I was dead tired, as you may fancy; and when I got to sleep, which was not till after a great deal of tossing, I slept like a log of wood.
The rest had long been up and had already breakfasted and increased the pile of firewood by about half as much again when I was wakened by a bustle and the sound of voices.
“Flag of truce!” I heard someone say; and then, immediately after, with a cry of surprise, “Silver himself!”
And at that, up I jumped, and rubbing my eyes, ran to a loophole in the wall.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I was dead tired, as you may fancy; and when I got to sleep, which was not till after a great deal of tossing, I slept like a log of wood. I was awakened by a bustle and the sound of voices; and, looking forth, I saw the sun far gone upon the western hills, and the tall trees between me and it like masts against a sunset. Good heavens! it was already fourth bells—noon was long past. As soon as I was fairly awake I began to remember what I had seen, and though I was so exhausted, I felt a good deal of shame that I had been asleep for so long a time. I got on my feet at once, and found the camp in full swing. The buccaneers were burying their dead, of whom there had been six; six bodies had tumbled into the excavation that should have been the eighteenth-century treasure-seeker's grave. Our men, on the other hand, had posted sentries and renewed the fire; and Captain Smollett was now giving orders for the day. I was so hungry, having had so little to eat all day, that, finding a biscuit, I devored it, dry as it was, and it tasted like a delicacy, rather than a dry, hard biscuit. Then I went to the captain, who was sitting by the fire, and told him what I had seen. He was greatly pleased, and said that he had no doubt that the buccaneers would be back in the morning, and that we should have a fight. I was very glad to hear this, for I was eager to be in a fight, and I was sure that we should win. I was just going to ask him if I could be in the fight, when I heard a voice say, "Flag of truce!" and then another voice cry, "Silver himself!" I was so astonished at this news that I jumped to my feet, rubbed my eyes, and ran to a loophole in the stockade.

events.title: Silver's Arrival Under a Flag of Truce and Initial Parley
detailed_summary: Two men, one identified as Long John Silver and the other carrying a white cloth, appeared outside the stockade on a very cold morning.
The narrator, Jim Hawkins, observed the pervasive chill and low-lying vapor, noting the island's unhealthy, feverish atmosphere.
Captain Smollett, wary of a potential ruse, commanded his men to take defensive positions: Dr. Livesey to the north, Jim to the east, Gray to the west, while others were ordered to load muskets.
Captain Smollett hailed the buccaneers, demanding they identify themselves or face fire.
Silver announced they were under a flag of truce.
The unnamed buccaneer then stated that 'Cap'n Silver' wished to enter the stockade to negotiate terms.
Captain Smollett expressed skepticism and disdain for Silver's self-proclaimed captaincy.

Silver responded, asserting that his crew had chosen him as captain following Smollett's 'desertion,' and requested Smollett's word for safe passage out of the stockade after their discussion, assuring a willingness to submit if terms were met.
Captain Smollett replied sternly that he had no wish to speak with Silver but would permit him entry, cautioning that any treachery would be on Silver's head.
Silver, undeterred by his companion's apparent misgivings and the captain's brusque response, confidently approached and climbed over the stockade fence.
Jim confessed he had abandoned his lookout post to observe Captain Smollett, who was seated by the fire, whistling.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Sure enough, there were two men just outside the stockade, one of them waving a white cloth, the other, no less a person than Silver himself, standing placidly by.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was whistling “Come, Lasses and Lads.”

events.text_segment:
Sure enough, there were two men just outside the stockade, one of them waving a white cloth, the other, no less a person than Silver himself, standing placidly by.
It was still quite early, and the coldest morning that I think I ever was abroad in—a chill that pierced into the marrow. The sky was bright and cloudless overhead, and the tops of the trees shone rosily in the sun. But where Silver stood with his lieutenant, all was still in shadow, and they waded knee-deep in a low white vapour that had crawled during the night out of the morass. The chill and the vapour taken together told a poor tale of the island. It was plainly a damp, feverish, unhealthy spot.
“Keep indoors, men,” said the captain. “Ten to one this is a trick.”
Then he hailed the buccaneer.
“Who goes? Stand, or we fire.”
“Flag of truce,” cried Silver.
The captain was in the porch, keeping himself carefully out of the way of a treacherous shot, should any be intended. He turned and spoke to us, “Doctor’s watch on the lookout. Dr. Livesey take the north side, if you please; Jim, the east; Gray, west. The watch below, all hands to load muskets. Lively, men, and careful.”
And then he turned again to the mutineers.
“And what do you want with your flag of truce?” he cried.
This time it was the other man who replied.
“Cap’n Silver, sir, to come on board and make terms,” he shouted.
“Cap’n Silver! Don’t know him. Who’s he?” cried the captain. And we could hear him adding to himself, “Cap’n, is it? My heart, and here’s promotion!”
Long John answered for himself. “Me, sir. These poor lads have chosen me cap’n, after your desertion, sir”—laying a particular emphasis upon the word “desertion.” “We’re willing to submit, if we can come to terms, and no bones about it. All I ask is your word, Cap’n Smollett, to let me safe and sound out of this here stockade, and one minute to get out o’ shot before a gun is fired.”
“My man,” said Captain Smollett, “I have not the slightest desire to talk to you. If you wish to talk to me, you can come, that’s all. If there’s any treachery, it’ll be on your side, and the Lord help you.”
“That’s enough, Cap’n,” shouted Long John cheerily. “A word from you’s enough. I know a gentleman, and you may lay to that.”
We could see the man who carried the flag of truce attempting to hold Silver back. Nor was that wonderful, seeing how cavalier had been the captain’s answer. But Silver laughed at him aloud and slapped him on the back as if the idea of alarm had been absurd. Then he advanced to the stockade, threw over his crutch, got a leg up, and with great vigour and skill succeeded in surmounting the fence and dropping safely to the other side.
I will confess that I was far too much taken up with what was going on to be of the slightest use as sentry; indeed, I had already deserted my eastern loophole and crept up behind the captain, who had now seated himself on the threshold, with his elbows on his knees, his head in his hands, and his eyes fixed on the water as it bubbled out of the old iron kettle in the sand. He was whistling “Come, Lasses and Lads.”

As is usual at this season, the vapours hung in all the hollows and between the great rocks and pine-trees, and it was to this thickness of the fog that we owed our comparative safety during the assault of the morning.  In a word, the weather was temperate and kindly, and the bright sun shining on the fog promised a good day.  But for all that, there was something exceedingly unhomelike and threatening in the look of the island, and I can assure you we were all pleased to see the sun break through; and that was what it was doing over the eastern shoulder of the island, and shining already on the tops of the pine-trees. events.title: Silver Enters the Stockade and Captain Smollett's Scornful Reception
detailed_summary: Silver experienced considerable difficulty climbing the knoll towards the blockhouse due to the steep, sandy terrain and his crutch, yet he persevered without complaint.
He was dressed in his finest attire, including an immense blue coat and a laced hat, and offered a formal salute to Captain Smollett upon reaching him.
Captain Smollett acknowledged Silver's arrival and curtly instructed him to sit down on the sand outside the blockhouse.
Silver complained about the cold morning and expressed a desire to be allowed inside.

Captain Smollett sharply retorted that Silver's current discomfort was a consequence of his own choices; had he remained an honest man, he might be comfortable in the ship's galley, but as a mutineer, he deserved to hang.
Silver, outwardly unfazed, sat as bidden and addressed Jim and Dr. Livesey with feigned cordiality, remarking that they presented a picture of domestic contentment.
Captain Smollett impatiently urged Silver to state his business.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Silver had terrible hard work getting up the knoll.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “If you have anything to say, my man, better say it,” said the captain.

events.text_segment:
Silver had terrible hard work getting up the knoll. What with the steepness of the incline, the thick tree stumps, and the soft sand, he and his crutch were as helpless as a ship in stays. But he stuck to it like a man in silence, and at last arrived before the captain, whom he saluted in the handsomest style. He was tricked out in his best; an immense blue coat, thick with brass buttons, hung as low as to his knees, and a fine laced hat was set on the back of his head.
“Here you are, my man,” said the captain, raising his head. “You had better sit down.”
“You ain’t a-going to let me inside, Cap’n?” complained Long John. “It’s a main cold morning, to be sure, sir, to sit outside upon the sand.”
“Why, Silver,” said the captain, “if you had pleased to be an honest man, you might have been sitting in your galley. It’s your own doing. You’re either my ship’s cook—and then you were treated handsome—or Cap’n Silver, a common mutineer and pirate, and then you can go hang!”
“Well, well, Cap’n,” returned the sea-cook, sitting down as he was bidden on the sand, “you’ll have to give me a hand up again, that’s all. A sweet pretty place you have of it here. Ah, there’s Jim! The top of the morning to you, Jim. Doctor, here’s my service. Why, there you all are together like a happy family, in a manner of speaking.”
“If you have anything to say, my man, better say it,” said the captain.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Silver had terrible hard work getting up the knoll. The slope was not very steep, but it was sandy and loose, and he floundered badly about the knees, and his crutch went deep into the sand. Still, it was amazing how he got along at all; and so determined he seemed to be that I am sure he would have reached the top with a broken neck rather than give in. He was all in his best clothes, I observed, a fine, broadcloth blue coat, striped waist-coat, and bright brass buttons, that shone like gold. He had a laced hat on his head, and he wore a great old sea-cloak, that fell about his shoulders. His cheeks were pale, and his eyes dark and shining; but the smile he was always ready with made his face, I thought, remarkably pleasant. He stopped a little to recover when he reached the level ground, and then came slowly towards us, with the monkey on his shoulder. "Avast there, John!" said Captain Smollett. "Drop your anchor." "Cap'n," said Silver, with a salutation, "I am here by appointment." "You may sit down, John," said the captain. "Thank ye kindly, sir," said the cook, as good-humouredly as if nothing had happened. He sat down as he was bidden, and stated his business as follows: "Cap'n," said he, "on the part of the gentlemen as is aboard, I am here to make terms." "Terms?" cried Captain Smollett. "That's the best joke I've heard this morning. And you, I reckon, are the ambassador?" Silver nodded. "Well, now, look here, John," said the captain. "You're a cool hand, ain't you?" "Not particularly, sir, I thank you for asking," said Silver. "I'm a little cold, to tell you the truth. I wish I had a drop of rum here to warm me." "If you had been an honest man, you would have been in my service, and comfortable aboard," said the captain. "But being as you are, and what you are, I'll trouble you to give up that talking and come to business." "Well, then, to come to business," said Silver. "Here it is. We want that treasure, and we'll have it. You can't stop us. I know that, and you know that. I tell you, by the living thunder, that you can't stop us!"

events.title: Silver Reveals Knowledge of the Prior Night's Events and States His Demands
detailed_summary: Silver began by acknowledging the effectiveness of the defenders' surprise attack the previous night, admitting that his men, and possibly himself, had been shaken by it, which was his reason for seeking terms.
He warned Captain Smollett that such an event would not be repeated, as his crew would henceforth maintain better sentry duty and consume less rum.
Silver claimed that he himself had been sober but extremely tired, and had he awoken moments sooner, he would have caught the attackers.
Captain Smollett maintained his composure, though Silver's allusions were initially puzzling to him.

Jim, however, started to piece things together, recalling Ben Gunn's earlier words and surmising that Gunn must have been the one to attack the buccaneers during their drunken revelry, thereby reducing their numbers.
Silver then bluntly stated his primary demand: the treasure, for which they needed the chart possessed by the captain's party, offering their lives in exchange.
Captain Smollett responded evasively about the chart's existence.
Silver insisted he knew they had the chart and that Smollett's guardedness was unhelpful.
Captain Smollett cut him off, asserting that they were fully aware of Silver's mutinous intentions and that Silver was now powerless to achieve them, before calmly proceeding to fill his pipe.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Right you were, Cap’n Smollett,” replied Silver.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And the captain looked at him calmly and proceeded to fill a pipe.

events.text_segment:
“Right you were, Cap’n Smollett,” replied Silver. “Dooty is dooty, to be sure. Well now, you look here, that was a good lay of yours last night. I don’t deny it was a good lay. Some of you pretty handy with a handspike-end. And I’ll not deny neither but what some of my people was shook—maybe all was shook; maybe I was shook myself; maybe that’s why I’m here for terms. But you mark me, Cap’n, it won’t do twice, by thunder! We’ll have to do sentry-go and ease off a point or so on the rum. Maybe you think we were all a sheet in the wind’s eye. But I’ll tell you I was sober; I was on’y dog tired; and if I’d awoke a second sooner, I’d ’a caught you at the act, I would. He wasn’t dead when I got round to him, not he.”
“Well?” says Captain Smollett as cool as can be.
All that Silver said was a riddle to him, but you would never have guessed it from his tone. As for me, I began to have an inkling. Ben Gunn’s last words came back to my mind. I began to suppose that he had paid the buccaneers a visit while they all lay drunk together round their fire, and I reckoned up with glee that we had only fourteen enemies to deal with.
“Well, here it is,” said Silver. “We want that treasure, and we’ll have it—that’s our point! You would just as soon save your lives, I reckon; and that’s yours. You have a chart, haven’t you?”
“That’s as may be,” replied the captain.
“Oh, well, you have, I know that,” returned Long John. “You needn’t be so husky with a man; there ain’t a particle of service in that, and you may lay to it. What I mean is, we want your chart. Now, I never meant you no harm, myself.”
“That won’t do with me, my man,” interrupted the captain. “We know exactly what you meant to do, and we don’t care, for now, you see, you can’t do it.”
And the captain looked at him calmly and proceeded to fill a pipe.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Right you were, Cap’n Smollett,” replied Silver. “Dooty is dooty, to be sure. You will have seen my signal, I dare say, and the cap’n of the schooner—if you hear me aright, the cap’n of the schooner—you’ll have seen him waving of his hat, I dare say, to draw your attention. And so, Cap’n, by your leave, I’ve come aboard to treat about terms.”

“Silver,” said the captain, shortly, “you are the ringleader of these mutineers.”

“Well, now, Cap’n, by your leave, that’s Mr. Silver on the platform,” returned the cook, in that pleasant voice of his, which made it so hard to believe he was a monster. “Mr. Silver, if you please.”

“Well, Mr. Silver, you’re the ringleader of these mutineers,” said Captain Smollett. “And you are just about the worst man in the lot, what’s more. I and my friends have opened a second barrel to-day. And what would you like?”

“To capitulate, Cap’n,” said Silver, “and make a bargain. Here we are, in a bit of a mess, to be sure, but there’s argyments in your favour, likewise, and in mine. And I k’n tell you, Cap’n, you ain’t either of you much account till you have the treasure in your pocket—no, nor till you, Mr. Hawkins, bring us unreg’lar news of it likewise. And you may lay to that.”

“Ah, to be sure!” said Captain Smollett. “Well, now, you six gentlemen of fortune on shore, we eight gentlemen of fortune on the island, where are we? Silver, I’ll tell you what it is. events.title: Rising Tensions and a Momentary Truce of Tobacco
detailed_summary: Silver attempted to raise the subject of Abe Gray, likely to suggest Gray had betrayed information or to sow discord.

Captain Smollett reacted with a sudden burst of anger, vehemently stating that Gray had told him nothing, he had asked Gray nothing, and he would rather see Silver, Gray, and the entire island utterly destroyed than negotiate on such a premise.
This display of temper seemed to sober Silver, who had been growing increasingly irritated.
Composing himself, Silver observed that the captain was preparing to smoke and proposed he do the same.
The two men then filled and lit their pipes, sitting in a prolonged, watchful silence, a scene Jim found as compelling as a theatrical play.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “If Abe Gray—” Silver broke out.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was as good as the play to see them.

events.text_segment:
“If Abe Gray—” Silver broke out.
“Avast there!” cried Mr. Smollett. “Gray told me nothing, and I asked him nothing; and what’s more, I would see you and him and this whole island blown clean out of the water into blazes first. So there’s my mind for you, my man, on that.”
This little whiff of temper seemed to cool Silver down. He had been growing nettled before, but now he pulled himself together.
“Like enough,” said he. “I would set no limits to what gentlemen might consider shipshape, or might not, as the case were. And seein’ as how you are about to take a pipe, Cap’n, I’ll make so free as do likewise.”
And he filled a pipe and lighted it; and the two men sat silently smoking for quite a while, now looking each other in the face, now stopping their tobacco, now leaning forward to spit. It was as good as the play to see them.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
```text
“If Abe Gray—” Silver broke out.

“Silver,” said the captain, in a sudden burst of anger that startled me, and Silver as well, “if you were ready to shiver your timbers, I am ready to shiver mine. Do you think we are children? I know nothing of Abe Gray, nor of the information you pretend he gave me. I asked him nothing, nor would I. I would rather see you, and Gray, and this whole island blown clean out of the water than take a single step under false colours or negotiate on such a base premise. Not a man of us will budge, unless it be to blow that accursed ship of yours out of the water!”

The sudden fury of the captain seemed to sober Silver, who had been growing visibly more irritated. He paused, his eye fixed on Smollett, then slowly composed himself.

“Well,” said he, with a change of voice, “that’s clear enough, to be sure. And now, since you are ready to smoke, Captain, I am ready too.”

He sat down again, as he spoke, and drawing a pipe from his pocket, began coolly to fill it.

“That’s the best thing a man can do when he is troubled,” he added, with a grin.

Captain Smollett, still flushed but regaining his composure, likewise produced his pipe. The two men, the pirate and the officer, sat facing each other, filling and lighting their pipes with deliberate care. A long, watchful silence fell between them, broken only by the soft puffing of smoke. To me, watching from my hiding place, the scene was as strange and compelling as any play upon a stage.
```

events.title: Silver Formally Proposes His Terms for the Treasure Chart
detailed_summary: Silver resumed the negotiation, formally presenting his terms.
He demanded that Captain Smollett's party surrender the treasure chart.
In return, Silver offered two options to the defenders:
Firstly, they could join the pirates aboard the Hispaniola once the treasure was secured, with Silver giving his 'affy-davy' (affidavit) or word of honor to land them safely ashore somewhere.

Secondly, if they preferred not to trust his crew due to past grievances, they could remain on the island. Silver pledged to divide the remaining stores fairly, man for man, and again gave his word to hail the first ship he encountered and arrange for their rescue.
Silver asserted that these were very fair terms.
He then raised his voice, ensuring his words were audible to everyone within the blockhouse, stating that his offer was made to all of them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Now,” resumed Silver, “here it is.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And I hope”—raising his voice—“that all hands in this here block house will overhaul my words, for what is spoke to one is spoke to all.”

events.text_segment: “Now,” resumed Silver, “here it is. You give us the chart to get the treasure by, and drop shooting poor seamen and stoving of their heads in while asleep. You do that, and we’ll offer you a choice. Either you come aboard along of us, once the treasure shipped, and then I’ll give you my affy-davy, upon my word of honour, to clap you somewhere safe ashore. Or if that ain’t to your fancy, some of my hands being rough and having old scores on account of hazing, then you can stay here, you can. We’ll divide stores with you, man for man; and I’ll give my affy-davy, as before to speak the first ship I sight, and send ’em here to pick you up. Now, you’ll own that’s talking. Handsomer you couldn’t look to get, now you. And I hope”—raising his voice—“that all hands in this here block house will overhaul my words, for what is spoke to one is spoke to all.”

```text
“Now,” resumed Silver, “here it is. I give you my word of honour: surrender the chart, and you can pick your hand. If you ain't for going along with us, then you can stay here, and I'll call for commodore nor captain, not to mention doctor, no, nor squire. But I'll call for the first ship that sails, with true colours, and send you home. I'll divide the stores with you, man for man; and I'll give my affy-davy, so I will, to see you safe out of this island. Or, if you like to join hands with us, we'll make a man of you, and you'll have your share of the treasure, and we'll land you safe ashore somewhere, and I'll give you my affy-davy upon that too.”

He paused a moment, and then added, “These are my terms, and I reckon they are fair ones. And now,” he cried, raising his voice, “I'm here to speak to all of you, and not to Captain Smollett only. I'm here to speak to all of you, and I say that you can take your choice.”
```

events.title: Captain Smollett's Uncompromising Rejection and Counter-Ultimatum
detailed_summary: Captain Smollett rose from his seat and carefully knocked the ashes from his pipe into his hand.
He asked Silver if his proposal was complete.
Silver affirmed it was, adding a threat of 'musket-balls' should his terms be rejected.
Captain Smollett then delivered his resolute counter-offer: the mutineers must approach the stockade one by one, unarmed.
If they complied, he would place them in irons and transport them back to England to face a fair trial.
If they refused, Smollett declared that, as a loyal officer of his sovereign, he would fight them until they were all defeated and dead.

He taunted Silver, stating the mutineers could neither find the treasure nor sail the ship due to lack of skill, nor could they defeat his men, reminding Silver how Gray alone had escaped five of them.
He asserted that Silver's ship was effectively disabled and that the mutineers were trapped in a dangerous coastal position with no easy escape.
Smollett concluded by warning Silver that these were the last civil words he would offer, promising to shoot him on their next meeting, and then curtly ordered him to leave the stockade immediately.

events.text_segment:
Captain Smollett rose from his seat and knocked out the ashes of his pipe in the palm of his left hand.
“Is that all?” he asked.
“Every last word, by thunder!” answered John. “Refuse that, and you’ve seen the last of me but musket-balls.”
“Very good,” said the captain. “Now you’ll hear me. If you’ll come up one by one, unarmed, I’ll engage to clap you all in irons and take you home to a fair trial in England. If you won’t, my name is Alexander Smollett, I’ve flown my sovereign’s colours, and I’ll see you all to Davy Jones. You can’t find the treasure. You can’t sail the ship—there’s not a man among you fit to sail the ship. You can’t fight us—Gray, there, got away from five of you. Your ship’s in irons, Master Silver; you’re on a lee shore, and so you’ll find. I stand here and tell you so; and they’re the last good words you’ll get from me, for in the name of heaven, I’ll put a bullet in your back when next I meet you. Tramp, my lad. Bundle out of this, please, hand over hand, and double quick.”

events.title: Silver's Wrathful Departure and Vows of Retaliation
detailed_summary: Silver's face contorted with fury at Captain Smollett's terms, his eyes wide with wrath.
He angrily shook the burning tobacco from his pipe.
He demanded assistance to get to his feet, but Captain Smollett refused.
Silver then roared for help, but none of Captain Smollett's men moved to aid him.
Muttering foul curses, Silver crawled across the sand until he reached the porch, where he managed to pull himself up onto his crutch.
In a final gesture of contempt, he spat into the nearby spring.
He then furiously threatened to demolish their 'old block house' within the hour, proclaiming that those who died in the ensuing fight would be the fortunate ones.

With a terrible oath, Silver stumbled away from the stockade, struggled down the sandy incline, and was eventually helped back over the fence by his companion after several unsuccessful attempts, disappearing swiftly among the trees.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Silver’s face was a picture; his eyes started in his head with wrath.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And with a dreadful oath he stumbled off, ploughed down the sand, was helped across the stockade, after four or five failures, by the man with the flag of truce, and disappeared in an instant afterwards among the trees.

events.text_segment:
Silver’s face was a picture; his eyes started in his head with wrath. He shook the fire out of his pipe.
“Give me a hand up!” he cried.
“Not I,” returned the captain.
“Who’ll give me a hand up?” he roared.
Not a man among us moved. Growling the foulest imprecations, he crawled along the sand till he got hold of the porch and could hoist himself again upon his crutch. Then he spat into the spring.
“There!” he cried. “That’s what I think of ye. Before an hour’s out, I’ll stove in your old block house like a rum puncheon. Laugh, by thunder, laugh! Before an hour’s out, ye’ll laugh upon the other side. Them that die’ll be the lucky ones.”
And with a dreadful oath he stumbled off, ploughed down the sand, was helped across the stockade, after four or five failures, by the man with the flag of truce, and disappeared in an instant afterwards among the trees.

events.title: Captain Smollett's Reprimand and Rallying Cry
detailed_summary: After Long John Silver's departure, Captain Smollett discovers that only Gray remains at his assigned post within the house, the rest of the defenders having momentarily abandoned theirs.
He angrily roars for everyone to return to 'Quarters,' expressing severe disappointment at the serious lapse in discipline.
Mr. Trelawney and Dr. Livesey are specifically admonished for their conduct, while Gray is commended for his steadfast adherence to duty.

With his crew abashed and back in their positions, the Captain announces his conviction that Silver's pirates will attack within the hour, revealing he intentionally provoked Silver to hasten the confrontation.

He acknowledges their numerical inferiority but emphasizes their strategic advantage of fighting from a fortified position and expresses his confidence in their ability to achieve victory if they maintain discipline.
The Captain then meticulously inspects all defensive arrangements to ensure complete readiness for the impending assault.

events.text_segment:
As soon as Silver disappeared, the captain, who had been closely watching him, turned towards the interior of the house and found not a man of us at his post but Gray. It was the first time we had ever seen him angry.
“Quarters!” he roared. And then, as we all slunk back to our places, “Gray,” he said, “I’ll put your name in the log; you’ve stood by your duty like a seaman. Mr. Trelawney, I’m surprised at you, sir. Doctor, I thought you had worn the king’s coat! If that was how you served at Fontenoy, sir, you’d have been better in your berth.”
The doctor’s watch were all back at their loopholes, the rest were busy loading the spare muskets, and everyone with a red face, you may be certain, and a flea in his ear, as the saying is.
The captain looked on for a while in silence. Then he spoke.
“My lads,” said he, “I’ve given Silver a broadside. I pitched it in red-hot on purpose; and before the hour’s out, as he said, we shall be boarded. We’re outnumbered, I needn’t tell you that, but we fight in shelter; and a minute ago I should have said we fought with discipline. I’ve no manner of doubt that we can drub them, if you choose.”
Then he went the rounds and saw, as he said, that all was clear.

'I shall make it a personal favour, I give you my word, and I am pretty good at wringing,' he added, grimly smiling. 'You shall have your wish, Gray, if you earn it,' said Smollett. 'Handsomely said. Now, you doctor, you squire, you Jim, back to your posts, every man jack of you, and that at the double!' events.title: Defensive Preparations and Assignment of Posts
detailed_summary: The defensive layout of the blockhouse is detailed: two loopholes on the east, west, and south sides respectively, and a more numerous five on the north side.
A total of twenty muskets are available for the seven defenders, with firewood ingeniously stacked to serve as makeshift tables holding ammunition and four loaded muskets on each side of the house.
Cutlasses are stored centrally for quick and easy access should close combat become necessary.
Captain Smollett orders the fire in the hearth to be extinguished by Mr. Trelawney to prevent smoke from obscuring their vision during the fight.
He instructs Hawkins (Jim) to eat his breakfast quickly to maintain his strength and orders Hunter to distribute a ration of brandy to all hands to bolster their spirits.
The Captain finalizes his defensive strategy, assigning Dr. Livesey to guard the main door, firing from the relative safety of the porch.

Hunter is assigned to defend the east side, while Joyce is tasked with the west. Mr. Trelawney and Gray, identified as the best marksmen, are given the critical responsibility of defending the vulnerable north side with its five loopholes.
Jim Hawkins and Captain Smollett, acknowledging they are not skilled shooters, will focus on reloading muskets and providing overall support and assistance during the engagement.

events.text_segment:
On the two short sides of the house, east and west, there were only two loopholes; on the south side where the porch was, two again; and on the north side, five. There was a round score of muskets for the seven of us; the firewood had been built into four piles—tables, you might say—one about the middle of each side, and on each of these tables some ammunition and four loaded muskets were laid ready to the hand of the defenders. In the middle, the cutlasses lay ranged.
“Toss out the fire,” said the captain; “the chill is past, and we mustn’t have smoke in our eyes.”
The iron fire-basket was carried bodily out by Mr. Trelawney, and the embers smothered among sand.
“Hawkins hasn’t had his breakfast. Hawkins, help yourself, and back to your post to eat it,” continued Captain Smollett. “Lively, now, my lad; you’ll want it before you’ve done. Hunter, serve out a round of brandy to all hands.”
And while this was going on, the captain completed, in his own mind, the plan of the defence.
“Doctor, you will take the door,” he resumed. “See, and don’t expose yourself; keep within, and fire through the porch. Hunter, take the east side, there. Joyce, you stand by the west, my man. Mr. Trelawney, you are the best shot—you and Gray will take this long north side, with the five loopholes; it’s there the danger is. If they can get up to it and fire in upon us through our own ports, things would begin to look dirty. Hawkins, neither you nor I are much account at the shooting; we’ll stand by to load and bear a hand.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: On the two short sides of the house, east and west, there were only two loopholes; on the south side where the porch was, two again; and on the north side, five. There was a stout door on the south, and a little window, not glazed, on the west, as a single exception. Our stock of muskets was twenty, besides those of the captain's party; so that we had twenty-eight in all, and plenty of powder and ball. The firewood, which had been piled high near the door, we promptly took down and piled inside the blockhouse--a pile to be used by Dr. Livesey for his fire, and the rest for tables to hold our powder and shot. It was neatly done. One pile we made in a corner, near the doctor's fire, and piled the rest all round the blockhouse in an inner ring, leaving a clear space under the loopholes. Here we stored all our powder and cartridges, and all our muskets--twenty loaded muskets, I say, and the eight others ready to be loaded. The cutlasses were hung in a bundle on a nail near the door. And now, Captain Smollett, looking about on the seven of us, addressed us as follows: "Well, men," said Captain Smollett, "we must be quick. Attack will be here any moment. Doctor, I'll give you the door. Nobody will pass you. Hunter, I assign you the east side, Joyce the west, Mr. Trelawney and Gray, you will take this long north side, with the five loopholes, it's the hardest. Jim, you and I will fetch and carry, and load the muskets. We must have ten muskets loaded in the inside, in a pile, and ten ready loaded for use." At the same time, he ordered Jim to eat his breakfast quickly, and Hunter to give every man a good nip of brandy, which was done. He then went on: "This is the state of things: twenty-seven muskets, counting my own, and seven men; that is not enough. We must fight this ship's crew, and fire with every musket we can. We must keep up the fire. And there is another thing: we must have no smoke. The fire in the hearth must be out. Mr. Trelawney, will you be so good as to put it out?" And Mr. Trelawney, who was a very strong man, and knew all about woodcraft, soon had the fire out, and the hearth swept clean. "And now," said Captain Smollett, "the attack is coming. We must be ready. Every man to his post. No talking. No noise. Keep your eyes open. And God defend us!"

The house itself was a strong, square building, built of logs, with the bark still on them. It stood about twenty feet square.
