events.title: Eavesdropping on the Drunken Pirates' Quarrel
detailed_summary: As Jim waited for another gust of wind to ease the tension on the last two strands of the hawser, his attention was drawn to loud voices coming from the Hispaniola's cabin.
He identified one voice as belonging to Israel Hands, who had been Flint's gunner, and the other as the pirate known for wearing a red night-cap.
It was clear that both men were heavily intoxicated and still drinking; Jim even heard one of them throw what he presumed was an empty bottle out of the stern window.

The pirates were not merely drunk but also furiously angry, their argument punctuated by oaths and escalating to what seemed like the brink of physical violence, although each flare-up would subside without blows.
Jim could also perceive the glow of the pirates' large campfire on the shore and hear a mournful, droning sailor's song being sung.
He recalled some of the song's despondent lyrics about a sole survivor of a large crew and considered it uncomfortably appropriate given the pirates' significant losses earlier that day.
He reflected on the buccaneers' apparent insensitivity and hard-heartedness, likening their nature to the unforgiving sea.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then I lay quiet, waiting to sever these last when the strain should be once more lightened by a breath of wind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But, indeed, from what I saw, all these buccaneers were as callous as the sea they sailed on.

events.text_segment:
Then I lay quiet, waiting to sever these last when the strain should be once more lightened by a breath of wind.
All this time I had heard the sound of loud voices from the cabin, but to say truth, my mind had been so entirely taken up with other thoughts that I had scarcely given ear. Now, however, when I had nothing else to do, I began to pay more heed.
One I recognized for the coxswain’s, Israel Hands, that had been Flint’s gunner in former days. The other was, of course, my friend of the red night-cap. Both men were plainly the worse of drink, and they were still drinking, for even while I was listening, one of them, with a drunken cry, opened the stern window and threw out something, which I divined to be an empty bottle. But they were not only tipsy; it was plain that they were furiously angry. Oaths flew like hailstones, and every now and then there came forth such an explosion as I thought was sure to end in blows. But each time the quarrel passed off and the voices grumbled lower for a while, until the next crisis came and in its turn passed away without result.
On shore, I could see the glow of the great camp-fire burning warmly through the shore-side trees. Someone was singing, a dull, old, droning sailor’s song, with a droop and a quaver at the end of every verse, and seemingly no end to it at all but the patience of the singer. I had heard it on the voyage more than once and remembered these words: “But one man of her crew alive, What put to sea with seventy-five.”
And I thought it was a ditty rather too dolefully appropriate for a company that had met such cruel losses in the morning. But, indeed, from what I saw, all these buccaneers were as callous as the sea they sailed on.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: MODEL_RESPONSE_BLOCKED
Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_jailbreak: MODEL_RESPONSE_BLOCKED

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Then I lay quiet, waiting to sever these last when the strain should be once more lightened by a breath of wind. The coracle bobbed and scraped against the great hull of the Hispaniola, a tiny shell beside a mountain. The sounds were all of the sea and the ship: the gentle wash of water, the creak of timbers, the occasional flap of a sail overhead. My heart hammered against my ribs, a frantic drum in the vast silence of the night. Every moment seemed an age. I peered into the gloom, trying to make out the ship's outline, the position of the ropes, anything that might give me a hint of what was to come. The current pulled steadily, keeping the strain taut, the ropes singing like harp strings under the tension. I gripped my knife, my hand slick with sweat, ready to strike the instant the opportunity arose.

And then, it came. A faint sigh across the water, a whisper that grew into a gentle breeze. The sails above me filled with a soft thump, and the ship gave a slow, majestic lurch. For a precious second, the ropes went slack. This was my chance! With a desperate energy, I sawed at the remaining strands. They parted with surprising ease, one after another. The last one snapped, and suddenly, there was no longer the grinding friction of the coracle against the ship.

The Hispaniola, freed from her moorings, began to drift away. Slowly at first, then with increasing momentum, she slid into the darkness, her stern light a dwindling star. I was alone. Utterly, terrifyingly alone in the vast, black expanse of the sea. The coracle spun gently, a mere leaf on the water. The sounds of the ship faded, replaced by the endless murmur of the waves and the lonely cry of a seabird. Fear, cold and sharp, pierced through my exhilaration.

events.title: Setting the Hispaniola Adrift and Witnessing a Deadly Confrontation
detailed_summary: When the wind picked up again, causing the hawser to loosen, Jim exerted himself and successfully cut the final two strands, setting the Hispaniola adrift.
The coracle, barely influenced by the breeze, was almost instantly swept against the Hispaniola's bows.
The schooner then began to slowly rotate, turning across the current.
Jim worked desperately to prevent the coracle from being swamped, eventually managing to push it clear by shoving directly astern of the larger vessel.
Just as he gave the final push, his hands encountered a light rope trailing from the Hispaniola's stern.
Acting primarily on instinct, he grabbed it; finding it secure, his curiosity then prompted him to attempt a look through the cabin window.
He carefully pulled himself along the rope and, at considerable risk, raised himself just enough to peer into the cabin.
By this point, both vessels were moving quickly, already abreast of the pirates' campfire on shore, and the Hispaniola was making significant noise as it moved through the water.
A single, brief glance revealed that Israel Hands and his companion were locked in a desperate, physical struggle, each with his hands on the other's throat, explaining why no alarm had been raised.

Jim quickly dropped back into the coracle, narrowly avoiding falling overboard, the vivid image of the two enraged, flushed faces fighting under the dim lamplight imprinted in his mind; he closed his eyes to re-acclimate to the darkness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At last the breeze came; the schooner sidled and drew nearer in the dark; I felt the hawser slacken once more, and with a good, tough effort, cut the last fibres through.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I shut my eyes to let them grow once more familiar with the darkness.

events.text_segment:
At last the breeze came; the schooner sidled and drew nearer in the dark; I felt the hawser slacken once more, and with a good, tough effort, cut the last fibres through.
The breeze had but little action on the coracle, and I was almost instantly swept against the bows of the Hispaniola. At the same time, the schooner began to turn upon her heel, spinning slowly, end for end, across the current.
I wrought like a fiend, for I expected every moment to be swamped; and since I found I could not push the coracle directly off, I now shoved straight astern. At length I was clear of my dangerous neighbour, and just as I gave the last impulsion, my hands came across a light cord that was trailing overboard across the stern bulwarks. Instantly I grasped it.
Why I should have done so I can hardly say. It was at first mere instinct, but once I had it in my hands and found it fast, curiosity began to get the upper hand, and I determined I should have one look through the cabin window.
I pulled in hand over hand on the cord, and when I judged myself near enough, rose at infinite risk to about half my height and thus commanded the roof and a slice of the interior of the cabin.
By this time the schooner and her little consort were gliding pretty swiftly through the water; indeed, we had already fetched up level with the camp-fire. The ship was talking, as sailors say, loudly, treading the innumerable ripples with an incessant weltering splash; and until I got my eye above the window-sill I could not comprehend why the watchmen had taken no alarm. One glance, however, was sufficient; and it was only one glance that I durst take from that unsteady skiff. It showed me Hands and his companion locked together in deadly wrestle, each with a hand upon the other’s throat.
I dropped upon the thwart again, none too soon, for I was near overboard. I could see nothing for the moment but these two furious, encrimsoned faces swaying together under the smoky lamp, and I shut my eyes to let them grow once more familiar with the darkness.

```python
"""
At last the breeze came; the schooner sidled and drew nearer in the dark; I felt the hawser slacken once more, and with a good, tough effort, cut the last fibres through.

The coracle, which had been fast, was instantly swept against the Hispaniola's bows. I had scarce time to think, let alone act, when I found myself under her lee, and the great schooner began to turn upon her heel, swinging slowly, broadside on, across the current. And then I was in peril of being swamped; for drifting broadside on, she was so much wider than the coracle that she threatened to cover it entirely. I had to exert myself mightily to keep it clear, and at last, as I had only one oar, got it overboard and shoved directly astern of her.

But not till I had stumbled on something new, a great thing it seemed to me at the moment, a thing that I instantly grasped and held on to. It was the Hispaniola's hawser; she had only parted it at the other end. I instantly, and almost without thought, grasped the rope, and finding it firm, I was next seized with curiosity and the desire to look in at the cabin window. I pulled myself along hand over hand, and at last, with infinite risk, I got my head above the level of the cabin window.

Both vessels were now moving fast, and already abreast of the pirates' campfire on shore; and the Hispaniola was making a great noise of rushing water. One brief glance I had, and nothing more; but it was enough. The two men, Israel Hands and his companion (the man with the red night-cap), were locked together in deadly wrestle upon the floor. Each had his hands upon the other's throat, and they rocked to and fro in mortal struggle, the lamp swinging to and fro, and casting dizzy circles of light along the floor. They were too much absorbed to notice me.

And I, in my turn, was too much absorbed to be prudent. Instantly I dropped back into the coracle, and safe or unsafe, lay panting on the bottom. The great rush of the Hispaniola's water went roaring by me, and the schooner was rapidly leaving me astern. I have never seen two men fight it out so savagely; and the sight of their two enraged, flushed faces, locked together in deadly grapple, and lit by the dim lamp, struck me with a horror that I cannot name. I lay there for some time, my eyes closed, and the image of the two men fighting in the cabin still printed on my mind.
"""
```

events.title: Adrift and at the Mercy of the Current
detailed_summary: Jim heard the pirates ashore conclude their song and launch into their familiar, rousing chorus.
He was musing on the aptness of the
drink and the devil
line regarding the situation in the Hispaniola's cabin when his coracle suddenly lurched, veered sharply, and began to accelerate.
Opening his eyes, he observed small, glowing ripples around him and noticed the Hispaniola ahead also seemed to be changing course erratically, heading southward.

A look astern confirmed his fears: the campfire was now behind him, revealing that the current had abruptly changed direction, sweeping both the schooner and his coracle rapidly through the narrows toward the open sea.
The Hispaniola then yawed violently, and shouts from aboard indicated that the two fighting pirates had finally been interrupted and become aware of their ship's uncontrolled drift.
Terrified, Jim lay flat in the bottom of the coracle, prayed, and resigned himself to what he believed would be a swift death on unseen breakers at the sea entrance of the straits.
He endured hours of being tossed by waves and soaked by spray, constantly expecting his demise, yet unable to bear watching it approach.
Eventually, overwhelming weariness, numbness, and intermittent stupor dulled his terror, and he succumbed to sleep, dreaming of his home and the Admiral Benbow inn amidst the chaos.

events.text_segment:
The endless ballad had come to an end at last, and the whole diminished company about the camp-fire had broken into the chorus I had heard so often: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum! Drink and the devil had done for the rest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
I was just thinking how busy drink and the devil were at that very moment in the cabin of the Hispaniola, when I was surprised by a sudden lurch of the coracle. At the same moment, she yawed sharply and seemed to change her course. The speed in the meantime had strangely increased.
I opened my eyes at once. All round me were little ripples, combing over with a sharp, bristling sound and slightly phosphorescent. The Hispaniola herself, a few yards in whose wake I was still being whirled along, seemed to stagger in her course, and I saw her spars toss a little against the blackness of the night; nay, as I looked longer, I made sure she also was wheeling to the southward.
I glanced over my shoulder, and my heart jumped against my ribs. There, right behind me, was the glow of the camp-fire. The current had turned at right angles, sweeping round along with it the tall schooner and the little dancing coracle; ever quickening, ever bubbling higher, ever muttering louder, it went spinning through the narrows for the open sea.
Suddenly the schooner in front of me gave a violent yaw, turning, perhaps, through twenty degrees; and almost at the same moment one shout followed another from on board; I could hear feet pounding on the companion ladder and I knew that the two drunkards had at last been interrupted in their quarrel and awakened to a sense of their disaster.
I lay down flat in the bottom of that wretched skiff and devoutly recommended my spirit to its Maker. At the end of the straits, I made sure we must fall into some bar of raging breakers, where all my troubles would be ended speedily; and though I could, perhaps, bear to die, I could not bear to look upon my fate as it approached.
So I must have lain for hours, continually beaten to and fro upon the billows, now and again wetted with flying sprays, and never ceasing to expect death at the next plunge. Gradually weariness grew upon me; a numbness, an occasional stupor, fell upon my mind even in the midst of my terrors, until sleep at last supervened and in my sea-tossed coracle I lay and dreamed of home and the old Admiral Benbow.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The endless ballad had come to an end at last, and the whole diminished company about the camp-fire had broken into the chorus I had heard so often: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum! Drink and the devil had done for the rest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!” I was just thinking how busy drink and the devil were at that very moment in the cabin of the Hispaniola, when I was surprised by a sudden lurch of the coracle. It veered sharply, and I was aware of a strong current running beneath me. The ripples were small, but smart, and I was being carried along with considerable rapidity. I opened my eyes at once. The campfire was already far astern. The Hispaniola still lay where she had been anchored, but seemed to have swung more to the south. And the strange thing was that she was also moving. An unknown current had caught her, as it had caught me, and was sweeping her slowly to the southward. I knew at once the cause of this new movement. The ebb-tide, with the greater part of its force, was just beginning to run, and it was bearing me seaward in the mouth of the river. I began to pull with all my strength in an effort to get back. Now, I knew the Coracle could not live in a heavy sea, and I was sure that, if the tide carried me out, I should perish. I worked like a slave, but the tide was too strong for me; and presently I began to lose ground. The Hispaniola meanwhile was drifting more rapidly than I, and I began to fear that she would overtake me. I should have been glad of it, for I was sure that I could not live long in the open sea. I was not yet clear of the mouth of the river, but I was already in a very rough water. The waves were short and steep, and the spray flew over me. I was wet through, and very cold. I was also very much frightened. I lay down in the bottom of the coracle, and prayed. I expected every moment to be my last. I was sure that I should be dashed to pieces on the breakers at the mouth of the river. I lay there for a long time, tossed about by the waves, and expecting death every moment. But death did not come. The coracle was a wonderful boat. It rode over the waves like a sea-bird. I was wet through, and very cold, but I was still alive. I began to hope that I might live. I was very tired, and very sleepy. I had been up all night, and I had had a very hard day. I was also very much frightened. events.title: Awakening Adrift and the Perilous Southern Shore
detailed_summary: The narrator awakens to find himself adrift off the south-west coast of Treasure Island, near the imposing Spy-glass mountain.
He observes Haulbowline Head and Mizzenmast Hill, noting the dangerous cliffs and powerful breakers among fallen rocks.
His initial idea to paddle ashore is quickly abandoned due to the treacherous conditions and the fear of being dashed against the rocks or failing to scale the cliffs.
He is further deterred by the sight of numerous large sea creatures, which he initially perceives as "slimy monsters," making loud barking noises on the rocks and in the water.

Although he later learns they are harmless sea lions, their appearance, combined with the difficult shoreline and strong surf, convinces him to avoid this landing spot, preferring starvation at sea over such dangers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was broad day when I awoke and found myself tossing at the south-west end of Treasure Island.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I felt willing rather to starve at sea than to confront such perils.

events.text_segment:
It was broad day when I awoke and found myself tossing at the south-west end of Treasure Island. The sun was up but was still hid from me behind the great bulk of the Spy-glass, which on this side descended almost to the sea in formidable cliffs.
Haulbowline Head and Mizzenmast Hill were at my elbow, the hill bare and dark, the head bound with cliffs forty or fifty feet high and fringed with great masses of fallen rock. I was scarce a quarter of a mile to seaward, and it was my first thought to paddle in and land.
That notion was soon given over. Among the fallen rocks the breakers spouted and bellowed; loud reverberations, heavy sprays flying and falling, succeeded one another from second to second; and I saw myself, if I ventured nearer, dashed to death upon the rough shore or spending my strength in vain to scale the beetling crags.
Nor was that all, for crawling together on flat tables of rock or letting themselves drop into the sea with loud reports I beheld huge slimy monsters—soft snails, as it were, of incredible bigness—two or three score of them together, making the rocks to echo with their barkings.
I have understood since that they were sea lions, and entirely harmless. But the look of them, added to the difficulty of the shore and the high running of the surf, was more than enough to disgust me of that landing-place. I felt willing rather to starve at sea than to confront such perils.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was broad day when I awoke and found myself tossing at the south-west end of Treasure Island. The sun was up, and the sky was unclouded. In this quarter, neither Spy-glass nor Mizzenmast Hill was visible, but the great bulk of the Spy-glass stood up black against the sky in the north and north-east. A reef of rocks lay before me in the waves, and quite near the shore were two little islands, bare and rocky, not only separated from each other, but at a considerable distance from the land, with the most turbulent surf I ever beheld raging between them. At the south-west end of the island I came, as I say, broadside on to the breakers, and now, managed by the current and the sail, I was being carried rapidly past them. The surf bellowed and thundered among the rocks; the eddies spun and bubbled like a boiling pot. I was close enough to see the foam fly, and I heard the roar plainly. The coast here was very wild—nothing but cliff and rock, with the tangle of the woods coming in places almost down to the brink. In the face of the cliff were caves and buttresses, and green trees were growing in high places, the leaves hanging like ivy over the mouth of them. Once I saw an eagle perched upon a crag, looking out on the wide ocean. Immediately after, I began to be swept rapidly past this line of coast, and suddenly, as I looked back, came in sight of the Spy-glass again, and the great woods about it. I was now at the south-east corner of the island, and began to drift away towards the south. The land behind me had sunk low and seemed to be receding, but every now and then I caught sight of the Spy-glass, which was by three or four hundred feet the tallest mountain on the island. I had been drifting for about an hour when I saw the Hispaniola lying-to about a mile and a half to the south-east. The current had carried me round the south end of the island and I was now drifting towards the ship. I could see the men on deck, and I knew they could see me. I was in a terrible quandary. If I went on board, I was sure to be killed. If I stayed in the coracle, I was sure to starve. I decided to take my chance in the coracle.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was broad day when I awoke and found myself tossing at the south-west end of Treasure Island. The coracle, which had served me so well, was nowhere to be seen; it had either capsized or drifted away in the night. I was alone on the shore, the sand warm under my cheek, the sound of the surf in my ears. I sat up, stiff and sore, and looked about me. The island rose steeply behind me, covered in dense, unfamiliar vegetation. Before me stretched the great, empty sea, sparkling in the morning sun.

My eyes searched for the Hispaniola. There she was, a mile or two offshore, drifting slowly to the south-east. My heart gave a leap of triumph. My desperate venture had succeeded! The pirates were marooned, their escape cut off. But where were the captain and the others? And where was I, exactly? I knew this was the south-west point, but the island was large and wild.

A feeling of utter loneliness came over me, but it was quickly followed by a surge of resolve. I had done my part to cripple the mutineers; now I must find my friends. I got to my feet, my legs shaky, and scanned the coastline. There was no sign of life, no boat, nothing but the endless beach and the dark woods. I knew I couldn't stay here. I had to move, to explore, to find the stockade or some trace of the captain's party. Taking a deep breath, I turned my back on the sea and began to walk along the shore, heading north, towards the unknown interior of the island.

events.title: A New Plan for Landfall and the Coracle's Treacherous Nature
detailed_summary: The narrator spots a more promising landing area north of Haulbowline Head: a stretch of yellow sand leading to Cape of the Woods, which is covered in tall pines.
He remembers Silver's information about a northward current along the west coast and, seeing he is already in its grip, decides to aim for Cape of the Woods.
The sea is relatively calm with a gentle south wind, allowing his light coracle to ride the swells surprisingly well.
He often lies low, peeking over the gunwale, watching large waves pass without upsetting the boat, which dances lightly over them.
Feeling bolder, he tries to paddle, but the slightest shift in weight causes the coracle to behave erratically, nosediving steeply into a wave and drenching him.
Terrified, he returns to his prone position, and the coracle resumes its gentle movement, making it clear that it resists being actively steered and casting doubt on his ability to reach land.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the meantime I had a better chance, as I supposed, before me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was plain she was not to be interfered with, and at that rate, since I could in no way influence her course, what hope had I left of reaching land?

events.text_segment:
In the meantime I had a better chance, as I supposed, before me. North of Haulbowline Head, the land runs in a long way, leaving at low tide a long stretch of yellow sand. To the north of that, again, there comes another cape—Cape of the Woods, as it was marked upon the chart—buried in tall green pines, which descended to the margin of the sea.
I remembered what Silver had said about the current that sets northward along the whole west coast of Treasure Island, and seeing from my position that I was already under its influence, I preferred to leave Haulbowline Head behind me and reserve my strength for an attempt to land upon the kindlier-looking Cape of the Woods.
There was a great, smooth swell upon the sea. The wind blowing steady and gentle from the south, there was no contrariety between that and the current, and the billows rose and fell unbroken.
Had it been otherwise, I must long ago have perished; but as it was, it is surprising how easily and securely my little and light boat could ride. Often, as I still lay at the bottom and kept no more than an eye above the gunwale, I would see a big blue summit heaving close above me; yet the coracle would but bounce a little, dance as if on springs, and subside on the other side into the trough as lightly as a bird.
I began after a little to grow very bold and sat up to try my skill at paddling. But even a small change in the disposition of the weight will produce violent changes in the behaviour of a coracle. And I had hardly moved before the boat, giving up at once her gentle dancing movement, ran straight down a slope of water so steep that it made me giddy, and struck her nose, with a spout of spray, deep into the side of the next wave.
I was drenched and terrified, and fell instantly back into my old position, whereupon the coracle seemed to find her head again and led me as softly as before among the billows. It was plain she was not to be interfered with, and at that rate, since I could in no way influence her course, what hope had I left of reaching land?

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: In the meantime I had a better chance, as I supposed, before me. North of Haulbowline Head, the land runs in a long way, leaving, at low tide, a shallow, sandy spit and bar. South of this, an arm of the sea runs up, which at high tide penetrates far into the mainland and forms not only the Bay of the North Inlet, but cuts off the large peninsula of the Spy-glass, Trea-sure Island itself, and the peninsula of the Woods from the rest of the island. The Bay of the North Inlet was the key to the whole position. It was defended by the spit and bar at its mouth, and by Haulbowline Head to the south, was shallow and extremely treacherous for shipping, and yet was the only place where you could hope to beach a whole vessel. The other side of Spy-glass and the Wooded Mountain was steep and ironbound. Silver, if he was to have any chance to escape with the treasure, must hope to do so by the Bay of the North Inlet. I had taken the coracle out into the current, and found it was travelling swiftly northward. It struck me at once that if I could get ashore I should greatly embarrass the pirates and perhaps save the lives of the coxswain and the doctor and the squire. The current was carrying me rapidly to the north-east. If I kept my head, I should reach the spit and bar of the North Inlet. I had only to steer right and I should be ashore. I was already in the grip of the current, and I decided to aim for the Cape of the Woods. It was a long stretch of yellow sand, and the Cape of the Woods was covered with tall pines. The sea was calm, and there was a gentle south wind. The coracle was light, and it rode the swells surprisingly well. I often lay low, peeking over the gunwale, watching large waves pass without upsetting the boat, which danced lightly over them. Feeling bolder, I tried to paddle, but the slightest shift in weight caused the coracle to behave erratically, nosediving steeply into a wave and drenching me. Terrified, I returned to my prone position, and the coracle resumed its gentle movement, making it clear that it resisted being actively steered and casting doubt on my ability to reach land.

events.title: Learning to Steer and the Agony of Thirst
detailed_summary: Despite his fear, the narrator keeps his composure, first bailing out the coracle with his sea-cap.
He then carefully studies how the coracle naturally navigates through the waves, observing that it threads its way through the valleys and avoids the crests.
He devises a strategy: lie still to maintain balance but use the paddle occasionally in smoother water to nudge the coracle towards land.
This method is exhausting and slow, but he visibly gains ground, making some eastward progress even though he misses Cape of the Woods.
As he gets closer to the next promontory, he is tormented by extreme thirst due to the sun, saltwater spray, and the tantalizing sight of nearby trees.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I began to be horribly frightened, but I kept my head, for all that.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The sight of the trees so near at hand had almost made me sick with longing, but the current had soon carried me past the point, and as the next reach of sea opened out, I beheld a sight that changed the nature of my thoughts.

events.text_segment:
I began to be horribly frightened, but I kept my head, for all that. First, moving with all care, I gradually baled out the coracle with my sea-cap; then, getting my eye once more above the gunwale, I set myself to study how it was she managed to slip so quietly through the rollers.
I found each wave, instead of the big, smooth glossy mountain it looks from shore or from a vessel’s deck, was for all the world like any range of hills on dry land, full of peaks and smooth places and valleys. The coracle, left to herself, turning from side to side, threaded, so to speak, her way through these lower parts and avoided the steep slopes and higher, toppling summits of the wave.
“Well, now,” thought I to myself, “it is plain I must lie where I am and not disturb the balance; but it is plain also that I can put the paddle over the side and from time to time, in smooth places, give her a shove or two towards land.” No sooner thought upon than done. There I lay on my elbows in the most trying attitude, and every now and again gave a weak stroke or two to turn her head to shore.
It was very tiring and slow work, yet I did visibly gain ground; and as we drew near the Cape of the Woods, though I saw I must infallibly miss that point, I had still made some hundred yards of easting. I was, indeed, close in. I could see the cool green tree-tops swaying together in the breeze, and I felt sure I should make the next promontory without fail.
It was high time, for I now began to be tortured with thirst. The glow of the sun from above, its thousandfold reflection from the waves, the sea-water that fell and dried upon me, caking my very lips with salt, combined to make my throat burn and my brain ache. The sight of the trees so near at hand had almost made me sick with longing, but the current had soon carried me past the point, and as the next reach of sea opened out, I beheld a sight that changed the nature of my thoughts.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I began to be horribly frightened, but I kept my head, for all that. First, I set to work to bail the coracle out with my sea-cap. It was a good deal filled, both with rain-water and with spray from the sea. National as I am, I am something of a Dutchman, and a Dutchman I've heard, always keeps his head when threatened with drowning. So I bailed away, and then, rising to my knees, I set myself to study how to manage the coracle. It was not like any boat I had ever seen or heard of. It was a mere tub upon the water, it was so round, and so small, and so light. But the waves were wonderfully regular, and I soon found out that with a little skill and a good deal of patience, I might ride them down. The coracle, which I had been told was a mere basket, was in reality a very safe boat, and I found that it was not so much the waves themselves that were dangerous, as the spray that flew over them. I found that I must lie very still, and not move about, and that I must use the paddle only in the smooth water between the waves. This was a very slow way of getting on, but I found that I did get on, and that I was making some way to the eastward, though I was not able to make so much way as I had hoped. I was not able to make the Cape of the Woods, but I was able to make the next promontory, and I was getting nearer and nearer to the shore. As I got nearer, I began to suffer from thirst, for the sun was hot, and the salt spray had made me very thirsty. I could see the trees on the shore, and I longed to be among them, but I knew that I must not be in a hurry, and that I must wait for the right time.

events.title: The Mysterious Hispaniola and Suspicions of Desertion
detailed_summary: The narrator suddenly sees the Hispaniola under sail less than half a mile away, a sight that initially leaves him unsure whether to feel glad or sorry due to his desperate thirst.
The ship is under main-sail and two jibs, initially heading north-west, but then starts veering erratically westward, making him think they've spotted him.
However, the Hispaniola repeatedly falls into the wind's eye, her sails shivering helplessly, leading the narrator to believe the crew is drunk.
The ship continues its uncontrolled movements, sailing in swoops and dashes, always ending up stalled, convincing the narrator that no one is steering.
He speculates that the crew is either incapacitated by drink or has abandoned the ship, and considers the possibility of regaining control of the vessel for Captain Smollett.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Right in front of me, not half a mile away, I beheld the Hispaniola under sail.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Either they were dead drunk or had deserted her, I thought, and perhaps if I could get on board I might return the vessel to her captain.

events.text_segment:
Right in front of me, not half a mile away, I beheld the Hispaniola under sail. I made sure, of course, that I should be taken; but I was so distressed for want of water that I scarce knew whether to be glad or sorry at the thought, and long before I had come to a conclusion, surprise had taken entire possession of my mind and I could do nothing but stare and wonder.
The Hispaniola was under her main-sail and two jibs, and the beautiful white canvas shone in the sun like snow or silver. When I first sighted her, all her sails were drawing; she was lying a course about north-west, and I presumed the men on board were going round the island on their way back to the anchorage. Presently she began to fetch more and more to the westward, so that I thought they had sighted me and were going about in chase. At last, however, she fell right into the wind’s eye, was taken dead aback, and stood there awhile helpless, with her sails shivering.
“Clumsy fellows,” said I; “they must still be drunk as owls.” And I thought how Captain Smollett would have set them skipping.
Meanwhile the schooner gradually fell off and filled again upon another tack, sailed swiftly for a minute or so, and brought up once more dead in the wind’s eye. Again and again was this repeated. To and fro, up and down, north, south, east, and west, the Hispaniola sailed by swoops and dashes, and at each repetition ended as she had begun, with idly flapping canvas. It became plain to me that nobody was steering. And if so, where were the men? Either they were dead drunk or had deserted her, I thought, and perhaps if I could get on board I might return the vessel to her captain.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Right in front of me, not half a mile away, I beheld the Hispaniola under sail. I made sure, of course, that I should be instantly pursued; and that I had only time to plunge again into the nearest thicket, and wait till the chase was over. But the ship was not sailing in my direction at all. She was heading right out to sea with a sort of dolorous, lop-sided stavation, and I immediately began to wonder whether I had best be glad or sorry at this sight. My hunger and thirst were extreme, I was soaked with dew and chilled with the first airs of dawn; a long rest was indispensable to me, and yet here was my chance of help being steered away from me. I was so much annoyed, not knowing what to think, that I stamped my foot and broke into a sob. It was the second time that day that I had been forced into tears. The Hispaniola was under her main-sail and two jibs, and the beautiful white canvas shone in the dawn like snow or a cloud. The mainsail was drawing, and the jibs were drawing, and yet it seemed to me that every now and then the vessel was checked for an instant, and then pitched drunkenly forward. I began to imagine that the anchor was on the ground, to which I could find no parallel in all the rules of seamanship. But the Hispaniola was not only checked, she was veering and tacking at most irregular intervals, standing now east, now west, making a long reach to north-west and then falling suddenly into the wind's eye, all her sails taking aback at once. My great perplexity at this manœuvre was only increased when I saw the vessel's head swing slowly round and point straight at me. I fancied they had seen me and were going to hold me accountable for my desertion. I shall never forget the terror and the agony of that moment. It was all over in a flash. The Hispaniola suddenly took the wind again upon the quarter, and off she flew in a gust of fifty knots, swooping as she went. At the same instant, her head swung round again, the sails shivered, and she was back once more in the wind's eye. This unsteady behaviour lasted all the time she was in sight, with now and then a sudden spurt of speed, but always ending in a blow to. It was as if with every lurch the vessel were coming to a standstill. I watched her for a long time, observing all her movements, and wondering what could be wrong. To my great surprise, I could see no one on deck, not even at the helm. I was sure that the crew must be either dead or drunk, and that the ship was sailing by herself. I was not sure whether to be glad or sorry at this discovery. If the crew were dead, I might be able to regain possession of the ship for Captain Smollett. If they were drunk, I might be able to take advantage of their condition and get aboard. But in either case, it was a desperate enterprise, and I was not sure that I was equal to it.

events.title: The Audacious Chase and Perilous Pursuit
detailed_summary: The narrator observes that both his coracle and the Hispaniola are being carried southward by the current at the same speed.
He believes he can catch the erratically sailing schooner if he dares to sit up and paddle, motivated by adventure and the thought of fresh water on board.
He bravely sits up, gets sprayed by a wave, but persists in paddling with strength and caution.
He encounters a heavy sea that forces him to stop and bail, his heart pounding, but he gradually gets the hang of managing the coracle in pursuit.
He gains rapidly on the Hispaniola, seeing the tiller banging about and no sign of anyone on deck, reinforcing his belief that the ship is deserted or the crew incapacitated below.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The current was bearing coracle and schooner southward at an equal rate.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If not, the men were lying drunk below, where I might batten them down, perhaps, and do what I chose with the ship.

events.text_segment:
The current was bearing coracle and schooner southward at an equal rate. As for the latter’s sailing, it was so wild and intermittent, and she hung each time so long in irons, that she certainly gained nothing, if she did not even lose. If only I dared to sit up and paddle, I made sure that I could overhaul her. The scheme had an air of adventure that inspired me, and the thought of the water breaker beside the fore companion doubled my growing courage.
Up I got, was welcomed almost instantly by another cloud of spray, but this time stuck to my purpose and set myself, with all my strength and caution, to paddle after the unsteered Hispaniola. Once I shipped a sea so heavy that I had to stop and bail, with my heart fluttering like a bird, but gradually I got into the way of the thing and guided my coracle among the waves, with only now and then a blow upon her bows and a dash of foam in my face.
I was now gaining rapidly on the schooner; I could see the brass glisten on the tiller as it banged about, and still no soul appeared upon her decks. I could not choose but suppose she was deserted. If not, the men were lying drunk below, where I might batten them down, perhaps, and do what I chose with the ship.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The current was bearing coracle and schooner southward at an equal rate. By this time the sun was beginning to get low, and every minute the wind was freshening into the land breeze. All the world was so quiet that I could hear the ripples lapsing on the prow of the Hispaniola, and the great sails overhead flapping and filling now and again with a sort of momentary belch. Over the great battlements of the Spy-glass and the Black Hill, a few stars began to appear. The sky was proportionately dark in the south, and the ocean paler; but all round me the sea was so tawny that it looked like flowing mud. I knew that that was caused by the outflow from the rivers, and that it was harmless; but it looked ugly, and almost gave me a sick turn at my stomach. The last rays of the sun fell on the Spy-glass, and lit up the cliff face, and the tree-tops that grow there, as if with fire. The Hispaniola still lay becalmed, I could see her chains hanging down almost straight from the hawse-holes. In five minutes more I knew the current would have carried her past the buoy that marked the channel, and if she did not instantly slip anchor, she would be ashore, and my chance to get aboard of her was gone for ever. I lay on my elbows, watching her, and I felt quite sure that I had only to dare to sit up and paddle, and I should be aboard. I did not dare, for the coracle was such an egg-shell. And still I lay, and the ship drifted. It seemed impossible that she should puzzle the pirates so long. My thirst was raging, and I felt desperate. At last, with a sudden impulse, I sat up and cracked my paddle on the water. The coracle gave a great dip, and shipped a quantity of water. I lay back again half-drowned, and filled with despair. That was all right, I thought, and I might as well go home. But presently the impulse returned. Thirst made me desperate. The sun was gone, the stars were thick, and the land breeze was beginning to blow with a steady, freshening force. I knew what I wanted: I wanted to get aboard that ship, and I knew she was lying helpless. It was not so much for a drink that I was desperate; thirst was bad, but not so bad as that. But I was dying for want of something to eat; and I had aboard the Hispaniola a whole boatful of fresh water in a cask, and I knew that the doctor had some biscuits in the cabin. And then there was the adventure of getting aboard a ship that was lying helpless. I don't know what it was, but I was all in a heat to do it. I sat up again and paddled. This time I was more careful, and the coracle did not dip so much. I got my paddle fairly to work, and I began to move. I was surprised to find how easy it was to move the coracle, and how fast I went. I was soon abreast of the buoy, and then I was past it. I was gaining on the Hispaniola. I could see her sails flapping, and I could hear the ripples on her prow. I was gaining on her fast. I was soon within a cable's length of her. I could see the tiller banging about, and I could see that there was no one on deck. I was sure that the ship was deserted, or that the crew were all below, drunk or dead.

And then there was the adventure of getting aboard a ship that was lying helpless. I don't know what it was, but I was all in a heat to do it. I sat up again and paddled. This time I was more careful, and the coracle did not dip so much. I got my paddle fairly to work, and I began to move. I was surprised to find how easy it was to move the coracle, and how fast I went. I was soon abreast of the buoy, and then I was past it. I was gaining on the Hispaniola. I could see her sails flapping, and I could hear the ripples on her prow. I was gaining on her fast. I was soon within a cable's length of her. I could see the tiller banging about, and I could see that there was no one on deck. I was sure that the ship was deserted, or that the crew were all below, drunk or dead.

events.title: Closing In and the Desperate Leap Aboard
detailed_summary: The Hispaniola's tendency to stand still, heading south and yawing, while unhelpful for her own progress, makes it difficult for the narrator to catch her as she still drifts away with the current and leeway.
A temporary drop in the breeze gives him an opportunity as the Hispaniola slowly revolves, presenting her stern, with a cabin window open and a lamp still burning.
He redoubles his efforts and begins to overhaul the ship again.
Just as he is about a hundred yards away, the wind returns, and the Hispaniola fills her sails and speeds off.
Initial despair turns to joy as the ship unexpectedly turns broadside and then rapidly closes the distance towards him.

He suddenly realizes the danger as the schooner bears down on him; with no time to think, he springs to his feet as the bowsprit passes over him, leaps, and catches the jib-boom, his coracle being crushed beneath the Hispaniola. He is left clinging to the ship, his retreat cut off.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: For some time she had been doing the worse thing possible for me—standing still.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With one hand I caught the jib-boom, while my foot was lodged between the stay and the brace; and as I still clung there panting, a dull blow told me that the schooner had charged down upon and struck the coracle and that I was left without retreat on the Hispaniola.

events.text_segment:
For some time she had been doing the worse thing possible for me—standing still. She headed nearly due south, yawing, of course, all the time. Each time she fell off, her sails partly filled, and these brought her in a moment right to the wind again. I have said this was the worst thing possible for me, for helpless as she looked in this situation, with the canvas cracking like cannon and the blocks trundling and banging on the deck, she still continued to run away from me, not only with the speed of the current, but by the whole amount of her leeway, which was naturally great.
But now, at last, I had my chance. The breeze fell for some seconds, very low, and the current gradually turning her, the Hispaniola revolved slowly round her centre and at last presented me her stern, with the cabin window still gaping open and the lamp over the table still burning on into the day. The main-sail hung drooped like a banner. She was stock-still but for the current.
For the last little while I had even lost, but now redoubling my efforts, I began once more to overhaul the chase.
I was not a hundred yards from her when the wind came again in a clap; she filled on the port tack and was off again, stooping and skimming like a swallow.
My first impulse was one of despair, but my second was towards joy. Round she came, till she was broadside on to me—round still till she had covered a half and then two thirds and then three quarters of the distance that separated us. I could see the waves boiling white under her forefoot. Immensely tall she looked to me from my low station in the coracle.
And then, of a sudden, I began to comprehend. I had scarce time to think—scarce time to act and save myself. I was on the summit of one swell when the schooner came stooping over the next. The bowsprit was over my head. I sprang to my feet and leaped, stamping the coracle under water. With one hand I caught the jib-boom, while my foot was lodged between the stay and the brace; and as I still clung there panting, a dull blow told me that the schooner had charged down upon and struck the coracle and that I was left without retreat on the Hispaniola.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: For some time she had been doing the worse thing possible for me—standing still. She headed south, and yawed about and drifted. The currents were bearing her southward, and so was the breeze, to which little she exposed the side of her mainsail. By this time, she was so far out of my track, and I began to be so much exhausted, that I began to despair. It was not long, however, before I began to perceive motions in the ship. Her sails began to fill, and she drew a little ahead. And then the breeze freshened into half a gale, and the ship leaped forward in the sea. My despair was complete. I saw the vessel slip like a bird through the water. In a moment, she would be out of my reach. I could not return to the island, for the tide had carried me round the promontory; and I was too exhausted to pull against it. I determined to give up, and lie down in the coracle, and await what next might happen. But as I was thus meditating, a fresh hope sprang up. The ship began to change her course. She turned to the eastward, and then to the northeast, and then to the north. Presently, she began to decrease the distance, and I saw that she was heading directly for me. I could not understand this manoeuvre; but I saw that it was my only chance, and I redoubled my efforts. At last, I was within a hundred yards of her, and I saw the captain and the mate standing together on the quarter-deck. I hailed them, but they did not hear me. I hailed them again, and they turned and saw me. They seemed to be greatly surprised. The captain shouted something to the mate, and the mate ran forward. I saw him point to me, and then the captain waved his hand. I thought they were going to pick me up, and I was greatly relieved. But as I drew nearer, I saw that they were not going to stop. The ship was still coming on at full speed. I saw that they were going to run me down. I had no time to think. I sprang to my feet, and as the bowsprit passed over me, I leaped and caught the jib-boom. My coracle was crushed beneath the ship, and I was left clinging to the jib-boom, my retreat cut off.

- The middle section is missing the gradual change in the ship's orientation and the specific visual cues (like the stern and cabin window) that signal the narrator's opportunity.
- The completion does not include the description of the ship's stillness except for the current, nor the visual details that set up the narrator's approach.
- The final moments before the leap are missing the sense of urgency and the physical proximity described in the original, as well as the narrator's realization and reaction to the imminent danger.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately describes the ship's course changes, inventing directions and maneuvers not present in the original.
- The sequence of events is altered: the completion introduces despair and hope at different points, and the order of the ship's movement and the narrator's actions does not match the original progression.
- The completion attributes actions and intentions to the ship's crew that are not in the original, such as the crew noticing and reacting to the narrator.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: For some time she had been doing the worse thing possible for me—standing still. The schooner lay there, a dark, silent mass upon the water, anchored just as I had left her, but now a den of pirates. Every minute she remained motionless was a minute gained by the rascals within, a minute lost to our cause. My little coracle, frail as a nutshell, bobbed gently on the swell, carrying me closer to this floating prison. The moon, now high, cast a cold light that silvered the waves and glinted on the ship's rigging, making her look spectral and unreal. There was no sound from her, no light in her cabins, only that ominous silence that spoke louder than any shout. I strained my ears, listening for a footstep, a laugh, a drunken song – anything that would betray the presence of the villains. But there was nothing. Were they all asleep? Or were they awake, perhaps watching, waiting? The thought sent a shiver down my spine. To approach her while she was thus inert felt like creeping up on a sleeping tiger.

events.title: Grim Discovery on the Hispaniola
detailed_summary: The narrator, Jim Hawkins, narrowly avoids being thrown overboard as he boards the erratically moving Hispaniola.
He finds the deck deserted, bearing signs of the recent mutiny, including filth and an empty bottle.
A sudden lurch of the ship reveals two figures on the after-deck: the mutineers left as watchmen.
One, known by his red cap, lies dead and stiff, his arms outstretched and teeth bared in a fixed grin.
The other, Israel Hands, is propped against the bulwarks, appearing extremely pale and weak.
As the ship continues to toss violently, the dead man's body slides around without his expression changing.
Israel Hands seems to slump further with each movement, his face gradually becoming hidden from Jim's view.
Jim notices dark bloodstains on the planks around both men, leading him to conclude they had fought and killed each other in a drunken conflict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had scarce gained a position on the bowsprit when the flying jib flapped and filled upon the other tack, with a report like a gun.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At the same time, I observed, around both of them, splashes of dark blood upon the planks and began to feel sure that they had killed each other in their drunken wrath.

events.text_segment:
I had scarce gained a position on the bowsprit when the flying jib flapped and filled upon the other tack, with a report like a gun. The schooner trembled to her keel under the reverse, but next moment, the other sails still drawing, the jib flapped back again and hung idle.
This had nearly tossed me off into the sea; and now I lost no time, crawled back along the bowsprit, and tumbled head foremost on the deck.
I was on the lee side of the forecastle, and the mainsail, which was still drawing, concealed from me a certain portion of the after-deck. Not a soul was to be seen. The planks, which had not been swabbed since the mutiny, bore the print of many feet, and an empty bottle, broken by the neck, tumbled to and fro like a live thing in the scuppers.
Suddenly the Hispaniola came right into the wind. The jibs behind me cracked aloud, the rudder slammed to, the whole ship gave a sickening heave and shudder, and at the same moment the main-boom swung inboard, the sheet groaning in the blocks, and showed me the lee after-deck.
There were the two watchmen, sure enough: red-cap on his back, as stiff as a handspike, with his arms stretched out like those of a crucifix and his teeth showing through his open lips; Israel Hands propped against the bulwarks, his chin on his chest, his hands lying open before him on the deck, his face as white, under its tan, as a tallow candle.
For a while the ship kept bucking and sidling like a vicious horse, the sails filling, now on one tack, now on another, and the boom swinging to and fro till the mast groaned aloud under the strain. Now and again too there would come a cloud of light sprays over the bulwark and a heavy blow of the ship’s bows against the swell; so much heavier weather was made of it by this great rigged ship than by my home-made, lop-sided coracle, now gone to the bottom of the sea.
At every jump of the schooner, red-cap slipped to and fro, but—what was ghastly to behold—neither his attitude nor his fixed teeth-disclosing grin was anyway disturbed by this rough usage. At every jump too, Hands appeared still more to sink into himself and settle down upon the deck, his feet sliding ever the farther out, and the whole body canting towards the stern, so that his face became, little by little, hid from me; and at last I could see nothing beyond his ear and the frayed ringlet of one whisker.
At the same time, I observed, around both of them, splashes of dark blood upon the planks and began to feel sure that they had killed each other in their drunken wrath.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I had scarce gained a position on the bowsprit when the flying jib flapped and filled upon the other tack, with a report like a gun. The schooner trembled to her keel under the reverse; but presently, the breeze catching her again upon the starboard quarter, she leaned heavily over to the side, and went booming away with a great deal of noise and a wild plunge, that made it quite impossible to stand upon the deck. I was safely perched upon the bowsprit, open to the great sea and the great winds; but half-an-hour later, when I had clambered aboard again, and before I had well reached the forecastle head, ten thousand things went swimming before my eyes, and I felt putting forth my hands to catch at something. The deck was high and dry, not only from the sea, but from the rain and dew, and only littered with broken pails and empty bottles, and the discharge of firearms. Something foul was committed here, I thought, something very foul, and long after midnight. The fore hatchway stood open with a ladder clearly descended. All round was silence, broken only by the wash of the sea and the creaking of the two great booms that rocked to and fro, and the occasional flapping of the sails. The Hispaniola was rolling heavily, and at each plunge her bowsprit dipped deep in the foam. I saw the water boiling white all around her, and heard the great roaring of the surf as it dashed into the caves of the island and up the great ravines; loud as a thunder. I lay long upon the deck, still shuddering at my narrow escape, when suddenly a fearful cry arose, and the schooner, giving a sudden lurch, threw me on my side. At the same instant, a voice shouted something unintelligible, and then things fell into their old routine. I knew the voice; it was Israel Hands'. I was now convinced that there were still hands aboard, and that they were not dead. I got to my feet, and, holding on to the bulwarks, I crept aft with a beating heart. There were two men lying on the after-deck, one of them with a red cap on his head. The other was Israel Hands. The red-cap lay flat upon his back, with his arms stretched out like a cross and his teeth bared in a fixed grin; he was stone dead. Israel Hands was propped against the bulwarks, his face as white as wax, and his eyes closed. He was not dead, but he was very weak. As the ship tossed and plunged, the dead man's body slid to and fro without changing its attitude or expression. Israel Hands seemed to slump lower with each movement, his face gradually becoming hidden from my view. There were dark bloodstains on the planks around both men, and I concluded that they had fought and killed each other in a drunken conflict.

events.title: A Wounded Mutineer's Plea
detailed_summary: During a brief calm, Israel Hands stirs, moaning and shifting, revealing he is still alive.
The sound of Hands's pain and weakness initially evokes sympathy in Jim.
However, Jim's pity vanishes when he recalls Hands's role in the mutiny, which he overheard from the apple barrel.
Jim approaches Hands and addresses him with irony.
Hands, too weak to show surprise or respond at length, simply requests “Brandy.”

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: While I was thus looking and wondering, in a calm moment, when the ship was still, Israel Hands turned partly round and with a low moan writhed himself back to the position in which I had seen him first.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All he could do was to utter one word, “Brandy.”

events.text_segment:
While I was thus looking and wondering, in a calm moment, when the ship was still, Israel Hands turned partly round and with a low moan writhed himself back to the position in which I had seen him first. The moan, which told of pain and deadly weakness, and the way in which his jaw hung open went right to my heart. But when I remembered the talk I had overheard from the apple barrel, all pity left me.
I walked aft until I reached the main-mast.
“Come aboard, Mr. Hands,” I said ironically.
He rolled his eyes round heavily, but he was too far gone to express surprise. All he could do was to utter one word, “Brandy.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: While I was thus looking and wondering, in a calm moment, when the ship was still, Israel Hands turned partly round and with a low moan writhed himself back to the position in which I had seen him first. I was so much surprised at this that I cried out aloud. I thought he must have been dead long ago, and the sight of his white face and bloody rags sickened me. But though I hid my face, and for a moment wished myself somewhere else, I soon remembered what kind of man he was and what we owed to him, and I hardened my heart, and took all the muzzle-loaders to the rail as before, and leaned my chin upon my hands, and waited. The great swells of the ocean passed as gently as I have sometimes seen the ripples pass a stone far inland upon a river. The sun shone down upon the countenance of Hands, and the great drops of sweat stood out plainly on his brow. He moaned and groaned like some disquieted animal, and at last opened his eyes upon me. He looked at me a long while, and at last, with a great effort, he raised himself to his knees, spat heavily on the deck, and as though my presence gave him some encouragement, ordered me to help him. “Hands,” I said, “there’s my medicine chest at the bottom of the companion. It seems to me the best thing you can do is to turn to and get it. I might help you but I haven’t got no wish to.” “Well, see here, sonny,” said he, “I’ve had enough of this. If you lend me a hand, I’ll put you down upon the nearest land, and then I’ll up and sail away.” “There’s a bargain for you!” cried I. “You find me my medicine chest, and I’ll lend you a hand, and then you’ll sail away as far as you can, and die where you can’t do no more mischief. You ain’t much account now, Israel, and more’s the pity. You’ve shaken your last shake, I take it.” He lay a while and moaned. “Brandy,” he said at last, “I want brandy.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: While I was thus looking and wondering, in a calm moment, when the ship was still, Israel Hands turned partly round and with a low moan writhed himself back to the position in which I had seen him first. He lay there, a ghastly figure, his face contorted with pain and malice. I watched him, my heart pounding, unsure if he was dying or merely feigning helplessness. The cutlass lay near him, just out of his reach. I dared not move closer, fearing a sudden lunge. The silence was broken only by the creak of the ship and the distant sound of the surf. I gripped my pistol, my eyes fixed on the pirate, waiting for his next move. The sun beat down, making the deck shimmer.

events.title: Foraging Amidst Cabin Chaos
detailed_summary: Recognizing the need for haste, Jim carefully navigates the unstable deck to reach the ship's cabin.
He discovers the cabin in a state of utter confusion, with locked compartments broken into, presumably in search of the chart.
The floor is caked with mud from the mutineers' boots, the white bulkheads are smeared with dirty handprints, and empty bottles clink in the corners.
A medical book belonging to the doctor lies open and damaged, its pages likely torn out for lighting pipes.
Jim proceeds to the cellar, finding all the barrels gone and a surprising number of bottles emptied and discarded, indicating constant drunkenness among the mutineers.
He successfully locates a bottle containing some brandy for Hands.
For himself, he gathers biscuits, pickled fruits, raisins, and a piece of cheese.
Returning to the deck, Jim secures his own supplies, takes a drink of water, and only then gives the brandy to Hands.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It occurred to me there was no time to lose, and dodging the boom as it once more lurched across the deck, I slipped aft and down the companion stairs into the cabin.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With these I came on deck, put down my own stock behind the rudder head and well out of the coxswain’s reach, went forward to the water-breaker, and had a good deep drink of water, and then, and not till then, gave Hands the brandy.

events.text_segment:
It occurred to me there was no time to lose, and dodging the boom as it once more lurched across the deck, I slipped aft and down the companion stairs into the cabin.
It was such a scene of confusion as you can hardly fancy. All the lockfast places had been broken open in quest of the chart. The floor was thick with mud where ruffians had sat down to drink or consult after wading in the marshes round their camp. The bulkheads, all painted in clear white and beaded round with gilt, bore a pattern of dirty hands. Dozens of empty bottles clinked together in corners to the rolling of the ship. One of the doctor’s medical books lay open on the table, half of the leaves gutted out, I suppose, for pipelights. In the midst of all this the lamp still cast a smoky glow, obscure and brown as umber.
I went into the cellar; all the barrels were gone, and of the bottles a most surprising number had been drunk out and thrown away. Certainly, since the mutiny began, not a man of them could ever have been sober.
Foraging about, I found a bottle with some brandy left, for Hands; and for myself I routed out some biscuit, some pickled fruits, a great bunch of raisins, and a piece of cheese. With these I came on deck, put down my own stock behind the rudder head and well out of the coxswain’s reach, went forward to the water-breaker, and had a good deep drink of water, and then, and not till then, gave Hands the brandy.

It was as I had feared. The mutineers had been here before me. All the chests and cupboards were broken open, and the floor was littered with their contents. The chart, of course, was gone. I saw a great many footprints of muddy boots on the floor, and the white bulkheads were smeared with dirty hands. The lamp was still burning, and by its light I saw that the place was in a state of utter confusion. Empty bottles lay about the floor, and clinked together as the ship rolled. A medical book, which I knew belonged to the doctor, lay open on the table, and I saw that some of the pages had been torn out, no doubt for lighting pipes. I went on to the cellar, and there I found that all the barrels were gone, and a surprising number of bottles had been emptied and thrown away. It was plain that the mutineers had been living in a state of constant drunkenness. I was not long in finding the brandy, which I needed for Hands. I took a bottle of it, and then I went on deck again. I secured my own supplies, which consisted of a few biscuits, some pickled fruits, a handful of raisins, and a piece of cheese. I hid these away in a safe place, and then I took a drink of water from the scuttle-butt. Only then did I give the brandy to Hands.

events.title: Asserting Command and Defying Mutiny
detailed_summary: Israel Hands greedily drinks a substantial amount of the brandy Jim provides.
Jim, having begun to eat his own food, asks Hands about the severity of his injuries.
Hands responds with a grunt, wishing the doctor were present and lamenting his ill fortune.
He confirms the death of the other watchman (O'Brien, the man in the red cap), disparaging his seamanship.
Hands then questions Jim about his presence on the ship.
Jim boldly declares that he has come aboard to assume command and instructs Hands to consider him captain.
Hands gives Jim a sour look but remains silent, some color returning to his face, though he still appears very ill and continues to shift with the ship's movements.
Jim announces his refusal to sail under the pirates' flag and states his intention to remove it.
He dodges the swinging boom, lowers the pirates' black flag, and throws it into the sea, exclaiming loyalty to the king and the end of Captain Silver's reign.
Throughout this, Hands observes Jim with a sharp, cunning, and watchful expression.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He must have drunk a gill before he took the bottle from his mouth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He watched me keenly and slyly, his chin all the while on his breast.

events.text_segment:
He must have drunk a gill before he took the bottle from his mouth.
“Aye,” said he, “by thunder, but I wanted some o’ that!”
I had sat down already in my own corner and begun to eat.
“Much hurt?” I asked him.
He grunted, or rather, I might say, he barked.
“If that doctor was aboard,” he said, “I’d be right enough in a couple of turns, but I don’t have no manner of luck, you see, and that’s what’s the matter with me. As for that swab, he’s good and dead, he is,” he added, indicating the man with the red cap. “He warn’t no seaman anyhow. And where mought you have come from?”
“Well,” said I, “I’ve come aboard to take possession of this ship, Mr. Hands; and you’ll please regard me as your captain until further notice.”
He looked at me sourly enough but said nothing. Some of the colour had come back into his cheeks, though he still looked very sick and still continued to slip out and settle down as the ship banged about.
“By the by,” I continued, “I can’t have these colours, Mr. Hands; and by your leave, I’ll strike ’em. Better none than these.”
And again dodging the boom, I ran to the colour lines, handed down their cursed black flag, and chucked it overboard.
“God save the king!” said I, waving my cap. “And there’s an end to Captain Silver!”
He watched me keenly and slyly, his chin all the while on his breast.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He must have drunk a gill before he took the bottle from his mouth. "Well," I said, "how are you, Hands? Do you think I could help you?" He groaned all his answer. "Doctor," he said. "Ay, doctor!" And then with a sigh, "Ah, shiver my timbers, if I hadn't been struck by that doctor no later than my watch below, I'd have got this schooner into port safe and sound. As for O'Brien, he's dead, God help him," he added, "a cheeful lad, O'Brien, but he's dead. So much for O'Brien. Now, master Jim, what the devil brings you here?" "I've come aboard to take possession," I said. "And you may lay to it that I'm master now, and you'll address me as Captain Hawkins." He lay for some time silent; then he smiled, a very sour smile. "Take possession?" he cried. "Why, ay, you've got the schooner, haven't you? And you've got your hands on Israel, haven't you? Take possession! Well, I'm damned if I can see what more you'd wish." "Well, I wish to tell you this," I returned. "I don't care a farthing for you, Israel. I'm here to do my duty. I'm here to get this ship into a safe anchorage, and I'll do it. And as for the flag, I've no use for that, and I'll strike it." And with that I laid hold of the halyard, and gave it a good pull. The flag came down with a run, and I threw it overboard. "God save the King!" I cried. "And there's an end to Captain Silver!" He watched me all the time with his sharp, cunning eyes, and when I had done, he said nothing, but lay there, looking at me with a kind of smile.

events.title: An Uneasy Bargain Struck
detailed_summary: Israel Hands, addressing Jim as 'Cap'n Hawkins,' proposes they discuss how Jim can get ashore.
Jim readily agrees to talk, and Hands begins to explain their situation.
Hands indicates the corpse of O'Brien, explaining they had intended to sail the Hispaniola back together.
With O'Brien dead, Hands admits he cannot manage the ship alone and implies Jim also lacks the skill to do so without his help.
He offers a deal: if Jim provides him with food, drink, and a bandage for his wound, Hands will teach him how to sail the ship.
Jim agrees to the terms but stipulates that their destination will be North Inlet, where he plans to beach the ship, not Captain Kidd's anchorage.
Hands, appearing to accept his defeat and limited options, readily concurs, stating he'd help Jim sail even to Execution Dock.
Jim finds the proposal sensible, and they formalize their agreement immediately.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I reckon,” he said at last, “I reckon, Cap’n Hawkins, you’ll kind of want to get ashore now. S’pose we talks.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Well, as it seemed to me, there was some sense in this. We struck our bargain on the spot.

events.text_segment:
“I reckon,” he said at last, “I reckon, Cap’n Hawkins, you’ll kind of want to get ashore now. S’pose we talks.”
“Why, yes,” says I, “with all my heart, Mr. Hands. Say on.” And I went back to my meal with a good appetite.
“This man,” he began, nodding feebly at the corpse “—O’Brien were his name, a rank Irelander—this man and me got the canvas on her, meaning for to sail her back. Well, he’s dead now, he is—as dead as bilge; and who’s to sail this ship, I don’t see. Without I gives you a hint, you ain’t that man, as far’s I can tell. Now, look here, you gives me food and drink and a old scarf or ankecher to tie my wound up, you do, and I’ll tell you how to sail her, and that’s about square all round, I take it.”
“I’ll tell you one thing,” says I: “I’m not going back to Captain Kidd’s anchorage. I mean to get into North Inlet and beach her quietly there.”
“To be sure you did,” he cried. “Why, I ain’t sich an infernal lubber after all. I can see, can’t I? I’ve tried my fling, I have, and I’ve lost, and it’s you has the wind of me. North Inlet? Why, I haven’t no ch’ice, not I! I’d help you sail her up to Execution Dock, by thunder! So I would.”
Well, as it seemed to me, there was some sense in this. We struck our bargain on the spot.

“I reckon,” he said at last, “I reckon, Cap’n Hawkins, you’ll kind of want to get ashore now. S’pose we talks.”

“Why, yes,” said I, “with all my heart, Mr. Hands. Say on.”

And here let it be remarked that Israel Hands was quite the smoothest customer to look at in the whole ship’s company; and the great cut in his cheek had rather improved his appearance than otherwise. As for his smile, it was perfect, agreeable, and bland. There was a singular contrast between it and the blood-stained bandage round his head and the dirty, drunkard, disreputable scoundrel he had proved himself to be.

“Well, Cap’n Hawkins,” he went on, “I feel pretty bad, owin’ to them drinks and the loss of blood; but seein’ as I’m cap’n, why, I stands to it. I was drownded, I was, and ain’t drownded yet, but I hear the death-watch all about the mast; and I know I’ll have to do without O’Brien. O’Brien ain’t worth a biscuit to help plan. So you and me, Cap’n Hawkins, we must work it out betwixt and between. Hands is the name. I feel pretty bad, to be sure, but I ain’t never been dead yet. The Cap’n—that’s me—is here. We’ll save the ship, Cap’n. You and me will save her. You shall be Cap’n, and I’ll be mate. We’ll sail her home.”

“All right,” said I, “I’m agreeable to that, Mr. Hands; but what about the others? We can’t sail her home without hands, you know.”
