LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “Aye, mates,” said he, “it’s lucky you have Barbecue to think for you with this here head. You’d have been lost long ago, every mother’s son of you, without old John to steer the ship. Now, about this here voice – don’t go shaking in your boots like a parcel of children. It’s no ghost, nor devil neither, unless it’s one of our own making. Someone’s playing tricks, or maybe it’s just the echo in these cursed hills. But treasure there is, and treasure we’ll have! Did you think it would be laid out like a picnic for us? This is Flint’s hoard, remember, guarded by more than just sand and trees. We’ll find the trick of it, never fear. Just keep your eyes peeled and your cutlasses ready. We’ve come too far to be scared off by a bit of shouting. Follow me, and we’ll see who’s got the last laugh on Skeleton Island.” The men, though still pale and uneasy, seemed somewhat reassured by his bold words and steady gaze, their fear momentarily overshadowed by their greed and his commanding presence.

events.title: Jim's Deepening Despair and Multifaceted Anxiety
detailed_summary: While Silver's speech lifts the pirates' spirits, Jim feels profoundly dejected.

He recognizes that if Silver's outlined scheme proves successful, the already duplicitous pirate would not hesitate to betray the doctor's party again, preferring wealth and freedom with the pirates over the mere escape from hanging offered by his agreement with Dr. Livesey.

Jim considers the grave danger he would face even if Silver were forced to remain loyal to Dr. Livesey, envisioning a desperate struggle for survival—a crippled man and a boy against five able seamen—should the pirates' suspicions about Silver's allegiance turn to certainty.

His distress is amplified by the unresolved mysteries surrounding his friends' actions: their desertion of the stockade, the surrender of the treasure chart, and Dr. Livesey's cryptic warning to Silver about expecting trouble upon finding the treasure.
These combined anxieties leave Jim with no appetite and a heavy heart as he embarks on the treasure hunt with his captors.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was no wonder the men were in a good humour now.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Add to this double apprehension the mystery that still hung over the behaviour of my friends, their unexplained desertion of the stockade, their inexplicable cession of the chart, or harder still to understand, the doctor’s last warning to Silver, “Look out for squalls when you find it,” and you will readily believe how little taste I found in my breakfast and with how uneasy a heart I set forth behind my captors on the quest for treasure.

events.text_segment:
It was no wonder the men were in a good humour now. For my part, I was horribly cast down. Should the scheme he had now sketched prove feasible, Silver, already doubly a traitor, would not hesitate to adopt it. He had still a foot in either camp, and there was no doubt he would prefer wealth and freedom with the pirates to a bare escape from hanging, which was the best he had to hope on our side.
Nay, and even if things so fell out that he was forced to keep his faith with Dr. Livesey, even then what danger lay before us! What a moment that would be when the suspicions of his followers turned to certainty and he and I should have to fight for dear life—he a cripple and I a boy—against five strong and active seamen!
Add to this double apprehension the mystery that still hung over the behaviour of my friends, their unexplained desertion of the stockade, their inexplicable cession of the chart, or harder still to understand, the doctor’s last warning to Silver, “Look out for squalls when you find it,” and you will readily believe how little taste I found in my breakfast and with how uneasy a heart I set forth behind my captors on the quest for treasure.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was no wonder the men were in a good humour now. For my part, I was horribly cast down. Should the scheme he had sketched prove successful, even though Silver was a sworn ally of my friends, it was plain that he would be able to bring them out or not, as he chose. He might keep his word; and then again, he might not. There was the doctor, to be sure; there were the squire and the captain. But I knew not what force they had, nor where they were hidden. All I knew was that they had deserted the stockade, and that Silver was so sure of their incapacity or his own numbers that he dared to leave me by the cave, and set out for the island with so small a force. If they were alive, they were somewhere about the island; if they were dead, Silver would be just as glad to have the trouble of accounting for me taken off his hands. A man who could betray his comrades in a cause so dear to him as the hunt for treasure, it was hard to believe would be true to a dead man's agreement, or a living man's promise. The doctor, I knew, constable as he was, was not without a sense of honor and justice; and he might report the whole story, with Silver's part in it, to the authorities. But who would believe a story told by Silver, and supported only by the word of a boy? And what was more, I began to fancy I saw a new danger. If Silver, who was so clever and so bold, had been afraid to come to blows with the doctor's party, what hope was there for me, a crippled man and a boy, against five able seamen? Even if Silver kept his word, and brought me safe to the ship, what was to become of me then? I should be a prisoner on board, at the mercy of the crew. And if the doctor's party were to be killed, or to escape, what was to prevent the pirates from killing me too? These thoughts, and a thousand others, crowded into my mind, and made me so miserable that I had no appetite for the breakfast that was set before me. I ate a little, and then, with a heavy heart, I got ready for the march.

events.title: The Treasure Hunting Expedition Sets Out
detailed_summary: The treasure-seeking party presents an odd appearance, dressed in dirty sailor attire and, with the exception of Jim, heavily armed.
Silver is particularly well-equipped with two slung guns, a cutlass, and pistols in his coat pockets, while his parrot, Captain Flint, sits on his shoulder chattering.
Jim is led by a rope tied around his waist, the end held by Silver, making Jim feel like a 'dancing bear'.
Other pirates are laden with tools such as picks and shovels, which were their first priority brought ashore, and provisions like pork, bread, and brandy.

Jim observes that all their supplies originate from the loyal party's stock, confirming Silver's earlier statement about striking a bargain with the doctor; without it, the mutineers would have faced severe shortages.
The entire group, including a man with a head injury who should have been resting, proceeds to the beach where two gigs, showing signs of the pirates' previous drunken neglect, await them.
For safety, both boats are used, and the party divides itself between them to set off across the anchorage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We made a curious figure, had anyone been there to see us—all in soiled sailor clothes and all but me armed to the teeth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Both were to be carried along with us for the sake of safety; and so, with our numbers divided between them, we set forth upon the bosom of the anchorage.

events.text_segment:
We made a curious figure, had anyone been there to see us—all in soiled sailor clothes and all but me armed to the teeth. Silver had two guns slung about him—one before and one behind—besides the great cutlass at his waist and a pistol in each pocket of his square-tailed coat. To complete his strange appearance, Captain Flint sat perched upon his shoulder and gabbling odds and ends of purposeless sea-talk. I had a line about my waist and followed obediently after the sea-cook, who held the loose end of the rope, now in his free hand, now between his powerful teeth. For all the world, I was led like a dancing bear.
The other men were variously burthened, some carrying picks and shovels—for that had been the very first necessary they brought ashore from the Hispaniola—others laden with pork, bread, and brandy for the midday meal. All the stores, I observed, came from our stock, and I could see the truth of Silver’s words the night before. Had he not struck a bargain with the doctor, he and his mutineers, deserted by the ship, must have been driven to subsist on clear water and the proceeds of their hunting. Water would have been little to their taste; a sailor is not usually a good shot; and besides all that, when they were so short of eatables, it was not likely they would be very flush of powder.
Well, thus equipped, we all set out—even the fellow with the broken head, who should certainly have kept in shadow—and straggled, one after another, to the beach, where the two gigs awaited us. Even these bore trace of the drunken folly of the pirates, one in a broken thwart, and both in their muddy and unbailed condition. Both were to be carried along with us for the sake of safety; and so, with our numbers divided between them, we set forth upon the bosom of the anchorage.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: We made a curious figure, had anyone been there to see us—all in soiled sailor clothes and all but me armed to the teeth. Silver was the chief of the party; and he had not only a brace of his old pistols in his belt, but a great cutlass slung round his neck, and a pistol in each pocket of his great coat. His cheeks were pale, and his eyes shone widely when he came out of the stockade, guiding himself with his crutch, his hand upon my shoulder. I was pleased to see the parrot perched upon his shoulder, as I thought it did not look healthy for the old buccaneer to be much alone. The rest were all heavily laden; one with a pickaxe, one with a shovel, another with a coil of rope, and another carrying a great pork-butcher’s knife and a bundle of bread. The injured man, Morgan, was also of our party; he limped heavily at my side, and I had some thoughts of him, from the trouble he had been used to give me, but he seemed quite cowed and abject. They were all beasts of burden, and I was pleased to see it. It was not my business to be pleased or displeased; but I thought it a good sign that they could not get on without so many implements. "Silver," said I, as we were trudging down to the beach, and I remembered the talk we had had that morning, "if I was sure of you, I would tell you what I have heard this morning." "Ah," said he, "you are a smart lad, to be sure, but it’s not the time for talking. We are on business now." And so he was. He was all business. He was the first to reach the gigs, and he was the first to get into one of them. We were to go in two boats, the gigs, which lay on the beach, and which had been left there, I suppose, by the mutineers when they had come ashore. They were in a bad way, the gigs, for they had been left to lie high and dry, and the sun had warped them, and the rain had filled them, and the sand had drifted about them, and they were full of water and sand. We had to bail them out, and we had to push them down to the water, and we had to get into them, and we had to push off. It was a long business, and a hard one, and we were all wet and sandy before we were done. But we got off at last, and we pulled out into the anchorage. We were a strange crew, and a strange sight, as we pulled out into the anchorage. There were the six pirates, all armed to the teeth, and there was I, a boy, with my hands tied behind my back, and there was Silver, with his crutch and his parrot, and there was Morgan, with his limp, and there was the boat, with its load of tools and provisions. We were a strange crew, and a strange sight, as we pulled out into the anchorage.

We were a strange crew, and a strange sight, as we pulled out into the anchorage.

events.title: Navigating by Chart and Ascending to the Plateau
detailed_summary: While rowing across the anchorage, the pirates discuss the treasure map, recognizing that the large red cross marking the treasure's location is too imprecise to be a definitive guide.
The chart's instructions refer to specific landmarks: 'Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet.'
The main landmark is a 'tall tree,' but the nearby plateau is densely covered with pine trees of various heights, making identification from their current position challenging.
Despite the ambiguity, most pirates aboard the boats eagerly select their own candidate for the 'tall tree,' though Long John Silver advises them to wait until they are on site.
Following Silver's direction to row slowly to conserve energy, they eventually land at the mouth of the island's second river, which flows down from the Spy-glass hill.
Turning left, they begin to climb the slope towards the plateau, initially facing difficult terrain with heavy, miry ground and dense, marsh-like vegetation.

As they progress, the ground becomes steeper and stonier, and the forest more open, leading them into a more pleasant area of the island characterized by fragrant broom, flowering shrubs, green nutmeg trees, and tall pines.
The fresh, stirring air under the bright sunlight provides a welcome sensory refreshment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As we pulled over, there was some discussion on the chart.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The air, besides, was fresh and stirring, and this, under the sheer sunbeams, was a wonderful refreshment to our senses.

events.text_segment:
As we pulled over, there was some discussion on the chart. The red cross was, of course, far too large to be a guide; and the terms of the note on the back, as you will hear, admitted of some ambiguity. They ran, the reader may remember, thus: Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet.
A tall tree was thus the principal mark. Now, right before us the anchorage was bounded by a plateau from two to three hundred feet high, adjoining on the north the sloping southern shoulder of the Spy-glass and rising again towards the south into the rough, cliffy eminence called the Mizzenmast Hill. The top of the plateau was dotted thickly with pine-trees of varying height. Every here and there, one of a different species rose forty or fifty feet clear above its neighbours, and which of these was the particular “tall tree” of Captain Flint could only be decided on the spot, and by the readings of the compass.
Yet, although that was the case, every man on board the boats had picked a favourite of his own ere we were half-way over, Long John alone shrugging his shoulders and bidding them wait till they were there.
We pulled easily, by Silver’s directions, not to weary the hands prematurely, and after quite a long passage, landed at the mouth of the second river—that which runs down a woody cleft of the Spy-glass. Thence, bending to our left, we began to ascend the slope towards the plateau.
At the first outset, heavy, miry ground and a matted, marish vegetation greatly delayed our progress; but by little and little the hill began to steepen and become stony under foot, and the wood to change its character and to grow in a more open order. It was, indeed, a most pleasant portion of the island that we were now approaching. A heavy-scented broom and many flowering shrubs had almost taken the place of grass. Thickets of green nutmeg-trees were dotted here and there with the red columns and the broad shadow of the pines; and the first mingled their spice with the aroma of the others. The air, besides, was fresh and stirring, and this, under the sheer sunbeams, was a wonderful refreshment to our senses.

The pirates were grumbling to themselves as usual, saying that Flint must have been a fool to bury his money, and so on. But it was not very long after that till they began to agree that they had never seen so clear a chart. They began to pick out landmarks and make a plan of campaign. It was agreed that the large red cross was too large to be a guide, and that the instructions were needed. These instructions were written in the corner of the chart, and were as follows: 'Tall tree, Spy-glass shoulder, bearing a point to the N. of N.N.E. Skeleton Island E.S.E. and by E. Ten feet.' That was all. The 'tall tree' was the main landmark, but the plateau which they were now approaching was densely covered with pine trees of various heights, and it was impossible to say from where they were which was the tallest. Still, each of the pirates aboard the boats eagerly selected his own candidate for the 'tall tree,' though Long John Silver advised them to wait until they were on the spot. He also directed them to row slowly, so as to conserve their strength for the climb. They eventually landed at the mouth of the island's second river, which flowed down from the Spy-glass hill. Turning left, they began to climb the slope towards the plateau. The ground was at first heavy and miry, and the vegetation was dense and marsh-like. But as they progressed, the ground became steeper and stonier, and the forest more open. They came into a more pleasant area of the island, characterized by fragrant broom, flowering shrubs, green nutmeg trees, and tall pines. The fresh, stirring air under the bright sunlight provided a welcome sensory refreshment.

As we pulled over, there was some discussion on the chart. The old parchment, brittle with age and marked with faded ink, was spread out on the capstan head, weighted down by a couple of pistols to keep it from blowing away in the stiff breeze. Gathered around it were the Squire, his face flushed with excitement; Dr. Livesey, calm and observant, spectacles perched on his nose; Captain Smollett, his brow furrowed with professional concern; and myself, Jim Hawkins, peering over their shoulders, my heart thumping with a mixture of awe and apprehension.

The island lay before us, a dark mass rising from the shimmering sea, its peaks shrouded in a hazy mist. But it was the map that held our immediate attention. There it was, the outline of the island, strangely shaped like a crouching dragon, with its various

events.title: Ominous Discovery of an Artificially Placed Skeleton
detailed_summary: The pirates fan out across the terrain, moving boisterously, shouting and leaping as they advance.
Silver and Jim, with Jim still tethered, follow more slowly in the center, some distance behind the main group; Jim occasionally has to assist Silver to prevent him from falling on the loose gravel.
After covering about half a mile and nearing the top of the plateau, a pirate on the far left flank suddenly begins to shout repeatedly, as if in terror.
The other pirates, including Morgan who quickly dismisses the idea that the treasure itself has been found, rush towards the source of the cries.
Upon reaching the spot, they discover a human skeleton at the foot of a large pine tree, entangled in a green creeper which has even dislodged some of the smaller bones.
Jim observes that this sight sends a momentary chill through everyone present.
George Merry, venturing closer to examine the tattered clothing, identifies the remains as those of a seaman by the quality of the cloth.
Silver concurs, dryly noting one wouldn't expect to find a bishop there, but immediately questions the unnatural way the bones are arranged.

A more careful examination reveals that, despite some disturbance likely from scavengers or plant growth, the skeleton lies perfectly straight, with its feet pointing one way and its hands extended above its head, pointing in the exact opposite direction, like a diver.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The party spread itself abroad, in a fan shape, shouting and leaping to and fro.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Indeed, on a second glance, it seemed impossible to fancy that the body was in a natural position. But for some disarray (the work, perhaps, of the birds that had fed upon him or of the slow-growing creeper that had gradually enveloped his remains) the man lay perfectly straight—his feet pointing in one direction, his hands, raised above his head like a diver’s, pointing directly in the opposite.

events.text_segment:
The party spread itself abroad, in a fan shape, shouting and leaping to and fro. About the centre, and a good way behind the rest, Silver and I followed—I tethered by my rope, he ploughing, with deep pants, among the sliding gravel. From time to time, indeed, I had to lend him a hand, or he must have missed his footing and fallen backward down the hill.
We had thus proceeded for about half a mile and were approaching the brow of the plateau when the man upon the farthest left began to cry aloud, as if in terror. Shout after shout came from him, and the others began to run in his direction.
“He can’t ’a found the treasure,” said old Morgan, hurrying past us from the right, “for that’s clean a-top.”
Indeed, as we found when we also reached the spot, it was something very different. At the foot of a pretty big pine and involved in a green creeper, which had even partly lifted some of the smaller bones, a human skeleton lay, with a few shreds of clothing, on the ground. I believe a chill struck for a moment to every heart.
“He was a seaman,” said George Merry, who, bolder than the rest, had gone up close and was examining the rags of clothing. “Leastways, this is good sea-cloth.”
“Aye, aye,” said Silver; “like enough; you wouldn’t look to find a bishop here, I reckon. But what sort of a way is that for bones to lie? ’Tain’t in natur’.”
Indeed, on a second glance, it seemed impossible to fancy that the body was in a natural position. But for some disarray (the work, perhaps, of the birds that had fed upon him or of the slow-growing creeper that had gradually enveloped his remains) the man lay perfectly straight—his feet pointing in one direction, his hands, raised above his head like a diver’s, pointing directly in the opposite.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The party spread itself abroad, in a fan shape, shouting and leaping to and fro, and now and again calling to each other; for such was their unresting anxiety and excitement that they could scarce hold together. I was pleased to see I was not alone in a sense of boding. Silver, I thought, was struck by the same sense of awe, and kept Silver closer to him, and looked more continually and furtively about him, than of yore. As we were thus slowly following, about half a mile behind the rest, Silver suddenly stopped, not as if he had seen or heard anything, but simply as if he had forgotten something. "Like enough," said he. "It's the gallows." The words were hardly out of his mouth before the fellow in the waist of the party sang out. "Flint's pointer!" he shrieked. "So I've found it at last." "Confound the braggart!" muttered Silver. "He's found the old finger-post, has he? I'll wager that's the direction. And now look here, Jim, see if you can't help me to my feet. You're as strong as a bull." I was so much surprised at the suddenness of the cry that I scarce knew what I was doing, but I helped him to his feet, and we set out together for the place where the pirate had made the discovery. As we drew near, the shouts of the rest of the party redoubled, and we could hear voices crying, "Morgan has it! George Merry has it!" and so forth. "He's found the old finger-post, has he?" repeated Silver, in a low voice. "I'll wager that's the direction. And now look here, Jim, see if you can't help me to my feet. You're as strong as a bull." I was so much surprised at the suddenness of the cry that I scarce knew what I was doing, but I helped him to his feet, and we set out together for the place where the pirate had made the discovery. As we drew near, the shouts of the rest of the party redoubled, and we could hear voices crying, "Morgan has it! George Merry has it!" and so forth. "It's the gallows," muttered Silver, and he quickened his pace. We were the last to come up, and when we arrived, the whole party was collected at the foot of a tall pine, the most conspicuous tree upon the plateau, and from the branches of which a green creeper hung down to the ground. The man who had sung out was standing a little to one side, his eyes fixed upon the ground, and his face as white as paper. "What's the matter?" cried Silver. "Here's the pointer," said the man, in a trembling voice; "and here's the rest of him, too." I saw, with a start, that he was pointing to a skeleton, which lay half-buried in the ground, at the foot of the tree. The bones were all there, and lay in their natural order, but they were covered with a green mould, and the flesh was gone. "It's a man," said George Merry, who was the first to recover his voice. "Ay, ay," said Silver; "it's a man, sure enough. And a seaman, by the cut of his clothes. See, here's the remains of a blue jacket, and a pair of canvas trousers. But what's this?" He stooped down, and picked up a piece of rope, which was tied round the waist of the skeleton. "It's a rope," said he; "and a good stout one, too. And here's a knot in it, as if it had been used to tie him up." "Ay, ay," said Morgan; "it's a man, sure enough. And a seaman, by the cut of his clothes. events.title: Deciphering Flint's Macabre Signpost and Rising Dread
detailed_summary: Silver announces he has an idea and directs the men to take a compass bearing along the line of the skeleton, using the prominent peak of Skeleton Island as a reference point.
The measurement confirms that the skeleton is aligned directly towards Skeleton Island, with the compass reading E.S.E. and by E., matching a clue from the treasure map.
Silver triumphantly identifies the skeleton as a 'p'inter' deliberately arranged by the deceased Captain Flint, calling it one of his characteristic macabre jokes.

He recounts that Flint was on the island alone with six crewmen, all of whom he killed; this skeleton, Silver surmises, is Allardyce (a man Morgan remembers owing him money and taking his knife), positioned by compass as a guide.

The pirates become uneasy, noting the absence of any personal effects like a knife or money with the skeleton, which they find unnatural, as Flint wasn't known for robbing the dead and birds wouldn't take such items.

Silver agrees the scene is neither natural nor pleasant, ominously remarking that if Flint were alive, their current group of six would be in grave danger, just like Flint's original six companions who are now bones.
While Morgan confirms Flint's death, another pirate voices fear of Flint's lingering spirit, recalling his violent and terrifying end.
Another pirate adds to the chilling atmosphere by describing Flint's last moments: raging, demanding rum, and singing 'Fifteen Men,' a song that has haunted him ever since.
Silver attempts to curtail the superstitious talk, insisting Flint is dead and won't walk by day, urging them to focus on finding the doubloons.

Despite Silver's efforts and the bright daylight, the pirates are deeply unnerved, abandoning their earlier boisterousness to move closely together and speak in hushed tones, their spirits overshadowed by the terror of the dead buccaneer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I’ve taken a notion into my old numbskull,” observed Silver.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The terror of the dead buccaneer had fallen on their spirits.

events.text_segment:
“I’ve taken a notion into my old numbskull,” observed Silver. “Here’s the compass; there’s the tip-top p’int o’ Skeleton Island, stickin’ out like a tooth. Just take a bearing, will you, along the line of them bones.”
It was done. The body pointed straight in the direction of the island, and the compass read duly E.S.E. and by E.
“I thought so,” cried the cook; “this here is a p’inter. Right up there is our line for the Pole Star and the jolly dollars. But, by thunder! If it don’t make me cold inside to think of Flint. This is one of his jokes, and no mistake. Him and these six was alone here; he killed ’em, every man; and this one he hauled here and laid down by compass, shiver my timbers! They’re long bones, and the hair’s been yellow. Aye, that would be Allardyce. You mind Allardyce, Tom Morgan?”
“Aye, aye,” returned Morgan; “I mind him; he owed me money, he did, and took my knife ashore with him.”
“Speaking of knives,” said another, “why don’t we find his’n lying round? Flint warn’t the man to pick a seaman’s pocket; and the birds, I guess, would leave it be.”
“By the powers, and that’s true!” cried Silver.
“There ain’t a thing left here,” said Merry, still feeling round among the bones; “not a copper doit nor a baccy box. It don’t look nat’ral to me.”
“No, by gum, it don’t,” agreed Silver; “not nat’ral, nor not nice, says you. Great guns! Messmates, but if Flint was living, this would be a hot spot for you and me. Six they were, and six are we; and bones is what they are now.”
“I saw him dead with these here deadlights,” said Morgan. “Billy took me in. There he laid, with penny-pieces on his eyes.”
“Dead—aye, sure enough he’s dead and gone below,” said the fellow with the bandage; “but if ever sperrit walked, it would be Flint’s. Dear heart, but he died bad, did Flint!”
“Aye, that he did,” observed another; “now he raged, and now he hollered for the rum, and now he sang. ‘Fifteen Men’ were his only song, mates; and I tell you true, I never rightly liked to hear it since. It was main hot, and the windy was open, and I hear that old song comin’ out as clear as clear—and the death-haul on the man already.”
“Come, come,” said Silver; “stow this talk. He’s dead, and he don’t walk, that I know; leastways, he won’t walk by day, and you may lay to that. Care killed a cat. Fetch ahead for the doubloons.”
We started, certainly; but in spite of the hot sun and the staring daylight, the pirates no longer ran separate and shouting through the wood, but kept side by side and spoke with bated breath. The terror of the dead buccaneer had fallen on their spirits.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“I’ve taken a notion into my old numbskull,” observed Silver. “Here’s the compass; there’s the line the old shipmate was a-laying of.”

And he clapped the compass to the head of the skeleton, and bid one of the men lay his finger on the lubber’s point and report the bearing. I observed Silver himself take an altitude of the sun and smile.

“I thought so,” he remarked. “No shipmate living would steer a course by dead men. Here’s the compass—as good as ever Flint had—and here’s the line—this handsome corsair. Now, look you, did not Captain Flint, a-dying, give me that paper with the bearings of the island? And had he not the bearings of this island stored away, for all the world as though he was expecting to be cast away here himself? And did he not point me to the bearings true, from the coast of America—‘south-east and by east, he said, ‘about the size of a country,’ says he, ‘do you see it?’ and I says, ‘I see it.’ And ‘send it home,’ says he, ‘like thunder.’ And now we come here, and we find this old bone upon the ground, and account for it there’s none. But hark ye, mates, what if this bones was a pointer? P’inter,” he repeated, with a grin. “I p’int to it,” says I, “with my finger, and the bones p’ints that way. And by the great horn spoon!” cried he, as he clapped his fist upon his thigh, “here’s the compass bearing, E.S.E. and by E. We were right all along. This old Flint knew what he was about. He laid this skeleton here, and he clapped a meanin’ into it. These six was alone with him; they told him the place as they had seen it when they was whaling; and when it was done, says he, ‘Don’t you think, my boys, I’ve killed six men with my two hands?’ And so he had. And this one,” added Silver, lowering his voice and looking round as if for spies, “this one, mates, is the airt of it. This is the old man himself, and who else but he could lay a body out like that? I’ve read somewhere in books that dead men don’t bite; but if he was alive, you would not feel safe in your berth, no, not for all the doubloons in Christendom.”

“A queer thing it is, to be sure,” said one of the men. “No sign of a knife about him.”

“Nor yet a shovel,” said another. “As if he had been buried in a hurry, so to speak—or not buried at all. Why, there’s deer here; and carrion birds. What could have prevented the birds a-picking of him clean?”

“Ay,” said Silver, “that’s the word. Clean. To the bones. Now, mates, what was the meaning of that? I take it here was a man that knew the coast, from end to end. He was a man that knew the bearings of this island. He was a man that knew the place where the treasure lay. And he was a man that knew how to keep a secret. I’ll lay you, mates, he was the only man among the six that knew the secret. And he died here, and he was buried here, and he was laid out here, and he was left here, to p’int the way to the treasure. And who do you think he was? I’ll tell you. He was Allardyce, the man that Morgan owed money to, the man that took the knife from him when they was on the beach. Ay, Allardyce it was. And he was a man that Flint trusted. And he was a man that Flint killed. And he was a man that Flint laid out here, to p’int the way to the treasure.”

“Ay, ay,” said Morgan. “Allardyce it was. I mind him now. A dark, sallow man, with a cast in his eye. He owed me money, he did. And he took my knife, he did.”

“Well,

“Ay,” said Silver, “that’s the word. Clean. To the bones. Now, mates, what was the meaning of that? I take it here was a man that knew the coast, from end to end. He was a man that knew the bearings of this island. He was a man that knew the place where the treasure lay. And he was a man that knew how to keep a secret. I’ll lay you, mates, he was the only man among the six that knew the secret. And he died here, and he was buried here, and he was laid out here, and he was left here, to p’int the way to the treasure. And who do you think he was? I’ll tell you. He was Allardyce, the man that Morgan owed money to, the man that took the knife from him when they was on the beach. Ay, Allardyce it was. And he was a man that Flint trusted. And he was a man that Flint killed. And he was a man that Flint laid out here, to p’int the way to the treasure.”

“Ay, ay,” said Morgan. “Allardyce it was. I mind him now. A dark, sallow man, with a cast in his eye. He owed me money, he did. And he took my knife, he did.”

“Well,

chapters.chapter_title: XXXII-The Treasure-hunt—The Voice Among the Trees

events.title: Rest on the Ascent and Ominous Recollections of Flint
detailed_summary: The group paused on the plateau after their climb to allow Long John Silver and the unwell members to rest.
Their vantage point offered a wide view of the Cape of the Woods, the anchorage, Skeleton Island, and the eastern sea.
The Spy-glass mountain loomed above, enhancing the sense of isolation, broken only by distant waves and insect sounds.
Silver used his compass for bearings, confidently stating the treasure's location was now simple to determine and suggested they eat first.
Morgan admitted he had no appetite, attributing his unease to thoughts of the deceased Captain Flint.
Silver remarked that Morgan should consider himself fortunate that Flint was dead.
Another pirate, with a shudder, described Flint as an 'ugly devil,' specifically mentioning his blue face.
Merry added that Flint's blue complexion was a consequence of his excessive rum consumption, confirming it as factual.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Partly from the damping influence of this alarm, partly to rest Silver and the sick folk, the whole party sat down as soon as they had gained the brow of the ascent.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That’s a true word.”

events.text_segment:
Partly from the damping influence of this alarm, partly to rest Silver and the sick folk, the whole party sat down as soon as they had gained the brow of the ascent.
The plateau being somewhat tilted towards the west, this spot on which we had paused commanded a wide prospect on either hand. Before us, over the tree-tops, we beheld the Cape of the Woods fringed with surf; behind, we not only looked down upon the anchorage and Skeleton Island, but saw—clear across the spit and the eastern lowlands—a great field of open sea upon the east. Sheer above us rose the Spy-glass, here dotted with single pines, there black with precipices. There was no sound but that of the distant breakers, mounting from all round, and the chirp of countless insects in the brush. Not a man, not a sail, upon the sea; the very largeness of the view increased the sense of solitude.
Silver, as he sat, took certain bearings with his compass.
“There are three ‘tall trees,’” said he, “about in the right line from Skeleton Island. ‘Spy-glass shoulder,’ I take it, means that lower p’int there. It’s child’s play to find the stuff now. I’ve half a mind to dine first.”
“I don’t feel sharp,” growled Morgan. “Thinkin’ o’ Flint—I think it were—as done me.”
“Ah, well, my son, you praise your stars he’s dead,” said Silver.
“He were an ugly devil,” cried a third pirate with a shudder; “that blue in the face too!”
“That was how the rum took him,” added Merry. “Blue! Well, I reckon he was blue. That’s a true word.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Partly from the damping influence of this alarm, partly to rest Silver and the sick folk, the whole party sat down as soon as they had gained the brow of the ascent. The plateau which they now occupied commanded the Spy-glass in one direction, and in the other a very wide view of the neighbourhood of the anchorage. Here we sat, many hundred feet above the level of the sea, in the sun, and in a silence broken only by the waves that beat up loudly on the beach, and the chirp of insects in the near grass. The short respite was accepted as a relief by all hands, pirates and honest men alike. Silver himself seemed to be more brought down than any man aboard, the colour had left his cheeks, and he breathed with difficulty. Old Morgan, too, who was not a strong man, was seized with a fit of trembling. Well, now, said Silver, "here we are. We've had a long climb, and pleasure's pleasure. I don't say no to that; but business is business. As soon as old Morgan here heaves up a bit, we'll start straight again for the treasure." "Treasure," said Morgan, faintly, "not much need of me for that. You can dig it by yourself, you can." "Well, see here, messmates," added Silver, "this is the real place, and I don't care if I tell you so now. The treasure's within a few yards of this." Jim Hawkins looked about him. The plateau was thick with trees, high coco-palms, it seemed, and other unfamiliar tropical growths. On the south, facing the Spy-glass, these trees came nearly to the brow of the ascent. That was the side of the island where the treasure lay; and it was there, surely, that the character of the vegetation had seemed to change—thick-set, thorny bushes, silver-coloured on the leaf, and taller trees beginning to spring. "Look at the compass," said Silver. "Bears north and north-by-east. Well, this'll be the wood, as sure as I'm a living sinner. It's the spruce trees that grow so thick, and the wild vines that tangle all about. And the treasure's buried in the same grove, trees with trunks like pillars, they're a樁. It's cool in that grove," he added. "I'll bet you that." "And there's the Spy-glass shoulder, look," said one. "Ay," said Silver. "Ay, my lads, all right. That's the place, sure enough. I've been naught else but fearin' you would miss it. Ye'd see it for yourself, I know, but the powers that be were—" "Here's the compass," said Silver. "Bears north and north-by-east. Well, this'll be the wood, as sure as I'm a living sinner. It's the spruce trees that grow so thick, and the wild vines that tangle all about. And the treasure's buried in the same grove, trees with trunks like pillars, they're a樁. It's cool in that grove," he added. "I'll bet you that." "And there's the Spy-glass shoulder, look," said one. "Ay," said Silver. "Ay, my lads, all right. That's the place, sure enough. I've been naught else but fearin' you would miss it. Ye'd see it for yourself, I know, but the powers that be were—" "Hold on," cried Morgan. "Don't you see that?" pointing up. "See what?" asked Silver. "The Spy-glass," said Morgan. "It's right over the wood." "Well, and so it is," said Silver. "I didn't see it before. Well, that's all right. That'll make it easier. We'll just go straight for the wood, and then we'll be right on the spot." "I don't like the look of it," said Morgan. "I don't like the look of it at all. It's too quiet. It's not natural." "Well, you can stay here if you like," said Silver. "I'm going on." "Ay, ay," said the others. "We're with you, Silver." "Come on, then," said Silver. "Let's get this over with." He rose to his feet with difficulty, and the others followed suit. They started to move towards the wood, Silver leading the way, leaning heavily on his crutch. The sick men followed slowly, supported by their comrades. Jim Hawkins brought up the rear, his heart pounding with a mixture of fear and excitement. As they approached the edge of the wood, the silence seemed to deepen.

events.title: The Phantom Singer and Abject Terror Among Pirates
detailed_summary: Following their discovery of the skeleton and subsequent morbid thoughts, the pirates' voices had dropped to near whispers.
Suddenly, from the midst of the trees, a thin, high, trembling voice began to sing the familiar words of 'Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!'
Jim Hawkins had never witnessed men so dreadfully affected; the color drained from the pirates' faces as if by magic.
Some pirates leaped to their feet, others clung to one another, and Morgan collapsed onto the ground in terror.
Merry cried out, attributing the voice to Flint.
The song stopped as abruptly as it had begun, as though a hand had been placed over the singer's mouth.
To Jim Hawkins, the song had sounded pleasant and light amidst the sunny greenery, making the pirates' extreme reaction all the more baffling.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Ever since they had found the skeleton and got upon this train of thought, they had spoken lower and lower, and they had almost got to whispering by now, so that the sound of their talk hardly interrupted the silence of the wood.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Coming through the clear, sunny atmosphere among the green tree-tops, I thought it had sounded airily and sweetly; and the effect on my companions was the stranger.

events.text_segment:
Ever since they had found the skeleton and got upon this train of thought, they had spoken lower and lower, and they had almost got to whispering by now, so that the sound of their talk hardly interrupted the silence of the wood. All of a sudden, out of the middle of the trees in front of us, a thin, high, trembling voice struck up the well-known air and words: “Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”
I never have seen men more dreadfully affected than the pirates. The colour went from their six faces like enchantment; some leaped to their feet, some clawed hold of others; Morgan grovelled on the ground.
“It’s Flint, by ——!” cried Merry.
The song had stopped as suddenly as it began—broken off, you would have said, in the middle of a note, as though someone had laid his hand upon the singer’s mouth. Coming through the clear, sunny atmosphere among the green tree-tops, I thought it had sounded airily and sweetly; and the effect on my companions was the stranger.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Ever since they had found the skeleton and got upon this train of thought, they had spoken lower and lower, and they had almost got to whispering by now, so that the sound of their talk hardly interrupted the silence of the wood. All of a sudden, out of the middle of the trees in front of us, a thin, high, trembling voice struck up the well-known air and words:

“Fifteen men on the dead man’s chest—
Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!”

I never saw men so dreadfully affected. The colour went clean out of their faces, and shrunk back into their very hearts. They stared in front of them with their eyes as big as saucers. I heard Morgan swear a prayer. Silver tottered against the nearest tree with a hoarse cry. One of the men fainted. Even the hardy old salts whom I had supposed to be past any surprise were taken aback, and stood staring and hearkening like children. Some leaped to their feet, some took to flight, some hid their faces, while old Pew’s death-chant was still ringing in their ears. It was incredible. For they were men who feared neither God nor man, and only death seemed terrible to them; yet here were men terrified at a mere sound. I shall never forget their faces. 

“That’s Flint, by the living thunder!” cried Merry. 

The song stopped as suddenly as it began—as if someone had clap his hand over the singer’s mouth. Coming so unexpectedly, and out of the silent, sunny woods, it had a strange effect on me, too. I confess I was not unaffected myself; but the pirates’ terror was so extreme and so amazing that it quite diverted me.

events.title: Silver's Attempted Reassurance and the Voice's Eerie Return
detailed_summary: Silver, though visibly pale, struggled to speak and tried to dismiss the event, urging the men to prepare to move on.
He suggested the voice belonged to a living person playing a prank, not a ghost.
As Silver spoke, his courage began to return, and some color came back to his face, which started to reassure the others.
Just as the men were regaining composure, the same voice was heard again, not singing, but as a faint, distant wail echoing from the Spy-glass.
The voice cried out “Darby M’Graw!” repeatedly, then, in a slightly higher tone and with an omitted oath, demanded, “Fetch aft the rum, Darby!”
The buccaneers remained frozen to the spot, their eyes wide with terror, staring silently even after the voice had faded.
One pirate gasped that this settled it and urged them to leave.
Morgan moaned that those were Flint’s last words spoken on board ship.
Dick retrieved his Bible and began praying earnestly, his prior good upbringing evident despite his current company.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Come,” said Silver, struggling with his ashen lips to get the word out; “this won’t do.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had been well brought up, had Dick, before he came to sea and fell among bad companions.

events.text_segment:
“Come,” said Silver, struggling with his ashen lips to get the word out; “this won’t do. Stand by to go about. This is a rum start, and I can’t name the voice, but it’s someone skylarking—someone that’s flesh and blood, and you may lay to that.”
His courage had come back as he spoke, and some of the colour to his face along with it. Already the others had begun to lend an ear to this encouragement and were coming a little to themselves, when the same voice broke out again—not this time singing, but in a faint distant hail that echoed yet fainter among the clefts of the Spy-glass.
“Darby M’Graw,” it wailed—for that is the word that best describes the sound—“Darby M’Graw! Darby M’Graw!” again and again and again; and then rising a little higher, and with an oath that I leave out: “Fetch aft the rum, Darby!”
The buccaneers remained rooted to the ground, their eyes starting from their heads. Long after the voice had died away they still stared in silence, dreadfully, before them.
“That fixes it!” gasped one. “Let’s go.”
“They was his last words,” moaned Morgan, “his last words above board.”
Dick had his Bible out and was praying volubly. He had been well brought up, had Dick, before he came to sea and fell among bad companions.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
```python
"""
Simulated output of the generate_literary_segment function based on the provided metadata.
"""
“Come,” said Silver, struggling with his ashen lips to get the word out; “this won’t do. Stand by to go about. This is some trick of that fellow that lives in the wood. Come, lads, it’s not frighting gold we’re after, but gold that you can feel in your hand. Hands up and ready to march.”

He stood and shook himself and looked about him with so natural an air of command that the pirates were half-reassured. But just as the first man had taken a step, the voice sounded again, fainter now, as if from a greater distance, but still clear and great and strange, and the note of it was still a singing note, but sorrowful now and husky, and with a note of fear in the sound that was new.

“Darby M’Graw,” it wailed—for that is the word that best describes the sound—“Darby M’Graw! Darby M’Graw!” again and again and again; and then rising a little higher, and with an oath that I dare not write, “Fetch aft the rum, Darby!”

The buccaneers remained rooted to the ground, their eyes staring, their mouths open, their knees trembling. They were like men who had been struck by lightning.

“That settles it,” gasped one. “Let’s go.”

“They were Flint’s last words,” moaned Morgan, “they were his last words on board the *Walrus*.”

Dick, who had fallen on his knees, was praying aloud with a fervour and an evident sincerity that did the lad credit.
```

- If the completion omits the initial dialogue and actions of the main speaker, this is a significant missing section at the start.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- Early in the passage, the completion may lack the description of the speaker's physical struggle and the attempt to encourage the group.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- If the completion provides an incorrect order of events, such as having the group react before the voice is heard, this is a sequencing error.
- If the completion attributes actions or dialogue to the wrong characters, this is a misattribution.
- If invented reflections, explanations, or scenes are added that do not appear in the original, these are inaccuracies that should be avoided.
- If the emotional tone or the level of fear and tension is not maintained as in the original, this is an inaccuracy in the portrayal of the scene's atmosphere.

events.title: Silver's Defiance and Rationalization of the Mysterious Voice
detailed_summary: Despite the pervasive fear, Long John Silver remained determined, his teeth audibly rattling but his resolve intact.
He muttered that only those present on the island would know the name Darby M'Graw.
Making a significant effort, he addressed his shipmates, declaring his intention to retrieve the treasure and his refusal to be bested by man or spirit.
He proclaimed he had never feared Flint during his lifetime and, by the powers, would confront him even in death, especially with seven hundred thousand pounds at stake.
However, his followers showed no signs of renewed courage; instead, they seemed more terrified by the irreverence of his words.
Merry warned Silver not to challenge or anger a spirit.
The rest of the pirates were too frightened to speak, huddling close to Silver as if his daring offered them some measure of protection, while Silver himself had largely overcome his own fear.
Silver then questioned the nature of the phenomenon, pointing out that the voice produced an echo, something he argued a spirit would not naturally possess.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Still Silver was unconquered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That ain’t in natur’, surely?”

events.text_segment:
Still Silver was unconquered. I could hear his teeth rattle in his head, but he had not yet surrendered.
“Nobody in this here island ever heard of Darby,” he muttered; “not one but us that’s here.” And then, making a great effort: “Shipmates,” he cried, “I’m here to get that stuff, and I’ll not be beat by man or devil. I never was feared of Flint in his life, and, by the powers, I’ll face him dead. There’s seven hundred thousand pound not a quarter of a mile from here. When did ever a gentleman o’ fortune show his stern to that much dollars for a boozy old seaman with a blue mug—and him dead too?”
But there was no sign of reawakening courage in his followers, rather, indeed, of growing terror at the irreverence of his words.
“Belay there, John!” said Merry. “Don’t you cross a sperrit.”
And the rest were all too terrified to reply. They would have run away severally had they dared; but fear kept them together, and kept them close by John, as if his daring helped them. He, on his part, had pretty well fought his weakness down.
“Sperrit? Well, maybe,” he said. “But there’s one thing not clear to me. There was an echo. Now, no man ever seen a sperrit with a shadow; well then, what’s he doing with an echo to him, I should like to know? That ain’t in natur’, surely?”

"Ay, and he's at the door of hell this minute, or he's kicked out to roam the earth in glory," cried Silver. "By the powers, men, what's to think of this? We're his dead men, are we? I was never afeard of Flint in his life, and, by the powers, I'll face him dead. There's seven hundred thousand pound not two hundred yards from here. Are you to be frightened out of that by the ghost or the devil?" He stopped, for they were not following him. "Speak up, lads," he said, standing by himself, and looking round with a sort of stern command or desperation. "Lads, say something. "Well," he said, at last, breaking the silence. "You lads, it seems, are too much of a messmate for the likes of Flint. By the powers, men, it's close by us, and it's sure enough of the devil. But there's one thing that's clear. This is no time for skulk-ing. We must stand up to it. events.title: Identifying the Voice as Ben Gunn's: Relief and Renewed Pursuit
detailed_summary: Although Jim Hawkins found Silver's reasoning about the echo unconvincing, it significantly reassured the superstitious George Merry.
Merry commended Silver's intelligence and urged the crew to reconsider their fear, stating he believed they were mistaken in their terror.
He then observed that while the voice resembled Flint's, it wasn't identical and sounded more like someone else's.
Silver suddenly and loudly identified the voice as belonging to Ben Gunn.
Morgan, jumping to his knees, enthusiastically agreed with Silver's assessment.
Dick questioned if it mattered whose voice it was, since Ben Gunn was not physically present any more than Flint.
The older pirates dismissed Dick's comment with disdain, Merry asserting that Ben Gunn was of no consequence, whether alive or dead.
The pirates' spirits remarkably lifted, their natural complexions returned, and they soon resumed chatting, pausing intermittently to listen.

After hearing no further sounds, they picked up their tools and continued their quest, with Merry leading, using Silver's compass to stay on course from Skeleton Island, proving that Ben Gunn, alive or dead, was not feared.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: This argument seemed weak enough to me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had said the truth: dead or alive, nobody minded Ben Gunn.

events.text_segment:
This argument seemed weak enough to me. But you can never tell what will affect the superstitious, and to my wonder, George Merry was greatly relieved.
“Well, that’s so,” he said. “You’ve a head upon your shoulders, John, and no mistake. ’Bout ship, mates! This here crew is on a wrong tack, I do believe. And come to think on it, it was like Flint’s voice, I grant you, but not just so clear-away like it, after all. It was liker somebody else’s voice now—it was liker—”
“By the powers, Ben Gunn!” roared Silver.
“Aye, and so it were,” cried Morgan, springing on his knees. “Ben Gunn it were!”
“It don’t make much odds, do it, now?” asked Dick. “Ben Gunn’s not here in the body any more’n Flint.”
But the older hands greeted this remark with scorn.
“Why, nobody minds Ben Gunn,” cried Merry; “dead or alive, nobody minds him.”
It was extraordinary how their spirits had returned and how the natural colour had revived in their faces. Soon they were chatting together, with intervals of listening; and not long after, hearing no further sound, they shouldered the tools and set forth again, Merry walking first with Silver’s compass to keep them on the right line with Skeleton Island. He had said the truth: dead or alive, nobody minded Ben Gunn.

events.title: The March Resumes: Dick's Worsening Condition and the Search for the Trees
detailed_summary: Only Dick continued to show fear, clutching his Bible and looking around nervously, but he found no support from the others; Silver even teased him about his caution.
Silver told Dick he had ruined his Bible and questioned its worth against a spirit, snapping his fingers dismissively.
Dick remained unconsoled, and Jim Hawkins noticed the young man was clearly becoming ill, his fever—predicted by Dr. Livesey—escalating due to the heat, fatigue, and shock.
The group moved through open terrain on the plateau, which sloped slightly to the west.
Pines of various sizes grew sparsely, and wide, sun-baked clearings lay between clusters of nutmeg and azalea.
Traveling roughly northwest, they moved nearer to the Spy-glass's base on one side, while on the other, their view expanded over the western bay where Jim had previously been adrift in the coracle.
They reached the first of the designated tall trees, but upon checking bearings, it proved to be the incorrect one.
The second tall tree they located also turned out to be the wrong marker.

events.text_segment:
Dick alone still held his Bible, and looked around him as he went, with fearful glances; but he found no sympathy, and Silver even joked him on his precautions.
“I told you,” said he—“I told you you had sp’iled your Bible. If it ain’t no good to swear by, what do you suppose a sperrit would give for it? Not that!” and he snapped his big fingers, halting a moment on his crutch.
But Dick was not to be comforted; indeed, it was soon plain to me that the lad was falling sick; hastened by heat, exhaustion, and the shock of his alarm, the fever, predicted by Dr. Livesey, was evidently growing swiftly higher.
It was fine open walking here, upon the summit; our way lay a little downhill, for, as I have said, the plateau tilted towards the west. The pines, great and small, grew wide apart; and even between the clumps of nutmeg and azalea, wide open spaces baked in the hot sunshine. Striking, as we did, pretty near north-west across the island, we drew, on the one hand, ever nearer under the shoulders of the Spy-glass, and on the other, looked ever wider over that western bay where I had once tossed and trembled in the coracle.
The first of the tall trees was reached, and by the bearings proved the wrong one. So with the second.

events.title: The True Landmark Tree and the Overwhelming Grip of Gold Fever
detailed_summary: The third tree they found was a colossal specimen, soaring almost two hundred feet high with a massive red trunk and a broad shadow, making it a prominent landmark visible from both east and west coasts.
However, it was not the tree's size that captivated the pirates, but the knowledge that seven hundred thousand pounds in gold was supposedly buried beneath its shadow.
As they drew closer to this tree, the intense desire for the money completely eclipsed their earlier fears.
Their eyes began to burn with anticipation, their steps became quicker and lighter, and their entire focus was consumed by the immense fortune awaiting them.
Silver, hobbling on his crutch, grunted with effort, his nostrils flared, and he cursed like a madman when flies landed on his heated face.
He violently tugged the rope securing Jim Hawkins to him and frequently cast deadly glares at the boy.

Jim clearly perceived that Silver made no effort to conceal his intentions: in the immediate proximity of the gold, all promises and warnings were forgotten, and Silver fully intended to seize the treasure, retake the Hispaniola by night, eliminate every honest person on the island, and sail away laden with riches and crimes as originally planned.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The third rose nearly two hundred feet into the air above a clump of underwood—a giant of a vegetable, with a red column as big as a cottage, and a wide shadow around in which a company could have manoeuvred.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Certainly he took no pains to hide his thoughts, and certainly I read them like print.

events.text_segment:
The third rose nearly two hundred feet into the air above a clump of underwood—a giant of a vegetable, with a red column as big as a cottage, and a wide shadow around in which a company could have manoeuvred. It was conspicuous far to sea both on the east and west and might have been entered as a sailing mark upon the chart.
But it was not its size that now impressed my companions; it was the knowledge that seven hundred thousand pounds in gold lay somewhere buried below its spreading shadow. The thought of the money, as they drew nearer, swallowed up their previous terrors. Their eyes burned in their heads; their feet grew speedier and lighter; their whole soul was bound up in that fortune, that whole lifetime of extravagance and pleasure, that lay waiting there for each of them.
Silver hobbled, grunting, on his crutch; his nostrils stood out and quivered; he cursed like a madman when the flies settled on his hot and shiny countenance; he plucked furiously at the line that held me to him and from time to time turned his eyes upon me with a deadly look. Certainly he took no pains to hide his thoughts, and certainly I read them like print.

```python
"""
The third rose nearly two hundred feet into the air above a clump of underwood—a giant of a vegetable, with a red column as big as a cottage, and a wide shadow around in which a company could have manoeuvred. It was conspicuous from all sides, the pirate's landmark, and the pirates had named it the "Spy-glass," by way of abbreviation, as it was visible from the Spy-glass Hill. I could see it myself from where I stood upon the neck and plain, and I daresay it was visible from the sea. It was not only by its height that this tree was remarkable, however, for it was the third of the four landmarks by which the treasure was to be buried. The pirates had been told that the seven hundred thousand pounds lay somewhere under its shadow. As we drew nearer, the lust of gold began to shine in their eyes. They quickened their pace, they forgot their terror, they were near enough now to taste the money, and all other considerations were forgotten. Their eyes burned in their heads; their feet grew speedier and lighter; their whole soul was bound up in that fortune. They ran, they leaped, they shouted, they cursed, they sang, they laughed, and tumbled one over another in their haste. Silver, hobbling, grunted for breath, and his nostrils and cheeks were dark with heat. When a fly settled on his face, he cursed it and spat at it, and knocked it off with his hand. He tugged at the rope that held me to him, and I saw that his eyes were fixed upon the tree, and that he was no longer thinking of me, but of the gold. I saw, too, that he was no longer pretending to be my friend, but was openly my enemy. He had forgotten his promises, his warnings, his threats. He was a pirate again, and a pirate of the blackest dye. I knew that when he had the gold, he would kill me, and all the honest men on the island, and sail away with the treasure and the ship, as he had planned from the first.
"""
```

events.title: Narrator's Dread and Haunting Memories on the Plateau's Edge
detailed_summary: Disturbed by Silver's threatening behavior and the evident danger, Jim Hawkins struggled to maintain the swift pace set by the gold-crazed pirates.
Whenever Jim stumbled, Silver would harshly pull the rope and glare at him with murderous intent.
Dick, who had fallen behind the group, was muttering a mixture of prayers and curses to himself as his fever intensified, which further added to Jim's misery.

To compound Jim's distress, he was haunted by the thought of the brutal tragedy that had previously unfolded on that very plateau, where the ruthless, blue-faced buccaneer Flint had personally murdered his six accomplices.
Jim imagined that the now-peaceful grove must have once echoed with their dying cries, and the thought made him feel as if he could still hear them.
The group finally arrived at the edge of the dense vegetation near the treasure site.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Shaken as I was with these alarms, it was hard for me to keep up with the rapid pace of the treasure-hunters.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We were now at the margin of the thicket.

events.text_segment:
Shaken as I was with these alarms, it was hard for me to keep up with the rapid pace of the treasure-hunters. Now and again I stumbled, and it was then that Silver plucked so roughly at the rope and launched at me his murderous glances. Dick, who had dropped behind us and now brought up the rear, was babbling to himself both prayers and curses as his fever kept rising. This also added to my wretchedness, and to crown all, I was haunted by the thought of the tragedy that had once been acted on that plateau, when that ungodly buccaneer with the blue face—he who died at Savannah, singing and shouting for drink—had there, with his own hand, cut down his six accomplices. This grove that was now so peaceful must then have rung with cries, I thought; and even with the thought I could believe I heard it ringing still.
We were now at the margin of the thicket.

events.title: The Shocking Discovery: An Empty Cache, The Treasure Gone
detailed_summary: Merry shouted enthusiastically, and the pirates at the front of the group began to run towards the expected location of the treasure.
Suddenly, less than ten yards further, they were seen to stop abruptly, and a low cry of dismay arose from them.
Silver increased his pace, digging his crutch into the ground with manic energy, and in the next moment, he and Jim Hawkins also came to a standstill.
Before them was a large excavation, evidently not of recent origin, as its sides had caved in and grass had begun to grow at the bottom.
Inside the pit lay the broken shaft of a pickaxe and several scattered boards from packing-cases.
On one of these boards, Jim Hawkins noticed the name 'Walrus'—the name of Captain Flint's ship—branded with a hot iron.
The situation was unequivocally clear: the treasure cache had been previously discovered and looted; the seven hundred thousand pounds were no longer there.

events.text_segment:
“Huzza, mates, all together!” shouted Merry; and the foremost broke into a run.
And suddenly, not ten yards further, we beheld them stop. A low cry arose. Silver doubled his pace, digging away with the foot of his crutch like one possessed; and next moment he and I had come also to a dead halt.
Before us was a great excavation, not very recent, for the sides had fallen in and grass had sprouted on the bottom. In this were the shaft of a pick broken in two and the boards of several packing-cases strewn around. On one of these boards I saw, branded with a hot iron, the name Walrus—the name of Flint’s ship.
All was clear to probation. The cache had been found and rifled; the seven hundred thousand pounds were gone!

events.title: The Empty Pit and Silver's Shifting Allegiance
detailed_summary: The six men are profoundly shocked to discover the treasure pit is empty.
Long John Silver, unlike the others, recovers swiftly from the disappointment, immediately adapting his strategy.
He covertly hands Jim a double-barrelled pistol and cautions him to prepare for trouble.
Silver strategically moves himself and Jim slightly apart from the other five buccaneers, using the hollow for separation.
He communicates their dangerous predicament to Jim with a meaningful nod.
Jim, repulsed by Silver's repeated betrayals, quietly remarks on Silver having switched allegiances once more.
The enraged buccaneers jump into the pit, digging frantically with their fingers and tossing aside planks, only to find a single two-guinea coin.
Merry angrily confronts Silver, deriding his supposed grand treasure and labeling him an incompetent leader.
Silver responds with cool insolence, suggesting they might discover some pig-nuts.
Merry, further infuriated, accuses Silver of having known all along that the treasure was gone.
Silver mockingly comments on Merry's renewed ambition to be captain.
This time, all the buccaneers align with Merry, climbing out of the excavation and casting furious looks at Silver.
Notably, the five opposing buccaneers position themselves on the side of the pit opposite to Silver and Jim.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There never was such an overturn in this world.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: One thing I observed, which looked well for us: they all got out upon the opposite side from Silver.

events.text_segment:
There never was such an overturn in this world. Each of these six men was as though he had been struck. But with Silver the blow passed almost instantly. Every thought of his soul had been set full-stretch, like a racer, on that money; well, he was brought up, in a single second, dead; and he kept his head, found his temper, and changed his plan before the others had had time to realize the disappointment.
“Jim,” he whispered, “take that, and stand by for trouble.”
And he passed me a double-barrelled pistol.
At the same time, he began quietly moving northward, and in a few steps had put the hollow between us two and the other five. Then he looked at me and nodded, as much as to say, “Here is a narrow corner,” as, indeed, I thought it was. His looks were not quite friendly, and I was so revolted at these constant changes that I could not forbear whispering, “So you’ve changed sides again.”
There was no time left for him to answer in. The buccaneers, with oaths and cries, began to leap, one after another, into the pit and to dig with their fingers, throwing the boards aside as they did so. Morgan found a piece of gold. He held it up with a perfect spout of oaths. It was a two-guinea piece, and it went from hand to hand among them for a quarter of a minute.
“Two guineas!” roared Merry, shaking it at Silver. “That’s your seven hundred thousand pounds, is it? You’re the man for bargains, ain’t you? You’re him that never bungled nothing, you wooden-headed lubber!”
“Dig away, boys,” said Silver with the coolest insolence; “you’ll find some pig-nuts and I shouldn’t wonder.”
“Pig-nuts!” repeated Merry, in a scream. “Mates, do you hear that? I tell you now, that man there knew it all along. Look in the face of him and you’ll see it wrote there.”
“Ah, Merry,” remarked Silver, “standing for cap’n again? You’re a pushing lad, to be sure.”
But this time everyone was entirely in Merry’s favour. They began to scramble out of the excavation, darting furious glances behind them. One thing I observed, which looked well for us: they all got out upon the opposite side from Silver.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: There never was such an overturn in this world. Each of these six men was as white as a sheet, and not they only, but Silver as well. They stood, for perhaps thirty seconds, silent, with their eyes riveted on the discovery. The boards most certainly had been removed recently, and every sign pointed to plunder, and plunder long ago; but though they had every reason to believe the treasure was gone, not one of the six budged an inch. Then, as if by agreement, they all turned with savage looks upon Silver. "Jim," he whispered, "take that." And he thrust into my hand one of the two pistols he still carried, a double-barrelled one. At the same time he began quietly moving northward, a little nearer to the trees. "Now, my lads," cried Merry, stepping forth, "there's the man to mend us! That's your captain now!" "Volunteers to your name!" cried Silver. "In the name of heaven, what's the meaning of this?" cried Merry. "Meaning?" cried Silver, "I'll give you scope for meaning, matey!" He paused, made as if to spit, but instead swallowed with a gulp. "Every man aboard of this ship was upon deck, sir," said he, "when that treasure was brought aboard. I'll swear to that. And every man that was alive when we sailed from here, sir, was alive and well when we came back. I'll swear to that too. And you can't tell me that any man aboard of this ship ever saw that treasure after it was put ashore. I'll swear to that too." "It's a clean sweep, sir," said Merry. "Not a coin left." "And you knew it, you dog!" cried Morgan. "You knew it all along!" "Ay, ay, mates," said Silver. "I knew it was gone. How else do you think I was so ready to come ashore?" "You'll swing for this!" cried Merry. "You'll swing for this, Silver!" "Swing?" said Silver. "Who's to make me swing? You? Or you?" He pointed to Merry and Morgan. "Come, come, mates," said he, "this is a poor way to go about business. There's the treasure gone, that's clear. But there's the ship, and there's the men. And there's the chart, mind you. We'll find it again. We'll find it again, never fear." "He's known it all along," cried Merry. "He's sold us!" "Ah, Merry," said Silver, "it's you that's come to be captain again, is it? You won't be captain long, my lad, unless you look sharper." "Down with the traitor!" cried Merry. "Ay, ay," cried the others. "Down with him!" Before you could wink, they were all upon their feet, and Merry, with a cutlass in his hand, was advancing on Silver. "Stand by, Jim," whispered Silver. "We'll have to fight for it now." He was as cool as ever, but his face was deadly pale. He was watching Merry with a narrow eye. The other four were on the side of the pit opposite to us. Merry was between us and the pit. "Come on, then," said Silver. "If you want a turn, you'll have to take it." Merry came on, and Silver raised his pistol. "Don't fire!" cried I. "You'll bring the others down on us!" "I know what I'm about," returned Silver. "Stand by!" He fired, and Merry tumbled head foremost into the excavation. The others paused for a second. Then, with a yell, they all leaped into the pit and began to dig with their hands. They tossed the boards aside. They dug like madmen. But there was nothing there. Not a coin. Not a speck of gold dust. Nothing but the single two-guinea piece that I had found in the sand. "Nothing!" they cried. "Nothing!" They scrambled out of the pit, their faces black with disappointment and rage. They cast furious looks at Silver. "You see for yourselves," said he. "It's gone. Every coin of it. And who's to blame? Not I. I was for coming ashore at once. It was you that kept me back. It was you that wanted to wait for the ship. It was you that thought the treasure was safe aboard. Well, you see for yourselves. It's gone." "He's known it all along," cried Merry, who had scrambled out of the pit, bleeding from a cut on his head. "He's known it all along!" "Ay, ay," said Silver. "I've known it all along. And I've known too that there was a ship in the offing. And I've known too that there was a man aboard of her that would be glad to see me. And I've known too that there was a man aboard of her that would be glad to see you too, Merry. And that man is Captain Smollett." He paused. "And now," said he, "you can do what you please. You
